PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
For permanent protection of old‐growth forests and all other areas of high conservation value, and for the implementation of tree plantation strategies.

This petition from the undersigned respectfully points out that: there is an increasing and urgent demand from the people, to protect all remaining high conservation value forests which support flora and fauna unique to Australia, thus complying with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention to which Australia is a signatory. We have a responsibility to future and present generations, and the necessary reasons, knowledge and technology to act now on the following achievable solutions.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate legislate to:

PARA.TAB: immediately stop all logging and woodchipping activities in high conservation value native forests;

ensure intergenerational equity by planning for the rights of future generations, and protecting in perpetuity all biologically diverse old‐growth forests, wilderness, rainforests and critical habitats of endangered species;

facilitate rapid transition of the timber industry from harvesting high conservation value native forests, to establishing mixed‐species farm forestry on existing cleared and degraded lands, using non‐toxic methods to protect ecological sustainability;

maximise use of readily‐available plantation timber for industry needs, using appropriate forestry techniques and progressive minimal‐waste processing methods, such as radial sawing, and wherever possible, reuse and recycle wood and paper products;

support incentives for nationwide employment in composting, soil remineralisation programs, and the planting programs of trees and annual fibre crops, inter‐grown with appropriate fruit and nut trees and medicinal plants;

encourage sensitively‐managed, environmental education tourism in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for natural ecosystems, Aboriginal cultural heritage, sacred sites and other sites of significance; and

progressively utilise technological expertise and resources transferred from the military sector, to help implement these tree planting solutions; and to motivate the international community to follow this example.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Darwin to Adelaide Railway
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:
We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia showeth that:
We are concerned with the outstanding debt owed to South Australia by the Commonwealth Government of Australia for South Australia's investment in Northern Territory.
Payment of this debt was to be in the form of a railway line from Darwin to Adelaide as a legislated agreement passed by Parliament in 1910 called the Northern Territory Acceptance Act 1910.

We have waited 87 years for the Commonwealth Government to honour and complete its obligation to the citizens of South Australia, and your petitioners therefore pray that this House will take all appropriate steps to ensure the fulfilment of this obligation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

The Australian Democrats believe that education should be available and accessible to all Australians, regardless of gender, age, health, background, racial or ethnic origin or place of residence. A distinction between part time and full time scholarships in our taxation laws imposes a restriction on the availability and accessibility to education.

We also believe that education is a lifelong process and all education is of value. We believe education has an increasingly important place in a rapidly changing and multi‐dimensional world. These changes and dimensions require human beings to adapt and confidently deal with the new circumstances through improvisation and an understanding of change. So it is in this context that scholarships are available to assist and reward the developments of a person's talents. The benefits of this talent can be in art work, new ideas, a new angle to an old theme or an achievement, and the list of possibilities goes on.

The history of the taxing provision provides an interesting insight into what the scholarship exemption was supposed to achieve. In 1950, the Spooner committee reported to the Treasurer at the time, the Right Honourable A.W. Fadden. The terms of reference of the committee were to examine the desirability of exempting scholarship income from taxation. At the time, England and New Zealand exempted scholarships from tax.

The committee concluded that payments in the form of `awards to enable students to pursue a course of study' should be exempt, while payments in the nature of remuneration for present and future services and living allowances should be taxed. The committee proposed an amendment to section 23 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, and the words they suggested are informative. They suggested the section should be amended to exclude tax on:
. . . the income arising from a fellowship, scholarship or bursary held by a person receiving instruction at a university, college, school or other educational establishment.

Since that time, the education sector has undergone considerable change. The attacks by both the former government and the current government are eroding the sector and moving the divide between educational purposes and industry purposes closer together. This blending of purposes was well illustrated by the Debate over the amendments to the Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1997, which removed the `rendering services' criteria from the full time scholarship provisions. That provision was modified by my amendments to the rendering services requirement and make sure full time scholarships were tax free. On this occasion it was notable that the Democrat's amendment was supported by all the other parties in the Senate.

At the time, the concern was only about full time scholarships. However, part‐time scholarships are not covered by that provision, and if they satisfy all other aspects of that provision they will be taxed as the provision now stands. This is an unfortunate distinction, and this Bill will address that distinction by extending the exemption from taxation to part‐time scholarships which satisfy all the same criteria as tax exempt full time scholarships. This Bill proposes an amendment which abolishes the distinction between full time and part‐time scholarships and makes all scholarships which satisfy the other criteria in the existing provisions tax free. That is, any scholarship, bursary or other educational allowance or educational assistance received by a student receiving education at a school college or university will be exempt from tax as long as there an educational purpose involved and there is no condition that the student will enter into employment.

Following the amendments to the tax status of full time scholarships I sought a response from the Government about part‐time scholarships. Question No. 296 lodged by me on 19 August 1997 and reported by the Senate Employment Education Training and Youth Affairs Legislation Committee asked:
What is the status of postgraduate scholarships made to part‐time students? Is the Government concerned that there may have been an oversight made in relation to tax on part‐time scholarships?
The Government's response was:

Part‐time Australian Postgraduate Awards (with Stipend) are available to students who have been successful in gaining an award and who can demonstrate heavy care commitments or a medical condition precluding full time study.

Part‐time scholarships are not exempt from tax under the provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act. The part‐time rate is set so that, after tax has been deducted, it is equivalent to 50% of the full time stipend.
There has been no oversight in relation to tax on part‐time scholarships.

This response deals with a particular kind of scholarship known as Australian Postgraduate Awards. There are any number of other scholarships which will satisfy the requirements of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, but fail only because they are part‐time. But, this response fails to address the broader issues raised by the different tax status of part and full time scholarships. It is these differences which make this Bill an important measure to redress injustice by identifying and remedying inequalities and barriers to participation in our education system. We want the best, so we must make sure the best people are chosen.

Scholarships are provided to talented people to assist them to develop their talents. This has benefits for the individual, but it has a broader purpose which contributes directly to our community. We recognise this benefit by providing tax free full time scholarships. The same recognition should apply to part‐time scholarships. This has been recognised in part for Australian Postgraduate Awards by increasing the amount of the half scholarship to take into account the taxation effect. This recognition is welcome, and supports the contention the existing scheme is an anomaly which should be remedied. This is reason enough to make the amendment set out in this Bill.

However, and more importantly, this anomaly in the taxation legislation discriminates against part‐time scholarship holders. The discrimination arises from the fact that a person receiving a part‐time scholarship, who receives any further income and/or benefits based on the income they declare for taxation purposes, will be treated differently from a person who receives a full time scholarship.

This is best illustrated by example. Liz Darley is the recipient of a part‐time Australian Postgraduate Award which she received on the basis of merit at the University of Western Sydney, Hawkesbury. She needed to take this scholarship on a part‐time basis so that she could care for her two small children. The unfairness in this case arises from Liz being denied access to child care assistance and her family payment reduced because of her scholarship (and other) income. I want to quote her words:

The problem I have is that full time scholarships are not taxed and therefore regarded as non‐taxable income; no group certificates are issued, and other benefits such as child care assistance and home child care allowance are not affected by the stipend. However, part‐time scholarships are regarded as taxable income. This affects the amount of child care rebate I am entitled to, as well as home child care allowance, and also means that if I undertake any extra work (such as teaching and tutoring) this work gets added to my scholarship as taxable income. A person on a full time scholarship does not have to declare their scholarship as income, so any extra income they make is considered as their only income. If I make $5 000 on top of my scholarship of $8 253, then my taxable income is $13 252. If I took a full time scholarship of $15 000+, then my taxable income would be $5 000. I think you would agree this is inequitable.

This is a particular concern for women who make up a significant proportion of scholarship holders and a structural barrier to participation in higher education. Structural barriers in the education sector mean that talented people are excluded for reasons other than merit, such as gender, age, disability, ethnicity, etc.. For this reason alone, structural barriers must be removed to ensure our most talented students are provided with the opportunities to develop and express their special talents. Removing the distinction between part‐time and full time scholarship taxation, which this Bill does, is a step in the right direction.

Liz's case also highlights other inequalities in the higher education sector which future legislation affecting the higher education sector and many other sectors must address—structural barriers to women's participation in the education system.

The UN Fourth World Conference, Women's Platform for Action considered women in education as one of the twelve critical areas of concern addressed by the conference. Women's access to vocational training, science and technology and continuing education was specifically targeted in the list of actions to be taken by governments. This Platform of Action was agreed to by the former Labor Government, and the present Coalition Government has stated that it intends to uphold its commitments under the Platform.

The Government's commitment to abolishing structural barriers is doubtful and may be illustrated by an example. In May 1993 the then Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science and the Minister for Science and Small Business established the Women in Science, Engineering and Technology (WISET) Advisory Group to advise on strategies to improve women's participation in science, engineering and technology careers and education. The WISET Advisory Group prepared a report in the form of a discussion paper in May 1995 setting out some of the barriers facing women in science, engineering and technology.

Unhappy with the lack of response from the previous Government I asked the Coalition Government how they proposed to respond to the Advisory Group report. In response to a Question on Notice No. 447 dated 24 March 1997 the Minister for Science and Technology stated that the Advisory Group report would not be responded to because the "recommendations are more relevant to the outlook of the previous Government". Instead, the Government intends to pursue women's representation in science, engineering and technology areas by creating a "broad, positive environment in which all Australians have the maximum opportunity to achieve their potential". This includes the provision of non‐gender specific scholarships and awareness programs in relation to science, engineering and technology areas.

This response fails to recognise the systemic issues of discrimination identified in the Advisory Group report and will ensure that women in science, engineering and technology areas continue to face individual experiences of discrimination, and that women will not have equal access to representation in the science, engineering and technology community as a right . Unhappy with the response to Question No. 447 I asked a further Question on Notice No. 687 dated 7 July 1997. The Minister responded that the Government "is not aware of any structural barriers to women participating in science, engineering and technology careers" even though the Government has examined the WISET report. Does this mean the Government has rejected the WISET report?

Since that time the Australian National University has received the Burton Report which identifies a range of (similar) structural barriers to women's participation in a non‐science section of the University. Clearly, there is a problem here and the Government, and former Government, are trying to ignore the issues.

This Bill provides the Government with an opportunity to meet their international commitments and remove a measure which, as in Liz's case, specifically disadvantages women with small children participating in the higher education sector.

The costs of this proposal will be minimal and the outcomes in terms of equity are significant. I commend this Bill to the Senate as a measure directed at assisting talented Australians to achieve their full potential in a world where the benefits of highly educated persons are central to job creation and wealth for all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Gibson, I present the report of the Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee on the format of the portfolio budget statements together with submissions and the transcripts of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert, Sen Paul

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate Senator Gibson's speech in Hansard and to move a motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

This is the fourth report by the Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee—or its predecessors—on the format and contents of the explanatory material provided to senators for use in estimates hearings; and it is the thirteenth occasion on which the committee has reported on a matter referred to it by the Senate following the recommendation of another committee and arising out of the estimates process. Clearly the committee has acquired a role as watchdog and mouthpiece of the Senate's interest in these matters, a role I welcome as it enables the committee to build on a considerable body of expertise from the endeavours of previous members including fellow Taswegians Peter Rae and John Coates.

On this occasion, the committee's inquiry originated from the difficulties many senators experienced in using the Portfolio Budget Statements (PBS) for 199697. This was a matter of some significance as the PBS are some of the most significant of the accountability documents presented to Parliament. The committee concluded that in part at least, the difficulties related to the fact that there had been machinery of government changes following the change of government in March 1996; there was a one-off return to an August budget; there were 15 new or inexperienced senators; and a number of former ministers coming to grips with the use of the documentation for the first time in Opposition.

In conducting this inquiry, the committee sought the views of departments and agencies through their portfolio ministers and most responded with submissions and by sending representatives to the committee's round-table public hearing. The committee is extremely grateful for their helpful input and for that of the senators who participated in the hearing or the briefing with Finance. It singles out for particular thanks officers of the Department of Finance who have been of continuing assistance to the committee. The majority of senators was less forthcoming and the committee relied for the most part on extrapolating their views on the PBS from what was said in the estimates hearings.

The committee considers that the chief function of the PBS is to explain the Appropriation Bills. The fact that the legislation committees considering the estimates range far and wide does not mean that the PBS should attempt to second-guess senators' interests and attempt to cater for them in the documentation. The Department of Finance circulates its PBS guidelines widely for comment every year, so the opportunity is there through this committee or any legislation committee to have input to the format of the documentation.

After examining the evidence it received and many PBS themselves, the committee concluded that there were no major problems with the format of the documents and that the annual fine-tuning by Finance was helpful. With regard to the contents of the PBS, the committee noted certain problems with inconsistencies across portfolios in the level of detail contained and in the level of desegregation of the estimates. It also noted regular changes to program structures, which can have the effect of obscuring expenditure trends.

Having documented these and other problems, the committee has desisted from recommending any changes to the PBS for the final year before the move to accrual budgeting. That move, which the committee welcomes, will nevertheless cause a complete reworking of the documentation. The committee looks forward to working with the Department of Finance to ensure that the accrual budgeting PBS are as succinct, helpful and user-friendly as possible while continuing in their role as explanatory memoranda and accountability tool.

It must be said that the estimates process has moved beyond the capacity of any document to act as a single briefing document. The PBS cannot and should not be expected, in the short time-frame and in the increasingly complex budgeting environment in which they are prepared, to say it all. We will all have to learn to accommodate an array of accountability documents, including annual reports, audit reports, evaluations, corporate plans. And moreover, we may need to specialise even more. In an attempt to assist senators in their handling of the estimates process, rather than bulking out the PBS, the committee encourages the use by legislation committees of pre-hearing factual briefings from portfolio officers. It also encourages Finance to hold workshops for senators and their staff and perhaps provide a telephone hotline for explanations of the budgeting conventions which so often cause misunderstandings.

The committee has agreed to report again on the format of the PBS under accrual budgeting. Both to assist it in this task and to provide some feedback to the compilers of the documents, the committee recommends that legislation committees, in their reports on the estimates, be required to comment on the format and the content of the PBS.
I commend the report to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: (3) A proclamation fixing a day for the commencement of section 59 is not to be made unless:

TAB.TAB: (a) a public inquiry, sponsored by the Governments of New South Wales and Victoria, has been held with respect to environmental issues arising out of the current pattern of water flows in rivers and streams, caused by the operation of the Snowy Mountains Scheme, and the Minister is satisfied with the adequacy of the conduct, outcome and planned implementation of the inquiry, having regard to the continuing viability of the Scheme; and
(b) the Minister is satisfied that the Governments of New South Wales and Victoria have agreed to that section commencing on that day.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an amendment that we debated in prospect to some extent yesterday in the second reading stage when the Greens' amendment was under consideration by the Senate. The amendment that I propose on this occasion, as I said in the debate yesterday, addresses the situation that was the subject of yesterday's consideration. In saying that, I acknowledge that that is not the view of the Greens and I do not think it is the view of the Australian Democrats. However, it is the view of the opposition.
This amendment will insert in clause 2 a new subclause (3) in place of the existing subclause (3) to read:

. . . a public inquiry, sponsored by the Governments of New South Wales and Victoria, has been held with respect to environmental issues arising out of the current pattern of water flows in rivers and streams, caused by the operation of the Snowy Mountains Scheme, and the Minister is satisfied with the adequacy of the conduct, outcome and planned implementation of the inquiry, having regard to the continuing viability of the Scheme . . .

That relates to the operation of this bill, and it would require that the minister is satisfied that all of the water studies that have been the subject of this debate have been properly completed and that the planned implementation has been properly executed.

That is the nature of the amendment that I seek to insert. If it is carried, it will ensure that the Commonwealth government does not ignore the Snowy Mountains scheme once the legislation is passed. Under the amendment, the government will have to be satisfied with the adequacy, conduct, outcome and implementation of the results of the water inquiry. The bill, as it currently stands, is very limited in so far as the role of the Commonwealth in the establishment of the water inquiry is concerned, as the Commonwealth has in essence left this responsibility to the states.

The reality is that the Snowy River is a national icon and therefore deserves, at the very least, a national interest policy consideration by this government. The amendment that I have foreshadowed goes some way to ensuring that the government pays some attention to the national interest in regard to the Snowy. It is vital that the Commonwealth is satisfied with the national outcome, given that the various issues the water inquiry needs to look at include the Snowy's rehabilitation, the water distribution between electricity generation, irrigation and environmental interests, and the management of those issues for the future. They involve questions of balance and questions of national significance. Neither the government nor the parliament should cede its responsibilities until it is satisfied that an appropriate balance has been found in respect of the various issues concerned.

The Snowy is a national infrastructure project, and at the very least it deserves the attention of the national government. We did debate this issue to so some extent yesterday, but they are the formal remarks I wish to attach to the moving of this amendment. I commend the amendment to the committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support this amendment because it is a small step in the right direction. We certainly welcome the opportunity for the public to have some input. While I understand that was going to happen informally, there was no real requirement for it in this legislation. However, I want to stress that we do not believe this goes anywhere near far enough in terms of the role of this parliament. Ideally, we would have liked a wide ranging inquiry held, with the involvement of the New South Wales and Victorian governments, and then a full and open assessment by the parliament of the outcomes of that inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: I also believe that, as far as this critical issue of water usage is concerned, this parliament should have maintained some contact, some thread by which it can continue an overseeing role. This is why I will be moving subsequent amendments regarding privatisation. If we lose control of what is Australia's largest river system and we do not sort out the problems facing the Snowy River at this time, I think we will stand condemned by future generations for our inaction. We will be supporting this amendment. To simply leave it to the minister to decide whether or not he or she is satisfied does not go as far as our responsibilities require us to go.

TALKER.NAME: Senator PARER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —This was a matter canvassed at the Senate Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee and it was a point made by Senators Lundy and Ray in a dissenting report. Subsequently, the opposition moved a similar amendment in the House of Representatives and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) stated, on my behalf, that I would consider the amendment and seek expert advice. Following that, the opposition made a number of minor changes to the text of that amendment as presented in the House of Representatives, and I am pleased to advise the Senate that the government supports that amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, in relation to this amendment, and referring to an answer to question on notice No. 346 which the minister kindly provided in February this year, can he say whether the 1995 scoping study undertaken jointly by the New South Wales and Victorian government departments into the impacts of an increased water flow from Lake Jindabyne has been made public; and, if not, why not? Secondly, can the minister say which other river environments will be studied for assessment of the impact of allowing water to flow down the Snowy? The minister has indicated in that answer to my question that there will be a look at the environmental impact of releasing water from the Jindabyne Dam on rivers, including the Snowy. Which other rivers are to be investigated by this water study?

SPEECH.PARA: Thirdly, the minister indicated in his answer that, post‐corporatisation, to effect an environmental flow down the Snowy River will require action by the New South Wales government, the Victorian government and the Commonwealth government, including legislative action. Can the minister tell the committee what that action would be?

TALKER.NAME: Senator PARER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —With regard to the first question, that study has not been made public. It is up to the New South Wales government to make that public, and they have not done so. The water inquiry would, of course, be all‐encompassing. It would cover not only the upstream damming of the Snowy but also downstream at places like the Murrumbidgee and so on. As pointed out, if you have read the report of the Senate Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee, you will notice that, with the Snowy itself, there are a lot of competing interests. We heard this in the debate yesterday, particularly from Senator West, who was particularly concerned about things like salination and the continuing irrigation of the Griffith area. There are many competing interests, and environmental flows is certainly one of them. Other interests to be considered are water for irrigation for the Great Dividing Range, water to address salination and loss of agricultural land along the Murray River, and water for electricity generation for the hydro itself. It will be broad.
—South Australia would like some.

—I was wondering, Senator, when you were going to show some interest as to whether they might get chopped off. I think that was pretty well covered in the hearings of the Senate Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee. It is important, when we refer these things to legislative committees, that we do not then regurgitate them. Senator Brown's final question was with regard to the water supply. What is determined in the outcome would determine what Snowy hydro could do with its water with regard to irrigation, whatever environmental flows are involved, and the generation of electricity.

—I would like to elaborate on that. The point I wanted clarified was what legislative measure would be required by this parliament if, for example, the early scientific advice was that a 28 per cent restoration of flow to the Snowy was required for minimum environmental requirements. How would the government produce that legislation and introduce it into this place? What measures could be agreed to by the government without legislation for a variation in the flow of the Snowy River beyond Jindabyne?

TALKER.NAME: Senator PARER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are no legislative requirements. What we have agreed to, and I mentioned this yesterday in the second reading, has occurred after a lot of debate. There was debate about whether the corporatisation would take place first and then they would do the inquiry. The comment was made, and I think quite correctly at the time, that without corporatisation there would be no inquiry. There were no requirements under the existing act and under the existing operation of the Snowy system for any environmental flows to take place at all. One of the arguments used in debate between the various jurisdictions was that without corporatisation there would be no addressing of any environmental flows on the Snowy. Out of that came a situation, which I think I said in the hearings before the committee was probably a better outcome, where the inquiry would take place, it would take six months, then there would be a two-month review or whatever time was required, but two months was the time frame, and that only following that would the legislation be proclaimed in the various jurisdictions.

—Thank you, Minister. If no legislation would be required for restoring some flow to the Snowy, what did you mean by (6) of your answer to my question No. 346, when you said that `any restoration of part of the flow of the Snowy River and the necessary legislative process will be determined by government subsequent to the forthcoming inquiry'?

TALKER.NAME: Senator PARER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Can you just quote that again? I am trying to find it.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: BROWN

TALK.START.PARA: —The quote is (6) of the answer to my question, which was:

INTERJECT.PARA: Will the Government table subordinate legislation to provide for restoration of part of the Snowy River's environmental flow.

Any restoration of part of the flow of the Snowy River and the necessary legislative process will be determined by Governments subsequent to the forthcoming inquiry and any consequent environmental impact processes. (See (4))
That is, see (4) of the question above.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a problem here. Was your question, `What are the terms of reference of the proposed inquiry'; is that the one you are referring to, or is there another series of questions?
—Question No. 346 began with, `What is the Government's timetable for corporatising the Snowy Mountains Hydro Electric Authority?' I got the answer to that question on 4 February this year.
—Senator, I think you have asked a series of questions on this before, and I think we have the wrong list here.
—I would be happy to give you a copy of this.
—No, that is fine. The answer to your question is that any legislation in respect of that would be New South Wales legislation, not federal legislation.

—Thank you. In the answer to the question, you said that that legislative process will be determined by governments. So I presume there that, while it might be New South Wales legislation, it would be a requirement for the Commonwealth to have input. Could you indicate to the committee what the form of that input would be?

TALKER.NAME: Senator PARER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to that question is two-fold. First, in regard to the terms of reference for the water inquiry, we need to have some input into that to assure ourselves that it is broad and that it covers all the aspects. The second part of it is now covered by the Labor amendment which we have agreed to—that we need to assure ourselves of the adequacy of the conduct, outcome and planned implementation and having regard to the continuing viability of the scheme.

—I go back to an earlier part of the minister's answer where we were speaking about the impact on other rivers in the Snowy of restoring part of the natural flow of the Snowy. What I was looking for there was a recognition that the inquiry would look into the impact on rivers, like the Murrumbidgee and the Murray, of their increased flow due to the diversion west of the Snowy. That will, on first principle, have a negative impact on those river systems if you are looking at the natural environment. I wonder whether the water inquiry will be looking at what that impact has been, and what amelioration of that impact there would be, by restoring part of the flow to the east and south through the Snowy River.

TALKER.NAME: Senator PARER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me repeat exactly what I said in regard to the competing interests. Those competing interests are: water for the environmental flows; things such as tourism; irrigation west of the range; salination. Then we get into things such as flood mitigation; agricultural land along the Murray River; and, as I said, the electricity generation itself. So it does cover the whole area where there are—and I think you would agree—a lot of competing interests. The water inquiry, as pointed out by Mr Whelan in the New South Wales parliament, will develop costed options for environmental flows.

—The minister is not getting the point of my request, which is not about tourism and not about irrigation; it is about the natural environment of the Murrumbidgee and Murray River systems, and the impact on that natural environment by the enhanced flow due to the diversion, since 1949, of the Snowy River. Has an assessment of the impact of the abnormally high flow on the environment since 1949 been done on those westward flowing river systems? And will the water inquiry be looking at what amelioration of that impact there would be through restoring part of the natural flow of the Snowy?

TALKER.NAME: Senator PARER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I do not know what assessments have been made, but I am sure there have been a lot made in regard to things such as salination. Let me say to you that, yes, it will all be part of the water inquiry.

—Thank you. Going back to the first part of my question about the scoping study by the New South Wales authorities, does the minister or his department have a copy of that study or has it been studied by him or the department? And, if so, what pressure has been put on the New South Wales government to make public that important document?

TALKER.NAME: Senator PARER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to your question, apparently we do have a copy of it, but it is up to the New South Wales government to release it and they have not released it.
—Would the minister write to the New South Wales government to express concern that has arisen during this debate and ask the New South Wales government to allow publication of that document?

TALKER.NAME: Senator PARER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue has been raised by us with them and we have put some pressure on, but so far they have resisted.
—Would you use your good offices to write to the New South Wales government and try again as a consequence of it being raised in this committee?
—Yes, senator.

—Thank you very much. Finally, I wonder if the minister has been to see the downstream effects on the Snowy River. Would he be good enough to indicate to the committee—and through it to the people of downstream centres like Dalgety and Orbost—that he would be prepared to consider an invitation to have a look at the Snowy River, the impact and their concerns?

TALKER.NAME: Senator PARER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mistakenly in the inquiry I said that I had not been there, but in fact I went there a few years ago. I am happy to visit the area whenever I can get a spare moment. In fact, I have been invited to have a general overlook at the whole Snowy system and on both occasions I have been frustrated by this place sitting on a Friday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —That is very positive and I thank the minister for that. Finally, like Senator Lees and her colleagues, I will be supporting this amendment, but I have to indicate to the Senate—seeing that we have not discussed the matter since yesterday—that it is weak. I am disappointed that we did not see Senator Margetts's much stronger amendment which would have required the water inquiry's recommendations to have been implemented, rather than this amendment which leaves it to the minister. I do not have too much faith in that process at all. I can assure the minister that, whatever the outcome of the inquiry, this matter will continue to be raised in this chamber in the strongest terms until the day comes when the restoration of a minimal natural flow to the Snowy River is achieved.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 7, page 7 (line 5), omit "The Commonwealth", substitute "Subject to subsection (2A), the Commonwealth".
(2) Clause 7, page 7 (after line 13), after subclause (2), insert:

PARA.TAB: (2A) The Commonwealth must not dispose of or transfer shares in the Snowy Hydro Company without the approval of the Parliament if the disposal or transfer of shares would result in the Commonwealth holding less than the relevant percentage of all issued shares.

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments require the government to come back to this place before selling off its share in the corporation. From the beginning the Democrats have argued that this bill should have been treated as a bill initially to determine how the water was going to be allocated from the system and then secondly as a bill which was dealing with corporatisation.

The way the bill is drafted it is really a bill that will enable privatisation. Effectively, yes, it is labelled and named the Snowy River Hydro Corporatisation Bill, but the more accurate description, looking at the contents, should be the Snowy Hydro Corporatisation and Potential Privatisation Bill.

There are many question marks that still hang over the allocation of water and how much goes east or west, where it goes and to what. I am sure anyone who is aware of the committee report will know all the various bits and pieces and about the various competing interests. But certainly, until that is all sorted out and adequately dealt with, we should not even be thinking of corporatisation, let alone privatisation. I have moved these amendments and I will leave it to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendments. I would like to ask the minister a couple of questions in view of the clear possibility—and I would say probability and almost certainty—that corporatisation is the first step towards the privatisation of Snowy Mountain scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: It is proposed that existing water rights will be continued for 75 years, with a 50‐year renewal option. I would like to ask the minister: how will environmental water be provided under such a regime and will the government rule out that the environment has to pay to recover water, that is, that the people have to pay for the environmental amenity that has been taken away being restored?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALKER.NAME: Senator PARER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The rights of the scheme with respect to water will be continued under a water licence granted by the appropriate New South Wales water authority. As pointed out by both you and Senator Lees, that will be for an initial term of 75 years with a renewal.

SPEECH.PARA: Dr Dalziel of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy in his evidence to the committee explained there is a provision in the New South Wales legislation for more frequent analysis and review of those arrangements. He stated:
Governments have agreed that the licence will require that those arrangements be reviewed every five years and every 10 years for environmental flow.

TALK.START.PARA: —If it is decided that an environmental flow of 28 per cent—to take the scientists' assessment—is required, will that environmental flow be given to the Snowy River without cost? Or is there going to be a cost involved and, if so, who is going to pay it and how is that cost going to be met?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALKER.NAME: Senator PARER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Brown is pre-empting the outcome of inquiry. He is automatically assuming that that is what the inquiry will show. Of course, if there was an increased flow to the Snowy, there would be a cost and that cost may not just be electricity. It may also be a cost to the irrigators downstream on the western side.

SPEECH.PARA: They are the sorts of things which will be part of the inquiry itself. I do not think we need to pre‐empt the inquiry. The inquiry is broad. I think we have covered all that. It is encompassing and it will look at all the costs, whether relating to electricity, irrigation, flood mitigation or salination. It is going to be a fairly broad inquiry. The decision as to the decision making process at the end of the day will be made by New South Wales and Victoria, with us having a look to make sure that everything is okay—in accordance with the Labor Party amendment to which we have agreed.

One of the things raised in the committee was the question of section 100 of the constitution. We had the benefit of evidence from the Australian Government Solicitor. He explained the background to the legislation. He pointed out that water is traditionally a state area. The Commonwealth only had the power to make legislation about it under the 1909 Seat of Government Acceptance Act.
As an aside, I do not know how the Commonwealth initiated all this back in 1949 and only ended up with 13 per cent. There must be a story behind that.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can blame Bob Menzies for that.

—I thought it was done by the Labor Party in 1949. Anyway, under the 1909 Seat of Government Acceptance Act, the state of New South Wales granted the Commonwealth the right to use Snowy River water to generate electricity for the ACT. So that was the right that came to the federal parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I am intrigued by this costing—particularly the costing of an environmental amenity. My questions must not be taken as an agreement that you can put a dollar value on an environmental amenity.

SPEECH.PARA: That said, I am now led to ask the minister whether this water inquiry will include a cost assessment of the opportunity lost downstream from Jindabyne to communities—including the Aboriginal community—since 1949. We heard last night that there has been a break‐up of the Aboriginal community, that it has lost its connection with the river to a degree and that there has been a loss of fishing and recreational amenity. I know that the enor mous canoeing and rafting potential of the river has been lost. There have been all sorts of changes to the river downstream of Jindabyne. Will a cost assessment be made of that loss since 1949, and will the Snowy Mountains Hydro‐electric Authority be paying those communities—in monetary terms—for the loss of those opportunities?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALKER.NAME: Senator PARER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, the answer to your question would have to be no. Bear in mind that the whole Snowy irrigation system was based on the damming and diversion of the Snowy River and the Guthega River. Essentially it was an irrigation system, but there was also a massive engineering feat. If it had not been for that damming of the Snowy River, the hydroelectricity generating infrastructure could not have been put in place—and it is recognised around the world as being one of the great engineering feats.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that you will argue that there were environmental consequences. In response, I think I said yesterday during the second reading debate that at that time—going right back to 1949—those sorts of things were not taken into consideration.

However, the purpose of this inquiry is to look to the future and to cover all those items which I have mentioned—two or three times now, I think. It is to cover environmental flows, irrigation, salination, flood mitigation and electricity generation. That is the purpose of the inquiry. There may be efficiencies that can be made. I do not know until this whole inquiry is done. We have to wait for the inquiry to reach its conclusions. It may well be that there are more efficient ways of doing things which would enable water to be released into the Snowy, achieving some of the things you are looking for. I am not making any predictions about it.
All I can say to you is, let the water inquiry take its course. Everyone who has an interest in it will be able to participate in that inquiry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Here we get to the crux of the matter. If there is an environmental loss to be weighed up against an economic gain, you turn your back on it. But if there is an envi ronmental gain which is going to cost, you demand that payment be made for it.

SPEECH.PARA: This is part of the problem of loss of environmental amenity worldwide. Everywhere pollution is not paid for, destruction of forests is not paid for, loss of species is not paid for and degradation of fisheries is not paid for. Loss of variety in life is not paid for and loss of culture of indigenous people is ignored. Here we see, as clear as day, that, if there is an environmental cost which is to be weighed up against an economic gain, we ignore it. We have to change that.

Let us go out of the past and into the future. I ask the minister whether an assessment of the cost of the environmental detriment—from here on in—of not having a natural flow in the Snowy will be made? Such an assessment should take into account the loss of the tourist amenity potential, fishing potential and agricultural and irrigation potential which results from the loss of the river's natural flow. It should also consider the loss of potential extending right down to the fisheries and the ocean changes at the mouth of the Snowy River, as well as the loss of the use of the river as far as the Aboriginal people are concerned and the loss of the amenity for people in townships like Orbost and Dalgety.

Will those economic costs go on for centuries into the future? Here we have a government guaranteeing water flows for more than a century, but will those costs be assessed? It might be a difficult task, but it is essential that a fair‐minded attitude be taken. If we are going to take the economic rationalist viewpoint and determine these things according to dollar amounts, let us be fair‐handed about it and look at assessing the cost of the environmental amenity in the Snowy River; that is, the loss of the whole natural flow—not 28 per cent but 100 per cent of the natural flow downstream of Jindabyne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment to the bill by the Australian Democrats, moved by Senator Meg Lees, enables the parliament to make a decision on approving the disposal of transfers of shares if it would result in the Commonwealth holding less than a relevant percentage of all issued shares. On behalf of the opposition, I wish to indicate that we will be supporting that motion and voting for it.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to say a couple of words on this point and I will not delay the Senate very long. The debate that we were just engaging in seems to focus on the environmental loss of the river flows because of damming of the Snowy Mountains scheme. As a matter of historic record—because this was a matter of some minor interchange in the chamber a moment ago—the construction of the Snowy Mountains scheme was commissioned by the Chifley government but the opening of the scheme was handled by the Menzies government. The scheme was completed just as the Menzies government took power, so they opened the scheme. The reason why we have this very difficult management regime is that the Menzies government then gave the states of Victoria and New South Wales power to actually block any Commonwealth initiative about the management of the scheme.

If you look at the Snowy Mountains scheme, it is true that it was, in its day, one of the greatest civil engineering projects the world had seen and one that captured the imagination and admiration of Australians. It is an icon for that reason. It also attracted engineering praise from around the world.
The management of the scheme, though, is vested in the states of Victoria and New South Wales and in the Commonwealth—

TALK.START.PARA: —Paul Keating's father was a contractor.
—Paul Keating what?
—His father was a contractor on it.

—His father was a contractor; I did not know that. The point is that the structure of the scheme is run down. It needs a capital injection. Victoria and New South Wales use the scheme as a backup generator to lift their load when the load on their grid system cannot be met by their normal power supplies. They just throw a switch and away it goes, lifting the power supply into their grid out of the Snowy in order to meet peak load demand. Victoria and New South Wales have an equal say with the Commonwealth govern ment, and every time someone has wanted to spend a bit of money to actually make the scheme more efficient, which will have environmental consequences, those states have resisted, through successive governments, an ability to upgrade the scheme. Now that the engineering of it is being run down and is close to exhaustion, there is a need to do something about it.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Brown has raised the question of the riverine system below the damming. The amendment that the Senate just carried with the support of the government and, I think, the minor parties helps to put that into some context. The study that is being conducted on the water flows will be very important and the implementation of it will be very important.

Since we are talking about environmental damage and since you have been asked to respond to a question about the environmental impact of the reduction of river flows, you might also wish to tell the Senate from an environmental point of view, given the power generated by the Snowy Mountains Hydro‐Electric Authority since 1949 and if that had been generated by coal‐fired power stations, what has been forgone in terms of greenhouse gas emissions? How much have we saved Australia in greenhouse gas emissions by generating our electricity by hydro and not by coal‐fired power stations? I do not expect you to know that off the top of your head; you may wish to take it on notice. I ask that question because, when we are talking about the environment, one needs to keep a balance between all elements of the environment. I think that is a relevant question in getting a full picture.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALKER.NAME: Senator PARER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —When I got up to respond briefly to Senator Brown—because I think we have canvassed this whole thing in the previous amendment and I do not want to keep going over it—I intended to say that it is an interesting observation. The Snowy is the biggest contributor of renewable energy, by a long shot, of anything else on the mainland of Australia. The electricity generated by the Snowy, or the capacity of the Snowy, is 5,000 gigawatt hours. I am sure we can crank that all back and work out what it represents.
—How many tonnes of greenhouse gases?

—On a megawatt basis, you are talking about 3,000 megawatts. That is three times the size of the Gladstone power station and bigger than Eraring in New South Wales. I do not think Eraring is as big as that. So you are looking at millions of tonnes per year. Just by way of a rule of thumb, which I had calculated the other day, each tonne of coal generates about 2½ tonnes of CO2. I think we are the most efficient in the world and I think we would be using about two million tonnes for a 1,000 megawatt power station. That gives you some idea. You can run the figures out. Often people are mistaken when they look at the renewable energy usage in Australia, which is of the order of seven or eight per cent or thereabouts. About 90‐odd per cent of that, or more, comes from the Snowy and the Tasmanian hydro‐electric systems.

SPEECH.PARA: In response to the Democrats' amendment: the amendment states that the Commonwealth must not dispose of or transfer its shares in the Snowy hydro without the approval of the parliament. Essentially it is an attempt to prevent the Commonwealth from disposing of its 13 per cent holding in the company. It has only 13 per cent; Victoria has 29 per cent and New South Wales has 58 per cent. Certainly there have been overtures made—nothing has eventuated at this stage—for either New South Wales or Victoria to acquire the Commonwealth share in the Snowy. We are not a big player. What we are talking about in this bill is the corporatisation of the Snowy Mountains Hydro‐electric Authority. As Senator Lees has pointed out, Victoria and New South Wales have both stated that they may like to privatise their holdings in the company. I might add that it would be of limited value to us if that occurred to hold Snowy hydro shares if we retained 13 per cent.

There are in any case, I believe, compelling reasons against a government, particularly this one, continuing its own electricity generation assets. The national electricity market is increasingly competitive. Across the market, generators now bid against one another to supply electricity, which is of great benefit, I might say, to consumers, and wholesale purchasers to buy their electricity at prices set by the market. Spot wholesale prices have fallen almost 35 per cent, from $23 per megawatt hour to $15 per megawatt hour. This is below the cost of production of the Snowy Mountains Hydro‐electric Authority.

The competitive market means there are significant risks in owning electricity generators, and generators who make wrong investment decisions will, of course, perform badly. I do not believe we should risk sums of taxpayers' money assets in this way and believe that governments have better things to do with their money. I would like to ask the Senate to give us the flexibility to dispose of our Snowy hydro shares without further reference. I might say that the most likely outcome I can see at this stage—things may change—is that one or two of those states which have the bigger shareholdings may eventually take over the Commonwealth's 13 per cent in the Snowy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to come back to the question that I asked the minister before, and I will state it as simply as possible. An assessment is going to be made of the cost to the value of the Snowy Mountains authority and its output of restoring a natural flow to the Snowy River. I want to know if an assessment will be made of the cost to the residents, and the cost of the potential loss to the residents and other people potentially involved with the Snowy River downstream of Jindabyne, of not restoring the natural flow. That is, will the exercise be done of assuming that the natural flow is restored, that an amenity which was cut off in 1949 is there, and the loss of that amenity to the economies of New South Wales and Victoria, and particularly the local economies, of not having that flow there over the next 125 years?

TALKER.NAME: Senator PARER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we have canvassed this at great length. Senator Cook gave a background to the whole Snowy scheme. I gave a bit of a background to it and indicated that the great Snowy development came about because of certain things that had to be done at the time, like diverting the Snowy and so on. If it had not been for that, we would not have had the Snowy Mountains Hydro‐electric Authority or the Snowy Mountains scheme. We would not have had the irrigation, we would not have had the electricity generation which came after it. What we are saying is that we are starting from now.
—That is what I am saying.

—Correct, and I do not disagree with that. What we are saying is that part of that overall inquiry will look at all those aspects of it and it is not just a single‐issue aspect. I think you agree with me on that. It is the environmental water flows to the Snowy, it is water for irrigation, it is flood mitigation, it is salination and it is electricity generation. All of those things will have to come out in the inquiry. It is a six‐month inquiry and there will be a two‐month period for the various governments to look at it and to come out with some conclusion. What that is going to be I have no idea, and I would not like to pre‐empt whatever it is going to be. I think what you are saying to me, though I might be wrong, is this: `Look, some people have said it needs a 28 per cent increase in the flow to bring it back to what they would like it to be. Therefore that should be the conclusion, and we work backwards from that.' That is not going to be the way the inquiry is carried out.

—No, that is not what I am saying, Minister. What I am saying is that there ought to be an assessment of the cost to the Snowy River and those people who could or would depend on it of not having the natural flow from here on, because that natural flow has been stopped and will be stopped for the next 125 years at least by the very existence of the Snowy Mountains scheme, and a privatised Snowy Mountains scheme at that. Will this assessment include a value on the opportunity lost because the Snowy River does not have its full natural flow?

TALKER.NAME: Senator PARER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —All I can say is that it is a broad inquiry. Anyone who has got interest in this inquiry will be able to come forward and present their case. If there are people who want to present that sort of information to the inquiry, I am sure it would be very welcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I have put my concern to the committee. I have already seen one newspaper report—in the Canberra Times —flagging an assessment by Mr Costello that a restoration of a natural flow to the Snowy River could be detrimental to the cost of sale of the Snowy Mountains scheme of some $913 million.

SPEECH.PARA: I know what is going to happen; I have seen this happen before. We are going to get an inquiry which says you cannot restore the natural flow because it is going to cost X hundreds of millions of dollars. It is the great escape clause: we will not do anything about the environment. I am saying that, if you are taking a fair‐handed attitude to this, the alternative figure must come up. That is the opportunity lost by not having the natural flow of the Snowy River downstream of Jindabyne, and that cost must be paid by the Snowy Mountains scheme.

That cost has to be paid because otherwise you have got this blinkered view that you use the cost of keeping environmental excellence as a reason for not doing anything about the environment, but you do not use the cost of not doing anything about the environment as an argument for restoring the environment. It is a one‐way thing. I am saying be even‐handed about it. This inquiry will be a failure if it does not assess the opportunity lost in not restoring the natural flow of the Snowy River. I think the minister might have difficulty with that, but I will be putting it to the inquiry that that assessment be done.

I would like to know—if the New South Wales legal jurisdiction is the one under which the corporation will operate, and the minister has already indicated that that is so—what legal rights residents of other states, and clearly Victoria is one of those in mind, will have to take action at any time in the next 125 years. What if the good people of Orbost decide that they want to take action because of the cost to them of having a much dimin ished Snowy River flowing through their municipality? How do they take such legal action? Where is their avenue for redress of the loss that they have accrued since 1949? Even if there is not that loss to be taken into account, what of the continuing loss from the date of corporatisation and/or privatisation of the scheme?

TALKER.NAME: Senator PARER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, legislation has to be passed through all jurisdictions—New South Wales and Victoria—and I understand the Victorian legislation has in fact been introduced and that New South Wales will do so. I might say also that water flow is a matter that will be determined by both New South Wales and Victoria. As regards legal action, it is really a matter for people in those jurisdictions to work out their own ways of legally addressing matters. I do not think it is up to me to tell them how to go through the legal process in the states of Victoria and New South Wales.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —It is up to you, Minister—through you, Madam Acting Chair—because in this legislation the Commonwealth is divesting itself of powers. There is no doubt about that. It is moving towards this authority becoming a corporate entity and there is a clear intention to have it privatised. That removes residents' avenue of redress through political action. It puts a stopper on that. We have an obligation to residents to let them know what redress there is to that loss of their power to act in their interests.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very important that in the passage of legislation like this, where we are diminishing the rights of people, we recognise that diminution and we outline very clearly what alternative rights are available to them. I am asking the minister: what are the rights of the people of Orbost? For example, when this authority goes under New South Wales law, what rights will Victorian residents have under New South Wales law to take action because of the effects on the river in Victoria?

TALKER.NAME: Senator PARER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me answer your question directly: they have no power at the moment.
—Yes, they won't under you.

—You are talking about what legal power they will have—what redress and how they can go to the courts or challenge the government of the day—but they have nothing right now. We have no power either in regard to water, and I explained that to you earlier. I really cannot add to the answer that I gave you earlier. This matter—the determination of water—will be a matter between New South Wales and Victoria. The legislation on the corporatisation process involves legislation to be passed by all three jurisdictions, and that is the process we are going through.

—My good adviser Margaret has just pointed out to me that at the moment they do have a potential legal power under the EP(IP) Act through the offices of the Commonwealth. That avenue is going to be removed. I ask the minister: if they have no power, does he think that is a good thing? Does he think we ought not be ensuring that they do have power to act in their interests through the opportunity that this legislation represents?

TALKER.NAME: Senator PARER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think your adviser is wrong. The EP(IP) Act applies only to new developments, not existing developments like the Snowy.

—Be that as it may—and I always think that Margaret's advice is impeccable—the question is, Minister, that you said the people have no power. Ought not we be ensuring that people who are affected by the Snowy Mountains scheme do have legal redress for that effect?

TALKER.NAME: Senator PARER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I really cannot add to my answer. I think we are just prolonging the debate. I have got nothing to add.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is a little unfair to suggest that the governments in these areas are not doing anything for the environment. I was interested in the exchange between Senator Cook and Senator Parer on the question that, if this scheme were not in operation, what would be the effect of greenhouse gas emissions. I think it was important that that matter be brought before the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very well aware of the work that was done in the Snowy hydro scheme and, indeed, the hydro scheme in my own state. It is opportune also to acknowledge the wonderful contribution that the people from Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia and other eastern European countries made to the Snowy Mountains Hydro‐Electric Scheme. Indeed, just two days ago in this parliament we celebrated the 50th anniversary of the arrival of the first ship in Australia with migrants from the Baltic states. That was a celebration at which there were, I think, seven persons who were on that original ship in 1947.

In regard to Senator Lees's amendment, I understand what the legislation is really saying—it is acknowledging that the Commonwealth in any event will not have a majority shareholding. At the present moment the initial issue of equity will be: the Commonwealth, 13 per cent; New South Wales, 58 per cent; and Victoria, 29 per cent. It will be managed through New South Wales, and the New South Wales legislation, including the environmental legislation, will have to apply. It is in a situation different from a wholly owned Commonwealth government corporation. Were it a wholly owned Commonwealth government operation, the amendment that has been moved by Senator Lees would be very much worth supporting.

The problem that we have at the present moment is that the Commonwealth does not have a final say on the matter. The minister has indicated—and I would like him to confirm this—that, in the event of the legislation going through, there may be offers by the New South Wales government or maybe the Victorian government to take the shares of the Commonwealth. Upon what grounds does the minister make that comment? Could he elaborate a little more to the committee on the government's view on that and also on the possibility of a bid being made by a private company for the shares held by the Victorian government? I do not know how the New South Wales government is operating or how it would go, but let me put a scenario to you. If the Commonwealth held 13 per cent of the shares and if New South Wales and Victoria sold theirs, where would we be? Would the Commonwealth have any control over the direction of that particular company?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALKER.NAME: Senator PARER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —As regards the possible sale, as it sits at the moment there have been overtures made—and that is probably the best way I can describe it—by Victoria, which has shown an interest in acquiring the Commonwealth share. Of course, we would have to negotiate what that would be. None of that would occur until the corporatisation process has taken place, and that will not take place until after the water flow inquiry and after those two governments have made a decision because that could affect the value. I do not know to what extent that would be; I have no idea.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to the possibility of privatisation by either New South Wales or Victoria selling their shares, Victoria has already gone down that track, as you would appreciate, and New South Wales has been attempting to go down that track. Where that will end up is in the lap of the gods. I am looking over to the other side of the chamber for some help from the various factions of the Labor Party. I am not sure I am getting nods or winks or whatever, but I would assume that the Treasurer and Premier of New South Wales will continue to pursue this with considerable vigour.

It is worth looking at—I will not go through it in detail—an article which appeared in the Australian Financial Review on 17 October relating to an interview given by the New South Wales Auditor-General. He said:
"If they—
their power stations—
are not sold, the NSW community—in terms of economics, accounting, resources—may well face a very significant diminution in its welfare."

Because of the high capital costs required for privatisation and deregulation—Senator Harradine, I am not sure whether you were here at the time—of the electricity markets, the main beneficiary in Australia has been the consumer. Prices have come down in some instances by as much as 30 per cent. We can debate how long that will go on, depending on demand and supply.

If that scenario were to occur and the Commonwealth had a 13 per cent share, we might miss out on the opportunity to maximise the benefit to the Australian taxpayer; as well the only powers available to us would be those of a minority shareholder.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to observe for the information of the committee that hydro‐electric schemes and dams in general produce greenhouse gases.
—Very minor.
—It depends on where they are. They do so throughout the life of their existence.

SPEECH.PARA: The question I wanted to ask the minister is: has there been any approach or any discussion by the Commonwealth or, to its knowledge, by the New South Wales and Victorian governments, about privatisation, and if so, by whom?

TALKER.NAME: Senator PARER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —All I can tell you is that New South Wales is going down the road of attempting to privatise. They are having their own internal battles about that. Victoria has gone down that route. To my knowledge, we have not been approached in any way. The only information I have is what I gave Senator Harradine: there have been overtures made by Victoria to take the Commonwealth's 13 per cent share of the Snowy.
—Is the government in favour of privatising the Snowy Mountains scheme?

—For the reasons I gave when I talked about Senator Lees's amendment, as a general principle I support the privatisation. With the deregulation of the market that has been going on for quite some time and the subsequent fall that has occurred in the price of electricity, not the cost, there are now very substantial risks involved in a government being involved in the game of producing electricity. There are better things we can do with money than maybe go down that track. That is just a general principle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Why would it not be attractive to the government for Senator Lees's motion to be adopted, given the fact that there is going to be an inquiry and we will not know until after the inquiry, as the minister indicated, what price might be expected? If after that situation occurs and after the inquiry has taken place, you are in a better position to know, why not let us deal with the matter at that particular stage?

SPEECH.PARA: Before I sit down, I wish to say that there were migrants from quite a number of other countries who were working on the Snowy Mountains hydro scheme, including a lot of Italians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALKER.NAME: Senator PARER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —You are quite right. I think about every nation on earth worked on the Snowy Mountains scheme. Basically, we are putting through corporatisation legislation to give us the flexibility to take it right through to the corporatisation stage. As you quite correctly said, it will not be proclaimed until after the water inquiry and until after the two states have reviewed it. When that occurs, we will have the proclamation. It gives us the flexibility to continue discussions, for example, with Victoria. I do not know whether New South Wales is interested; they may be. But it does give us that flexibility.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment does not give us this flexibility. I think you quite correctly said that this would be a different kettle of fish if the Commonwealth owned the whole of the Snowy; it owns 13 per cent. We just need that certainty to be able to continue discussions, maybe discussions which are to the benefit of the Commonwealth—they would be; otherwise we would not pursue them—and, of course, subsequently, the taxpayers, to enable us to have that flexibility. I think that is the best response I can give you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Just on that point, Senator Harradine has raised a good point at this stage. If we have a situation where New South Wales and Victoria have decided to privatise and we are still sitting there with our 13 per cent, surely that is a good bargaining chip to ensure that everything is sorted out. If we had legislation before us now in which the water allocations were clear and we knew exactly what was happening, the whole issue of corporatisation would have been dealt with differently as far as the Democrats are concerned; we would have treated that as a primary issue.

SPEECH.PARA: But if we let our shares go we have absolutely no bargaining chip in the future to make sure that all parties are considered, whether they are irrigators or small communities along the river with tourism interests in the river or whether they involve operators at the other end of the river in South Australia. We rely, as you know, incredibly heavily on that for water for Adelaide. If the Commonwealth gets rid of that 13 per cent before everything is sorted out, it loses its last bargaining chip.

TALKER.NAME: Senator PARER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have a differing point of view on this—we could debate this ad nauseam, I suppose—and it could well be that we had no bargaining power whatsoever. Even if you made all sorts of arrangements, you end up with a 13 per cent minority shareholding. We are both talking hypothetically. That is the problem. I think we should be able to take advantage of an opportunity if and when it arises.

—I must say that this is a difficult matter for me. I would generally oppose what is being suggested by the government in this particular regard until we know what we are up for. Minister, you did say that you do not know what you are up for until after the inquiry. I am inclined to vote for the amendment that has been moved by Senator Lees. It does worry me, frankly, that Victoria may be the one that you are doing a deal with. You would have to have a long spoon, I think. But at this stage I am inclined to vote for the amendment put forward by Senator Lees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALKER.NAME: Senator PARER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I just remind Senator Harradine that this bill does not become enacted until after the inquiry and after the review. So it really is not corporatised and, until it is corporatised, we are not in a position to dispose of anything. The corporatisation does not occur for at least eight months.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: HARRADINE

TALK.START.PARA: —That is really my point.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the amendments (Senator Lees's ) be agreed to.
