SPEECH.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Now that we have dealt with the amendments to the Snowy Hydro Corporatisation Bill 1997 , I wish to comment on an issue raised by Senator Cook and responded to by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer)—that is, the greenhouse issue.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a shame—indeed, it is more than a shame; it shows how disinterested both the previous government and this government have been in the issue of greenhouse gas reductions—that this is still the only major facility in mainland Australia, apart from the hydro systems in Tasmania, that is actually able to produce energy with very few gas emissions.

I believe the initiatives of the previous government could have made sure that some of the plans that were on the drawing board—for example, the wind generating facility in Gippsland in southern Victoria—could have gone ahead. One would have hoped that by now the federal government would have worked with state governments to ensure that the available technology in solar generation is put to use somewhere in this country.

The comments from the minister regarding the reduced greenhouse emissions from this facility are very welcome, but it is an indictment of this government and the previous government that this is basically all we have. We do not have the solar and wind facilities that other countries have. I point out that the energy output of the wind generating facilities in California equate to all of Victoria's energy output. Hopefully, the wind‐powered system planned for the Woakwine Range in South Australia will be able to go ahead so that at last it will not be just the Snowy scheme that is producing renewable energy; we will actually have some others.

BREAK.PARA: CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 5) 1997
This Bill is the first of two Bills whose purpose is to introduce a new method of calculating the safety net surcharge component of the customs and excise duty on certain tobacco products.

On 5 August 1997, the High Court held that the New South Wales tobacco business franchise fees were invalid. This decision also cast considerable doubt upon the constitutional validity of other State and Territory business franchise fees on tobacco, alcohol and some petroleum products. In order to protect State and Territory revenues following this decision, the Commonwealth agreed to a safety net, part of which involved increases in customs and excise duties on certain tobacco products of $167 per kilogram.

At the time these increases were implemented, the Commonwealth Government was aware of the effect that changing from a value‐based franchise fee system to a weight based system would have on the tobacco industry. Following the High Court decision, the States and Territories held discussions with the industry and have agreed to a revised level of taxation and new arrangements for the levying of the surcharge. These arrangements will shift from a solely weighted based surcharge to one based on both weight and value. They will ensure that the effect of the safety net on the manufacturers of the different tobacco products is as close as possible to effect of the business franchise fees which applied prior to the High Court decision. All of the States and Territories have requested the Commonwealth to implement these new arrangements.

This Bill will introduce the new arrangements in relation to customs duty on tobacco products. Identical changes to the method of calculating excise duty on tobacco products are proposed in the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1997.

All of the revenues collected under this Amendment Act and the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1997 will continue to be returned to the States and Territories under the provisions of the States Grants (General Purposes) Act 1994 . The States and Territories have also asked the Commonwealth the adjust the shares for tobacco products being returned to the States and Territories under that Act and these amendments are being made by the State Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997.
EXCISE TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 5) 1997

This Bill is the second of two Bills whose purpose is to introduce a new method of calculating the safety net surcharge component of the customs and excise duty on certain tobacco products for the reasons sets out in my Second Reading Speech on the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1997. This Bill will introduce the new arrangements in relation to excise duty on tobacco products.
STATES GRANTS (GENERAL PURPOSES) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1997
The bill gives effect to a request by the states and territories to alter their shares of revenue replacement payments for tobacco under the safety net arrangements.
These arrangements were introduced at the states' request to protect their finances following the High Court decision of 5 August 1997 affecting state business franchise fees.

Under the safety net, the Commonwealth uses its taxation power to collect, on the states' behalf, revenue that they previously collected by way of business franchise fees on petroleum products, tobacco and alcoholic beverages. The revenues so collected are returned to the states (after the deduction of Commonwealth administrative costs) as revenue replacement payments under the States Grants (General Purposes) Act 1994. The distribution of revenue replacement payments among the states and territories is in accordance with shares agreed among them and set out in a Schedule to the act.

The states and territories have asked the Commonwealth to adjust the shares for tobacco related payments at the earliest opportunity as part of new arrangements for the taxation of tobacco under the safety net involving a lower revenue target and a shift from a weight based surcharge to one based on both weight and value. Separate bills have been introduced dealing with the revenue side of these new arrangements.

The bill also seeks authority for any future changes in the distribution of tobacco, petroleum or alcohol revenues to be prescribed by regulation. This will provide flexibility should the review of the safety net arrangements, to be conducted within six months, give rise to further requests by the states to alter the existing shares. Any such change would be implemented only at the states' request.

Early passage of the bill will enable the Commonwealth to return tobacco collections to the states and territories on the basis of the new shares with minimum delay, assisting them to fund rebates for petroleum and alcohol—consistent with the objective of avoiding as far as possible price increases for these products.
Madam President, I commend the bill to the Senate.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of these bills be adjourned until the first sitting day in 1998, in accordance with standing order 111.
Ordered that the States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 be listed on the Notice Paper as a separate order of the day.

TITLE.XREF: STUDENT AND YOUTH ASSISTANCE (SEX DISCRIMINATION AMENDMENT) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 29 October, on motion by Senator Ian Campbell:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to discuss the Student and Youth Assistance (Sex Discrimination Amendment) Bill . Yesterday I put on record the Democrats' opposition to this particular bill, which seeks a permanent exemption for Abstudy and Austudy from the Sex Discrimination Act 1984. We do not believe that a permanent exemption is warranted or necessary. To that end, we have suggested that an exemption that lasts until 1 January 1999 would be more appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from explaining the reasons why we do not support the permanent exemption as requested by the government, I also put on record yesterday and do so again the concern that the Democrats and others had at the fact that we received fairly late in the piece the report into this matter that was requested in November 1996 by HREOC. It was a report on in principle marital discrimination under Austudy and Abstudy; a report that I would have thought was crucial to this debate; a report that is necessary as part of the decision making process on this bill. For that reason, I reiterate that it should have been tabled and made available in the other place before they made their decision to pass this particular bill. However, I thank the officers who made it available to us yesterday.

I mentioned yesterday the history of the exemption process and noted that I did not believe the former ALP government had dealt satisfactorily with this particular matter. When I was interrupted yesterday, I was talking about the various provisions that will exist under the common youth allowance which are designed to avoid rorting or abuse of the system, such as appropriate data matching and fraud checks. Those measures are already in place, so I argue that it is highly unlikely that these particular checks could not be readily applied to student assistance schemes.

Austudy already assesses a de facto relationship. If an independent recipient enters a de facto relationship, the income and the assets of his or her partner are assessed. According to page 51 of the 1996 Austudy guide:
. . . there are heavy penalties if you deliberately try to deceive Austudy.
There are already penalties in place if you should try to deceive the department or the system, so I do not believe there would be an extra administrative burden for the department.
Austudy has existing mechanisms for dealing with students who are independent and who are in de facto relationships. According to page 53 of the 1997 Austudy guide:

. . . the details you provide may be matched with other data held on DEETYA information systems, as well as other Government departments and agencies, education institutions, employers and financial institutions. These include the Department of Social Security . . . the Australian Taxation Office, the Department of Veterans' Affairs, the Australian Electoral Commission and the Department of Health and Family Services.

Furthermore, as part of the common youth allowance proposals, the government announced that it would reduce the workplace requirements of Austudy independence to a total of 18 months over the previous two years. If a student can register as a job seeker and receive recognition of this as establishing their independence, why would a student bother to pursue some kind of sham de facto marriage?

Given all of these factors, the Democrats cannot understand why the government insists that the inclusion of de facto status will, as I believe Mr Tony Abbott stated, encourage young people to `shack up'.
Senator Kemp interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Rod Kemp exclaims his distaste at this particular comment by the parliamentary secretary. It is not simply a matter of `shacking up'. You cannot `shack up', then fill in an Austudy form and then suddenly, miraculously and instantaneously be able to receive Austudy. There is a two-year period of living together in a partnership before you are able to get those entitlements—a partnership which can easily be disproved or proven by a check of the couple's financial, electoral and other arrangements. I listed those organisations through which data matching can take place. All of these are accessible and they are already accessed by the department. If we do not remove this discrimination, we may encourage young people not to shack up but encourage those in full-time study, or living independently or in a de facto relationship to drop out of full-time study. That is my worry. The belief that this measure will relieve the mischief of fraudulent and short-term relationships is false.

SPEECH.PARA: The statement made by the parliamentary secretary in the other place suggests that de jure married couples are less likely to have short-term or bogus relationships. It is precisely these assumptions that prohibition of discrimination on the grounds of marital status is aimed at stopping. So the Australian Democrats are strong supporters of the Sex Discrimination Act. We maintain that exemp tions to the SDA should be limited and that, where possible, all federal legislation should be consistent with the objectives of the SDA.

The problem we have is that this issue, in relation to marital status and de facto status when it comes to student financial assistance, has been in both the former government and the current government's too-hard baskets for too long. It is now time to do something about this problem. The Labor government's attempts to ameliorate this situation by denying married students independence would leave it in a bit of an embarrassing situation today. But I trust that this time it will take the proper course of action and move to eradicate the discrimination.

We will not be supporting attempts to allow an exemption for three years, as has been suggested by the Labor Party. As I say, we have put up an amendment that suggests that 1 January 1999 is appropriate. It forces the government to do something about this issue and it takes into account the operations of the reforms under the common youth allowance arrangements. I understand that they are purported to start from July next year, but we are allowing an additional six months in the amendment in case of any difficulties with the time and the starting arrangements of that legislation.

I look forward to clarification from the minister as to what happens to the issue of de facto couples, independents and married couples under the CYA arrangements. My understanding is that this will partly resolve the situation that we have before us today. As I said yesterday, if that is the case, we commend the government. I certainly hope it is the case. I look forward to further enlightenment from the minister on this issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The Student and Youth Assistance (Sex Discrimination Amendment) Bill 1997 will create a permanent exemption for Austudy and Abstudy schemes from the marital status provisions of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984. Student assistance schemes have been through a series of administrative and legislative Sex Discrimination Act exemptions since 1984. Most of them have been inadequate, including the last, considered by this chamber in 1995, when the ALP government attempted to exclude married couples under 22 years of age from the independent rate of Austudy. Obviously that would have been a ridiculous situation. The Greens will remain in favour, as we did in 1995, of Austudy being exempt from the provisions of the Sex Discrimination Act in order for married couples to receive the independent rate of Austudy.

SPEECH.PARA: While governments insist that young adults should remain dependent on their parents for education long after the age at which they can vote, drink, marry or—God forbid—fight in a war, there is little other choice. However, we do not believe that granting a permanent exemption for all marital status provisions of the Sex Discrimination Act is either necessary or an adequate way to deal with the complex marital issues associated with student assistance. In particular, the issue of de facto relationships remains one which governments fail to address and is simply glossed over with the introduction of this bill.

In the government's belated and cursory report on this issue—a report which we received less than 24 hours ago, and may not have received at all without the pressure put on by the minor parties and I assume Labor on this issue—the government claims there would be `significant cost implications' if the de facto relationships were recognised in line with the Sex Discrimination Act. But where are the figures? Where is the evidence that this would be the case? If people are going to go to the considerable effort of concocting a marriage type relationship, what does this tell you about the willingness of their parents to support them? None of these issues is addressed in the government's report, and they never will be addressed if this bill is passed.

When is a de facto relationship not a de facto relationship? This is a question that successive governments seem to have considerable difficulty answering, at least in any consistent manner. According to the Sex Discrimination Act, you are in a de facto relationship as soon as you live with someone as the husband or wife of that person on a bona fide domestic basis, although not legally married to that person. If you are in receipt of unemployment or pension benefits, you are in a de facto relationship as soon as you are in a marriage like relationship with someone of the opposite sex. If you receive Abstudy, you are deemed to be in a de facto relationship when you have lived with someone of the opposite sex for six months.

Under the provisions of the common youth allowance, you will be in a de facto relationship if you have been living with someone of the opposite sex for two years continuously in a marriage like relationship. If you are in receipt of Austudy, you will never be in a de facto relationship, because the Commonwealth government considers that you and your partner are too difficult to deal with.

A report was specifically requested by the Sex Discrimination Commissioner as a prerequisite for granting the administrative exemption for 1997. The government has hastily thrown together 10 pages of excuses for doing nothing.

The terms of the exemption granted by the Sex Discrimination Commissioner suggest that this exemption was granted by the commission with the bona fide intention of achieving an equitable and non-discriminatory solution to the problem of Austudy or Abstudy discrimination. The government agreed to this intention, but I would contend that it has failed miserably.

This bill is being enacted not out of any clear policy position but, rather, as an easy out to cover the government's inaction on this issue. It is not as though this is a new issue or that government members have not stated their position on the matter, as can be seen from the following extract of Hansard of 9 February 1995. On page 826, Senator Tierney, then an opposition senator, berated the Labor government for not coming up with a method to address the discrimination against de facto couples in relation to Austudy. He said:

This government was lazy and arrogant in not tackling this problem of definition. It could have decided on a fair and workable definition for genuine student de facto relationships. This would have removed the need to discriminate against any group.
And later:

BREAK.PARA: There is all this hurt and uncertainty for young married students because the Labor government could not find, with the help of its vast bureaucracy, a simple definition for de facto relationships.

One year on, it appears that the Liberal government has been just as neglectful. It has had nearly a year to address this issue—and here we are, in the second-last sitting week, having sighted the promised report less than 24 hours ago, and the best the government can come up with is a blanket exemption from the Sex Discrimination Act marital status provisions.

The relevant formal documents tabled with this bill state that it is government policy that `exemptions to the Sex Discrimination Act should be limited' and that, `where possible, all federal legislation should be consistent with the Sex Discrimination Act's objectives'. This is an important policy statement from the government. Unfortunately, the bill does not reflect this position and, for the most part, the bill merely reflects the status quo. It takes absolutely no steps to reduce discriminatory assumptions within the specified legislation.

The government's position on the de facto issue is quite difficult to fathom. On the one hand, it claimed during the second reading debate that it was too administratively complex to equate de facto couples with married couples due to issues of proof; and, as has been mentioned, we had Tony Abbott, the member for Warringah, claiming that it was improper for the government to be encouraging young people to `shack up'. But, on the other hand, it intends to enact a common youth allowance which will recognise de facto relationships. So, obviously, it is not all that difficult.

The government also seems to have forgotten that, from 1976 to 1982, during the term of a Liberal government, a de facto relationship provision existed under the Student Assistance Act. Gosh, it must not have been difficult then. The government certainly does not have a problem with it in terms of Abstudy either, where students are granted independence after establishing the existence of a de facto relationship, in this case, for six months.

We would like figures and research on the claimed cost implications and administrative difficulties of recognising de facto relationships, not the anecdotal guesswork that has accompanied this debate and which dominates the government's so-called report. For example, it might be appropriate to trial granting de facto relationships the same independent status as marriages. Surely, in an era where up to 25 per cent of long-term relationships are out of wedlock, this is an issue that deserves serious attention—not just `we reckon it'll cost too much'.

The government report cites the second key area of the necessity for discrimination—the first being de facto relationships—as the need for a spouse means test. Yet nowhere in the report is it mentioned that forcing a person, especially a woman, to be completely financially dependent on their partner can be detrimental to that person's self-esteem, freedom of choice and access to education. It is well documented that mature age women students, in returning to education, often face resistance from their partners. Surely these are major issues that one would hope a report of this nature would canvass. Nothing whatsoever. All it talks about is the need to make cost savings in the context of targeting payments.

The report highlights a `more minor' area of discrimination in which single students over the age of 21 who have been long-term unemployed are eligible for a higher rate of Austudy, but similar students with a spouse are not. In this case, the government has not explained its rationale for this arrangement at all, let alone canvassed any social justice or equity arguments. This report, to say the least, is inadequate. The government's lack of action in this area is reprehensible, and it needs to go and do it again; try it over again, and go back to the drawing board.

The government will also claim that the Sex Discrimination Commissioner will no longer grant administrative exemptions and, therefore, this legislation must be passed by the end of this year in order to prevent an administrative mess occurring with regard to Austudy claims. This may or may not be the case; we do not know. Certainly, the commis sioner would be justified in being tired of this government's inaction on this issue.

However, if the government is serious about addressing this issue, and if it has got itself into a mess via its incompetence or misfortune, or whatever other excuse it may come up with, it would seem that surely at the very least the government should only legislate for an exemption with a sunset clause that expires before the introduction of the common youth allowance due to be implemented in July 1998 but which, in the interests of fairness, should probably be introduced at the start of 1999. This would enable the exemption to be viewed in relation to what could be a substantially amended common youth allowance with various possible implications for sex discrimination issues; also, it would enable the government to consult with the community in a meaningful manner to address this issue once and for all.
Both Liberal and Labor governments have placed this issue in the too‐hard basket for far too long. We will not support a bill that enables the government to avoid this issue indefinitely.

The ALP have proposed an amendment to place a three-year sunset clause on the bill. Apparently, this has been moved to allow a more rigorous review on the issue. I would suggest that allowing three years to conduct a review will achieve nothing but inaction for about two years and nine months, and then perhaps another report like we have today. Surely, we should be insisting that this issue deserves to be addressed with certainty and equity, as quickly as possible. It is not as if people have not had enough time to think about it.

The Sex Discrimination Commissioner does not want to deal with the issue any more. Why should we allow up to three years for this issue to drag on? The Greens will be moving amendments in relation to recognition of same sex couples and the de facto relationships in the committee stage.

There are effectively two Greens (WA) associated amendments, one of which would say that, while marital status can be considered so that married people are granted the independent rate, `married' must include both de jure and de facto marriage. This would mean that the independent status would be extended to de facto couples and would recognise that de facto marriage is increasingly common, particularly among young people such as students.

In tax law, social security, the treatment of matters concerning children, family law and nearly every form of law in Australia, other than the Marriage Act, de facto relationships are seen as virtually indistinguishable from de jure marriage. I see no reason to try to create economic incentives to try to push young, usually childless, couples into marriage. The other amendment, in line with work I have done previously, would eliminate the discrimination between same sex and opposite sex de facto couples.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, I thank senators for their contributions. In relation to the arguments put by Senator Carr, which were largely on other issues, I acknowledge the fact that he admitted that it was a difficult issue and that in fact the previous government had wrestled with this problem. In fact, the previous government sought an exemption from the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commissioner and in 1995 had sought to remove marriage as a ground for independence, which was really quite outrageous and was opposed by the then opposition and by the Democrats.

SPEECH.PARA: This government is seeking to sort the matter out once and for all and not to keep coming back seeking temporary exemptions. By placing this in the legislation, there is nothing new. We have a precedent for it in the social security legislation, whereby exemptions from the Sex Discrimination Act have been enacted.

In relation to Senator Stott Despoja's inquiry as to the youth allowance and how that will work, that was covered in the report given to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commissioner by the government. Might I say that the previous minister gave an undertaking to give that report by the end of the year and the government is meeting that commitment two months ahead of time.

Suffice to say that, in relation to the youth allowance, it will recognise de facto relationships of at least two years duration as a ground for independence. That is stated in paragraph 24 of the government's report.

In relation to the timing of the report, I believe that it is not such a complex report that the opposition and minor parties could not get across it in time for this debate. I believe that the opposition and minor parties have had adequate time to have a look at that report and the government has set out its position quite clearly.

The question really is whether we should keep coming back seeking temporary exemptions or deal with the matter now once and for all and place it in the legislation. The government opts for the latter course as one being a more certain course and one which solves the problem.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek the agreement of the committee to reorganise the order of the placing of amendments. I would like a departure from the circulated running sheet.
—What circulated running sheet?

—I understand some senators do not have that running sheet and I have only just seen it myself. I seek the agreement of the committee that the opposition amendment to schedule 1, item 1, be taken first.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —If we are still talking about the order, then I oppose that. I was getting a copy of this running sheet, which I have only just seen myself. I believe that the order as set out in the running sheet is appropriate and the government does not support the proposal to change the order.
—I have not seen the running sheet, but the Democrats are happy to support that proposal.
—Senator Carr, you are the only one standing to be called.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —I understood that the Democrats were supporting my motion that the amendment to schedule 1, item 1, standing in my name be taken first within the committee.
—I am receiving amendments. Are you going to move opposition amendment No. 1? Do you wish to speak to it?

—I do not think that much needs to be said. This argument is essentially about the length of time in which an exemption is granted. I think it would be logical and consistent to get an accurate reflection of the Senate's opinion, if there were a rational presentation of the various options presented. Quite clearly—and the government is only too well aware of this—if the Democrat amendment is put before ours, we are obliged to vote against the Democrat amendment, and I suspect that would sink that amendment. That is a tactical device which you are entitled to pursue.

—Senator Carr, the amendments that will be moved have been circulated. The one that is moved first will be from the senator or party who stands and moves that amendment first. I take it that you are standing to move opposition amendment No. 1 on sheet 649, and that is what I am expecting you to be speaking to.

—Madam Chair, I am more than happy for you to offer me advice in that manner. All I can say to you is that, when I see a running sheet presented to me moments before a debate comes on, I would make the normal presumption that that is the order in which the Senate is going to be dealing with them.

SPEECH.PARA: I therefore move:
(1) Schedule 1, item 1, page 3 (line 6), omit "Nothing", substitute "For the period of 3 years beginning on the commencement of this subsection, nothing".

I note that this government has a difficult problem to resolve. However, we believe that the government's approach to student assistance is appalling. What we have is a government whose administration of student assistance is abominable. The minister would, I am sure, agree with me on that prospect.

Clearly what we have is a government which is unable to find a resolution to this difficult problem. However, we think the government is entitled to be given a further period of three years—not an indefinite period but a quite specific, reasonable length of time—to deal with this matter in a proper fashion. What we want the government to do is to stop treating this matter with the contempt it has shown to date.

We want the government to keep in mind that this issue, as we all appreciate, is far from simple. We are prepared to allow proper discussion to take place on the matter. That is why we suggest three years as being a reasonable time to come up with some sort of constructive solution, so that students are not treated differently from the rest of the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I stated my position in my speech in the second reading debate, but, just to make it quite clear, we believe three years is too long. There has been a long time to sort this out. I believe 1 January 1999 clearly puts the government on notice to sort this out, to make sure that there is clarity and consistency and to make sure that we do not continually have this problem. Quite clearly the progressive side of politics is indicating that permanent exemptions do not solve the problem. So I think 1 January 1999 is a reasonable time, and three years is letting the government off the hook.

—The Australian Democrats have also stated their position quite clearly. For the reasons stated in my speech in the second reading debate, we will not be supporting the opposition amendment which allows an additional three‐year period—or seeks a three‐year exemption. We would suggest that it is not only this current government that has treated student assistance abominably; the former government had a role to play.
—Oh!

—I am sorry, Senator McKiernan, because you were not a cheering squad for the rest of us. The former government had a role to play not only in reducing or narrowing what we considered to be the eligibility criteria but also in reducing the amounts that students were entitled to. Having said that, I think there have been particularly regressive moves by this government in relation to the time and age at which people can access student assistance and to the amounts they can access—be it Abstudy or Austudy. Therefore, I concur with Senator Margetts's comments. I think 1 January 1999 is reasonable. I urge other members to support that amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government has already outlined its position. This is a situation which the previous government could not solve. Having temporary exemptions will not solve the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: There are distinctions drawn in this legislation between married couples and de facto couples. The government thinks it is appropriate that the exemption from the Sex Discrimination Act be enacted in this legislation. There is a precedent for it in the social security legislation. There is nothing untoward. The government has provided a report to the Human Rights Commissioner. It believes that this is the only way to solve the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask the minister, as a consequence of his comments earlier in relation to the tabling of the report, why this legislation was passed in the House of Representatives without the report being made available either to HREOC or to members of that place?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer is that it was not available at that time. It was only available the night before last, as I understand it.
—Why was the legislation brought in?

—The legislation was brought in at that stage because there is a need to get this legislation through by the end of the year. If we do not have it passed by the end of the year, we will run into problems—there could well be action taken against the government.

—Given the minister's statement in regard to what he says are precedents in the exemptions in the social security acts versus the exemptions in regard to the student support acts, are there different exemptions, Minister? Is it the case that Austudy allowance discriminates between de jure and de facto marriages, and is it the case that, in regard to social security, the discrimination is between single people and members of couples—that is, de jure or de facto—which are quite separate issues?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was using the social security example as an example of principle and not of detail. It does not correspond in detail to the exemption here.

SPEECH.PARA: As I understand it, the exemption from the Sex Discrimination Act is legislated for in the social security legislation. I was pointing to that as an example where you can have the exemption enacted in legislation. That was the analogy I was drawing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it the case that the removal of the social security exemption would mean paying all members of couples more—to the tune of $115.40 a fortnight—to bring them up to the single rate and, therefore, it would be of significant cost to the government? Secondly, Social Security does not now discriminate between de facto and de jure marriages, but the youth allowance proposal will introduce this anomaly into the social security system—is that the position?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —The provisions of the social security legislation are not relevant here. The question that you ask is really for another debate. We are talking about student and youth assistance legislation here. The only thing I pointed to social security for was as an example of legislating for an exemption—nothing more, nothing less. The detail of it is irrelevant.

—That is the problem; you have raised the issue in the context of a precedent being set. I put it to you, in response, that these are not the same set of circumstances. Quite clearly, the detail is relevant and, in fact, quite significant. It is fundamental to the whole issue, again underlying the complexity of the issue. That is why I suggest, in support of our proposal, that the three‐year period would be appropriate.

—Following on from the comments that Senator Stott Despoja made earlier, the government has a choice about when it puts this legislation forward. Our concern, when we contacted representatives of the government, was that they did have a choice about when the legislation went forward. Of course, they did have the ability to make sure that this report was ready for whenever the legislation came forward. It would make no sense at all to deal with this legislation without that report being available. That is what we are saying; it was not a matter of the bill being urgent, rather the bill could not really have even been considered meaningfully without the report. So what the minister was saying was nonsense in relation to the timing. He said, `Aren't they great, they have produced it before the end of the year?' It would have been useless to have produced it before the end of the year if we had had to deal with the bill without the report.

—I would like to put another question to the minister. I note that the sex discrimination commissioner, when commenting on granting the exemption that was allowed last year, suggested not only that the report that we have discussed was appropriate but that that report should take into account the outcomes of a report being undertaken by the Minister for Social Security, Jocelyn Newman. That was the review of the notions of dependency. I am wondering whether this report did take into account those recommendations and, if so, is there consistency as a consequence and, if not, why not?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is yes.

—Thank you for that answer. In relation to the comments made in the lower house by the parliamentary secretary, I wondered if there was evidence to substantiate Mr Abbott's assertion that students would run out and establish de facto relationships to establish independent status. Is there any evidence? Do you know of any information on which he based that assumption and that assertion? Is it possible for you to tell me how many students who currently receive the independent rate have indicated on their application forms that they are in a de facto relationship?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —The provision was not in existence so there is no evidence to draw on as such. The parliamentary secretary was making an observation, which he was entitled to draw. As for any forensic evidence being available, there was none.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 2 (after line 5), after clause 3, insert:

PARA.TAB: This Act ceases to be in force on 1 January 1999, unless sooner repealed.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment suggests that an exemption essentially be granted until 1 January 1999. I have stated why. I think that is a reasonable amount of time in which to resolve this situation. If the government does not believe this is a reasonable amendment I would be quite curious as to why, because it certainly allows enough time for the introduction of the proposed common youth allowance legislation. It even allows not only for the introduction or proposed introduction of the CYA but, if anything should go wrong, an additional six months to be given. I will not reiterate my other comments because they are in my speech on the second reading.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate to the committee that the opposition will support the Democrats' amendment.
—The Greens (WA) will be supporting this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will be opposing the amendment. The reasons have been outlined previously.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment not agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 1, page 3 (after line 3), before item 1, insert:
1A Subsection 4(1) (definition of de facto spouse )
Repeal the definition, substitute:

PARA.TAB: de facto spouse , in relation to a person, means a person who lives with the first‐mentioned person, regardless of whether the people are of the same or opposite sex, in a marriage‐like relationship and on a bona fide domestic basis, although not legally married to that person.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment is another relatively simple amendment which would give recognition to the existence of same‐sex couples. The current definition of de facto spouse states:

de facto spouse, in relation to a person, means a person of the opposite sex of the first‐mentioned person who lives with the first‐mentioned person as the husband or wife of that person on a bona fide domestic basis, although not legally married to that person.

My amendment changes the definition of `de facto spouse' so that the term `as a husband or wife' is replaced with `in a marriage‐like relationship'. I had to do that because the courts insist that the use of the phrase `as the husband or wife of that person' when they are not legally married implies that this can only refer to members of the opposite sex. In other words, same‐sex couples are excluded yet again from any recognition which is happily given to de facto couples of the opposite sex. In case this is not enough, I have included `regardless of whether people are of the same or opposite sex'. Those are the only changes I have made to the current definition.

This is not because same‐sex couples do not exist. I think even Fred Nile would admit that they do. It is not that same‐sex couples do not have deep and abiding commitments to one another. After all, there is no requirement that opposite sex couples in de facto relationships have any commitments to one another other than those involved in the definition of a bona fide domestic relationship. Yet even if a same‐sex couple make vows to one another, legally and financially merge their affairs, and clearly have far more commitment than the average de facto couple, they cannot have their relationship recognised legally. This is simple discrimination.

I will speak for a moment on Senator Harradine's concern about preserving the institution or sanctity of marriage. In the first place, this is not what law does. What law does through the Marriage Act is to outlaw the recognition of same‐sex marriage. It means that, even where there are churches such as the Metropolitan Church or the Quakers who will marry same‐sex partners in love and for life before God and the community, that sanctified union is legally forbidden the grant of legal recognition as marriage. The Uniting Church has said that ministers can conduct ceremonies that acknowledge same‐sex relationships but they are not marriages. Anglican Bishop Baker has openly called for recognition and marriage of same‐sex couples. There are also various non‐Christian religions that recognise and sanctify same‐sex relationships, religions such as the Unitarians, Buddhists and so on. There are, further, many same‐sex couples who make vows of union in a civil ceremony presided over by civil celebrants.

None of these can legally be classed as marriage. We are denying love, denying commitment and denying the view of marriage in some religions, and we are denying reality if we say that such commitment does not exist. The fact is that same‐sex couples do exist. Same‐sex families exist and have children. It is both foolish and socially counterproductive to deny any recognition and support of commitment within such relation ships. We deny these people the opportunity to legally marry. They may morally, socially, materially and emotionally marry, but we deny any legal recognition. We are then potentially so mean‐minded that we deny such unions, including those sanctified in churches and by religion, the same legal status we give to any two people who live together for a few months.

We deny same‐sex people who effectively married with vows and commitments even the status of de facto. We grant de facto status to any opposite sex couple that live together under tax law, in social security, in employment, in superannuation, in life insurance and in aged care—in virtually all aspects of society where law rules. We deny that to people who, were there no legal boundary explicitly preventing it, would otherwise be recognised as married. We deny it to people who have lived together for 30 or 40 years, raised children together and bought houses together. It is not preservation of family; it is denial of it. It is not recognition of love and vows; it is denial of that. Under social security laws, we will force de facto status on unwilling heterosexuals. Under the same law we will not grant legal recognition even as de factos to a same‐sex couple even if they ask for such recognition. We are denying family.

Earlier this year the Anglican Archbishop of Melbourne gave qualified recognition for committed same‐sex relationships. He argued that there were ways and degrees by which God's ideals could be expressed, even if not expressed fully in the eyes of the church. He said that the couple, be they homosexual or heterosexual, who are living together in a committed relationship are coming closer to that ideal than those without such commitments. The Australian Catholic Bishops Conference, in their submission to the sexuality bill—even the Catholic bishops—recognised the injustice, inhumanity and unchristianness of this sort of discrimination. In their submission they said:

1. The church has upheld and taught consistently that the inherent and inviolable dignity of every human being, without exception, must be the foundation for any examination of individual and community rights and responsibilities.
2. This Anglican‐Catholic Bishops Conference supports attempts by parliaments to proscribe conduct which unjustly discriminates or vilifies members of the Australian community on whatever basis.
And at point 8:

In this regard, the sexuality discrimination bill concerning same‐sex couples is notable for its attempt to confer rights, albeit limited, on same‐sex couples. To the degree that it can provide protection from unjust discrimination and that it provides protection against discrimination similar to those accorded to persons living in a de facto relationship, it is hardly objectionable.

The Catholic bishops have asked for recognition as de facto relationships of same‐sex couples. How on earth can we, the Senate, continue with the pretext that this type of discrimination is acceptable? I am not asking for the recognition of same‐sex marriage. I recognise that this is a hurdle many people would not jump. What I am asking for is what the Catholic bishops declared was the just course, that is, legal recognition of same‐sex couples as being in de facto relationships.

The consequences of denying this and continuing homophobic discrimination are to deny people's rights, such as the ability to visit a partner in hospital after an accident, because there is no legal relationship. It is to deny a person the right to name a partner of decades as the recipient of superannuation in the event of death. It is to deny people the right to leave for familial duties when a partner becomes gravely ill. It is to deny two people who have lived together for decades, who have made vows to one another and have had them religiously sanctified, the rights you would thrust on a couple of teenagers living together with no intention of continuing to live together beyond what is fun and convenient.

I have heard a number of objections to similar amendments here. Senator Faulkner has claimed that heterosexual couples are treated so badly that same‐sex couples should be glad to live with systematic discrimination in all aspects of their lives rather than be treated the same way. We have heard the argument put by the ALP that, if we stopped treating some people in our society in a clearly discriminatory way, a way which violates their rights, it may have unforeseen revenue implications. In other words, we cannot stop discrimination because the oppressed group might get something from it.

We have heard the argument that this is no good because it is a piecemeal or ad hoc approach. Yet there is no intention shown or effort being made in this place for an integrated approach. The sexuality bill put forward by former senator Sid Spindler of the Democrats is the closest thing we have to an integrated approach. The report of the committee examining that bill has been delayed and delayed and is currently scheduled for the last day of this sitting session. So, if we get to reports on that day—and I will believe it when I see it—we can rest assured that any treatment given the issue will be minimal and generally ignored.

I call the date of the report a cynical exercise. This place and the two major parties in it have no intention of working on an integrated approach to ending this discrimination. In any case, even if the Sexuality Discrimination Bill were miraculously given debate and passed, we would still have to amend the many bills, one by one, to remove discriminatory clauses such as the one I am hoping to change here. We can simply change legislation as it arises, and it is actually not that difficult. The change to this bill will hopefully affect students on Austudy and Abstudy. We allow discrimination in granting married students special rights; we deny same sex couples the right to marry.

The second amendment would grant recognition to de facto students. This amendment would, in conjunction with that, allow same sex couples—who are adult in most legal senses and who, because of their orientation, may be abandoned and rejected by parents—some option for recognition as independent. But, even if my second amendment is not passed, this amendment will have a beneficial effect because it changes the definition of `de facto' in the Sex Discrimination Act. It will allow recognition of same sex couples under that act.

One result of this is that, in areas of employment where discrimination on the basis of marital status is not allowed, this would also prohibit discrimination on the basis of a definition of `de facto' that included same sex couples. It will therefore have an effect of allowing action to be taken in relation to discrimination in employment.I call upon the Senate to put aside its excuses and prevarication and to end the discrimination and grant legal recognition of same sex unions as being at least equivalent to the de facto status. I commend my amendments to the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to support, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, the amendments put forward by Senator Margetts. I think they are both reasonable and fair.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank her for including a reference to the private member's bill introduced into this place by former senator Sid Spindler. Certainly Senator McKiernan would be more than aware of some of the submissions, both verbal and written, that were put before the Legal and Constitutional References Committee's inquiry into this matter and which outlined—just as Senator Margetts has done—the nature and persistence of discrimination in law against people who are in same sex and other relationships.

I think, as mentioned, that this issue is one of human rights. It is about dignity and fair treatment before the law and it is above revenue considerations and other excuses that may have been put forward by current members of the government or, indeed, by members of the former government. The Democrats will be supporting what we see as a reasonable and fair amendment before us today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will not be supporting the Greens (WA) amendments. While we have some sympathy with the position that Senator Margetts has outlined in regard to the philosophical argument on the issues of discrimination against same sex, as against opposite sex, couples—and I do note the length to which Senator Margetts goes to quote supporting church evidence—I have always found this a particularly interesting line of argument on these questions when bishops and various other hierarchies are quoted on questions of discrimination, and I am sure it is a sympathy that they would appreciate only too well, given that these issues have been given such public attention. The problem for us, however, as people actually genuinely concerned not only with the theoretical issues of discrimination, is the practical effect of what is being proposed.

SPEECH.PARA: I would suggest to Senator Margetts, as a person who regards herself as a socialist, that that would be a matter of great concern to her. I would have thought the issue of the impact of such a proposal on the finances of low income, same sex couples—the loss of perhaps as much as $115 a fortnight if this proposition were to be carried—would have been given some prominence in the appeal that has just been put to the Senate because I think we should understand the full implications of this proposal.

We have clearly a difference here between sympathy for a philosophical statement and our real concerns about the practical effects such a proposal would have. It is our view that this proposal, if it were actually carried by the parliament, would allow this government, which is notorious for its attacks upon people on low incomes—people who are dependent on social security and people who are dependent on student assistance—to hop into people in a way that we have never seen before.

We would see that millions of dollars would be lost by people who were actually enjoying the benefits of Austudy or other social security benefits. I ask the Greens to please advise the Senate how they can be so sure that this is a position that same sex couples would in fact support. I think it would be appropriate to get some evidence that same sex couples would be volunteering to lose income of this order when, by definition, to get this money they are low income persons.

It is a wonderful thing to have a commitment to an abstract principle but, when it comes to actually assisting people on low incomes, we have to be aware of the very practical implications of such proposals. If the Greens expect the chamber to support such a proposition, I would ask them to at least provide us with the evidence to support the conclusions that they are reaching. I presume they are arguing that this is in response to the demands that are being made by low income people on social security benefits or student assistance benefits, and that same sex couples are actually asking for this to be done so that they can in fact lose up to $115 a fortnight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —Mention was made in the contributions by Senator Margetts and Senator Stott Despoja about the reference of the Sexuality Discrimination Bill to the Legal and Constitutional References Committee. SPEECH.PARA: I am very happy to be in a position to report progress on the reference. I am grateful to have the opportunity to report some progress on that matter. It is of interest to a great number of people in the community. TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested—intrigued, actually—to hear some of Senator Carr's comments. I can understand that, so I am not suggesting that this position is a 100 per cent position from the gay and lesbian community. TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports the Telecommunications Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 . TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 2, item 24, page 37 (lines 2 to 3), omit "condition set out in one of the paragraphs of subclause (2) is", substitute "conditions set out in subclause (2) are".
(2) Schedule 2, item 24, page 37 (lines 9 to 32), omit subclause (2), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (2) For the purposes of paragraph (1)(e), the following conditions are specified:

TAB.TAB: (a) the carrier has made reasonable efforts to negotiate in good faith with:
(i) each proprietor whose approval is required, or would, apart from Division 3, be required, for carrying out the installation; and
(ii) each administrative authority whose approval is required, or would, apart from Division 3, be required, for carrying out the installation; and
(b) one of the following subparagraphs applies:
(i) at least one approval that is referred to in subparagraph (a)(i) has not been obtained within 20 business days after the beginning of the negotiations concerned;
(ii) at least one approval that is referred to in subparagraph (a)(ii) has not been obtained within 6 months after the beginning of the negotiations concerned;
(iii) at least one approval that is referred to in paragraph (a) has been refused.

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments ensure that two conditions are met before a carrier can apply to the Australian Communications Authority for a facility installation permit. Firstly, the carrier must have made reasonable efforts to negotiate in good faith with each affected landowner and with each relevant administrative authority whose consent is required. Secondly, the landowner must have denied permission or must have failed to respond within 20 business days, or the administrative authority must have denied consent or must have failed to respond within six months.

The reason we have moved this amendment is that we want to ensure that the carriers would have to negotiate in good faith with both the landowner and the administrative authority. The government's original proposal would have permitted carriers to ignore one of these parties at the initial stage. Indeed, it could have been possible for a carrier to apply for a facility installation permit without even having talked to the relevant authority. I welcome the assistance that has been given by the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) and his office regarding this matter.
Amendments agreed to.
