SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate that the opposition supports the Sydney Airport Demand Management Bill 1997 , but I wish to make a few brief comments on it. I was tempted to put forward an amendment to the title of the bill to add an `s' to the word `demand' so it would read `Sydney airport demands management'. It is quite clear that this government has failed in its management of aviation issues generally and in its management of the operations of Sydney airport and the need for a second Sydney airport in particular.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation arises out of the initiative of the Labor Party and, in particular, the member for Grayndler, Mr Albanese, whose electorate has long suffered the problems of aircraft noise. Mr Albanese put forward a private member's bill to impose a cap on Sydney airport; something that the government has talked about and something that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), when he was Leader of the Opposition, made a lot of noise about it but was only prepared to act on once prompted by the opposition.

The legislation places a cap of 80 movements per hour on the operations of Kingsford Smith airport, subject to certain exemptions which relate to emergencies and military needs. Other aspects of the legislation relate to the establishment of a framework for slot management. As I said earlier, one has to be very sceptical about this government's real ability to bring about a more adequate system of aircraft management at Sydney airport and in Sydney generally. We are happy to support the legislation, but we are awaiting the regulations to come forward in regard to the detail of that aspect.

I want to remind the Senate that this government has failed absolutely in their handling of the ever increasing important issues of airports and aircraft noise, and aviation management in this country. We had the farcical situation where, not long after they were elected last year, they proposed that Sydney's second airport could be located at Holsworthy—something that was rejected as totally unsuitable many years earlier. This proposal caused great outrage and unnecessary anxiety in the community.

We in the opposition told the government that it was a stupid proposal and that it would never succeed once the EIS process was implemented. In fact, they did not even complete the EIS report. After having wasted around $13 million of taxpayers' money on an EIS into Holsworthy, the minister was forced to announce that Holsworthy had been taken off the agenda as a site for Sydney's second airport. That decision was announced even before the EIS was completed. This government has been going backwards in relation to fixing up the long-term problems of Sydney's airport needs.

The management of air safety in this country, an issue which everyone is aware of, is basically in a shambles at the moment. The former minister, Mr Sharp, who recently resigned, attempted to interfere in the management and structure of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. The previous chairman, Justice Fisher, and the executive director have resigned, largely because of the machinations of the minister in seeking to bring about a restructuring of the board. The minister previously appointed people to the board who were clearly there to do his bidding.

I will not continue with those issues at this time, because much has been said and much will be said in the future as the issues drag on. Notwithstanding this government's failures, we welcome this legislation and we are happy to support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate that the Australian Democrats will support the concept of the Sydney Airport Demand Management Bill 1997 . We will, however, be moving an amendment to the bill in the committee stage. On behalf of Senator Bourne, I seek leave to incorporate our speech in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
As we know, the purpose of this Bill is to establish a maximum limit on the number of aircraft movements at 80 per hour, during non-curfew hours, at Sydney's Kingsford Smith Airport.

The Bill also establishes an aircraft movement management system, to be known as a Slot Management System, to administer these movements. The Slot Management System will be overseen by a Compliance System, over seen by a committee. Airservices Australia may have membership on the Management committee, and will play a vital role in the compliance of the system.

Airservices Australia will also be required to report to the Minister on a quarterly basis on the operation of the System. In turn, the Minister will be required to table this report, and its recommendations, in Parliament.

While the Australian Democrats support the Bill in concept and rationale—the notion of ordered queuing makes sense. However, we do not support the maximum number of aircraft movements. This Bill proscribes a maximum number of 80 movements per hour, which the Democrats believe is just too high.
Therefore, I have tabled an amendment to this Bill, to provide that the maximum number of aircraft movements at Sydney Airport be no more than 70 movements per hour.

It is difficult to see how a limit of 80 movements per hour—as outlined in the Coalition's pre-election policy—will help residents, when this level is higher than the current number of maximum movements per peak hour.

The Democrats have been strong advocates for both an extended curfew for Sydney Airport, and for the limitation of aircraft movements. In my own Private Senator's Bill in 1995, the number of movements at Sydney Airport were capped at 60. The opening of the East West Runway—another decision the Democrats opposed—saw the number of aircraft movements into Sydney increase. Indications are that there will be a steady increase in the level of air traffic using Sydney, especially when the decision about the second airport seems so far from being made.
If increases continue to occur at Sydney Airport, tolerating aircraft noise for many people living close to the airport and under its flightpaths, already very difficult, will become unbearable.

This increase in usage of Sydney airport has seen the Coalition Government and the Labor Opposition call for a capping of 80 movements per hour—an increase of at least five movements per hour in peak time. It is almost as if, in drafting the bill, the government has used the fact that Sydney Airport already experiences peak hour movements in the mid-seventies, and that a mere increase to 80 movements will be negligible.
I have constituents across all the areas of Sydney affected by the airport, who would not agree.

I note that the Bill does allow the Minister to lower the number of aircraft movements per hour after community consultation. And this is to be applauded. The Democrats believe this is a commendable inclusion. And, when residents complain, about an increase in aircraft movements to 80, we hope the Minister will take notice. The Minister will be wise to remember that airlines and businesses are not the only groups affected by this decision.
This increase in movements will have a devastating effect of the lives of those residents most affected by aircraft noise.

There is a secondary effect of capping aircraft movements to 80. The effect will be to extend the peak hour periods, as flights will be pushed out from these busiest periods, meaning there will be a stream of movements over a longer period of time. I note that the Labor party believes this is worth the trade-off to ensure a legislative capping of aircraft movements.
Each aircraft user of the airport will be given a specific time within a specific hour, on a specified day, in which they can use Sydney Airport.

The Plan will be developed by the aviation industry and submitted to the Minister for approval. This Bill does not provide details on the way the Slot System might operate, although its idea is to provide a consistent approach to demand for all airport users. Two objectives of the Slot System are to provide equitable access for regional airlines, and for new entrants.

We hope this will be the case. There may be other issues impacting upon the development of the Slot Management System. It might be argued that congestion at Sydney Airport is only problematic at peak times. If congestion was the determining factor, then it certainly has not effected the efficiency of the operation of Heathrow Airport, for example, which has had a long problem with congestion.

Perhaps the Slot Management System could incorporate `aircraft-free days' to each of the areas most affected by aircraft noise, and that the Slot Manager informs those communities of the days set aside for their particular area. The ability to plan recreational activities, school exam days, weddings, and so on, and to know that these activities can be undertaken without the impediment of aircraft noise, will help alleviate some of the distress suffered by noise-affected residents.

The other feature the Democrats would like to see incorporated into the Slot Management System, is a fairer sharing of the patterns of take-offs and landings. This has a lot to do with the distribution of noise. Take-offs involve more noise—a lot more noise in some cases. Take-offs can be more flexible in where they can head, whereas landings must approach the airport both straight and low. There is also a greater difference in terms of aircraft type—767s, 747s, 737s and the smaller commuter jets.

These, for the purposes of this Bill are all defined as aircraft movements. The Democrats expect these issues will be taken into due consideration by the Slot Manager in the drafting of the Slot Management System. The day to day operations of the Slot Management System will be undertaken by the aviation industry, with the Department of Transport involved at the level of the Co-ordination Committee.
The Air Traffic Controllers will be involved as members of the Compliance Committee.

The Compliance Committee will be empowered to fine airlines which do not comply with the system. Fines can be up to $220,000, depending on the type of breach. Hopefully, too, the system will allow a clearer and closer scrutiny of the reasons for long delays.

It is also not clear whether the monies collected will be returned to the Slot Management System for administration of the system, or for the establishment of an appeals process. The Democrats believe that at least a proportion of those monies ought to be used for the purposes of funding community projects related to the airport issue.
Or, perhaps the Minister and the Slot Manager could consider channelling that money back into the Sydney Noise Insulation Project, to provide relief for all those residents under the flight path.
There are a couple of other points I wish to make in regard to this Bill.

In 1995, following the Senate inquiry report "Falling on Deaf Ears" I tabled a Private Senator's Bill which provided a capping on the number of movements at Sydney Airport (at 55 movements per hour, and then amended the Bill to extend this figure to 60). The Bill also contained provision for the extension of the curfew, and for the establishment of a Commission of Inquiry for environmental and noise related issues to be reported to the Parliament if the number of movements was to be extended. I received no support from either of the major parties for that Bill.

I find it quite interesting therefore, that in his second reading speech, the shadow Minister for Transport, Mr Tanner believes this Bill is long overdue, and that the `Albanese Bill', introduced by Mr Albanese, the member for Grayndler, to provide a capping of 80 movements per hour, "should have been allowed to be implemented and be passed through this parliament when it was introduced rather than sitting around for months".

Well, these outcomes could have been achieved over two years ago, with greater safeguards for all Sydney residents, by passing the Democrats Private Senator's Bill upon which Mr Albanese's Bill was based.

I also find it quite extraordinary that this Government still has not made a decision on the location of Sydney's second airport site. We can all so easily recall the debates over the sites, and the continual EIS studies which have cost an enormous amount of money. At least the Government have made their mind up about Holsworthy. But the fact remains that there still, in late 1997, has been no decision on the site of the second airport.

The "Falling on Deaf Ears" report found that the capacity of Sydney Airport will be reached within the next few years. The Olympics will be a catalyst for increasing pressures to further extend the capacity of the Airport, remove the curfew, or increase the number of hourly movements. And the longer it takes to develop the second airport, the greater this pressure.
These things cannot be allowed to happen.

I hope, for the residents of New South Wales, and for the users of the facilities at Sydney Airport, that the Slot Management (and its compliance) System and the guarantee of 80 movements per hour will create a better Sydney Airport.

I also expect that the capping of 80 movements per hour does not mean that we will actually get 80 aircraft movements every hour of the airport's operation, but that 80 aircraft movements will be the maximum in peak times only.

The Bill sets the framework for the operation of the Slot Management System only. We will have to wait for the details of the Slot Management System and its Compliance System to be developed by the aviation industry and the department. We will then be in a better position to consider the regulations on their own merits in order to determine whether or not they provide the most suitable vehicle in which to determine these matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Greens do not support the Sydney Airport Demand Management Bill 1997 . The bill sets the maximum hourly movement rate of Kingsford Smith airport at 80 movements an hour. The bill has been strongly endorsed by other components of the Senate, but I want to place on record some facts which challenge that support. It is a fallacy that a cap of 80 movements an hour will stop the growth of the airport. Inner city politicians, such as the member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey), even express the expectation that the number of movements through the airport will decline because of this bill.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the new Minister for Transport and Regional Development, Mr Mark Vaile, said in his speech to the bill that `80 movements an hour equates to approximately half a million movements per year'. That is half a million flights through the airport per year. These are words designed to allay any fears the air transport lobby might have that the cap will impede the growth of the airport.

BREAK.PARA: At present, the annual number of movements is about 270,000. By the minister's own admission, this so‐called cap will allow the number of movements to, in effect, double. The cap of 80 movements per hour is a clayton's cap. It is the cap you have when you are not having a cap at all.

The bill is misnamed. What is proposed here is not demand management; it is traffic management. For reasons I will explain in a moment, the maximum hourly movement rate should certainly not be set at more than 70 movements. This could be achieved quite easily through real demand management, such as requiring the airlines to reorganise their routes so that Kingsford Smith was no longer used as the main hub in Australia.

Currently, some 27 per cent of all air passenger movements at Kingsford Smith are attributable to people who are in transit or transfer. In other words, they never leave the airport in surface transport. They fly in, change planes or wait while other passengers join their flight and then fly out. That hubbing role does not have to be done at Kingsford Smith. If it were done by another airport, the maximum hourly movement rate could be held at 70 movements per hour.

One reason the cap should be set at no more than 70 movements is that the noise sharing component of the long‐term operating plan will not work at levels much above that. When it is handling high volumes of traffic, the airport must employ the parallel runways and not use the east‐west runway.

David Warner, the chair of Sydney's Air Traffic Management Task Force—the body that designed the long‐term operating plan—has said that noise sharing modes will not be possible at movement rates of 73 or more an hour, or even at 64 an hour if certain taxiway improvements are not made.

When the airport is regularly operating for several hours a day at movement rates of more than 73, when it must use the north‐south parallel runways, people north of the airport and at Kurnell in the south will have exposure to noise and air pollution worse than they had before the east‐west runway was re‐opened. The proposed cap of 80 is too dangerous. The maximum hourly movement rate should be set as low as possible to reduce the risk of aircraft crashing. Eighty movements an hour is an enormous stress on air traffic controllers and pilots and exposes hundreds of thousands of Sydney residents to unacceptable risks.

In 1989, long before the third runway became operational, it was estimated that for people living near the airport under the northern flight path the risk of being killed by an aircraft crash was 40 chances per million per year. Compare this with the risk of a pedestrian being killed by a motor vehicle, which is about 35 chances per million per year. In other words, there was more chance of being killed by a plane crash than being killed by a motor vehicle.

That was in 1989 when aircraft movements at Kingsford Smith were at about 200,000 per year. Today there are 270,000 and the number is growing at an incredible rate which, if unconstrained, could see the level at 400,000 by the year 2005.

The fatality risk for people living under the flight paths is already too high. It is terrifying to think what it will be in the future, but we have no figures on that because, to his everlasting shame, the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill, has refused an EIS on the long‐term operating plan. No doubt one reason he refused an EIS was that it would have made forecasts about the level of risk people will be exposed to as the air traffic increases, and the government does not want the people to know that.

Kingsford Smith sits cheek by jowl with many hazardous installations and storage facilities, including several oil terminals, the ICI complex and other petrochemical and chemical industries. The area adjacent to the airport is the major chemical and petrochemical industrial complex in New South Wales. The southern approach path brings planes in over the Kurnell refinery which is the largest in Australia.

You might think it is worth investigating the wisdom of intensifying the use of an airport so close to so many dangerous installations. This government, like the government before it, has shirked that responsibility. The two parallel runways are only 1,050 metres apart. By international standards, that is very small for independent operations of large aircraft. To achieve the rate of 80 movements an hour on these closely spaced runways—

TALK.START.PARA: —They're medium spaced.

—Senator Forshaw might reassure residents by saying that they are medium spaced, but I maintain that they are closely spaced. New and relatively untried radar technology must be used; whether they be medium or closely spaced, that is a requirement. This technology does not have a long and distinguished track record. It is only a couple of years old and is installed in only two airports in the world, one of them being Kingsford Smith.

BREAK.PARA: We are taking risks with this airport, and they are big risks. Several air transport organisations such as the International Air Transport Association and the aircraft manufacturer, Boeing, have predicted that by the year 2010 there will be a major air crash somewhere in the world, once a week—52 a year. There is no reason to think that Kingsford Smith will be immune from that trend, especially given the narrow separation of its runways.

Pilots are expected to follow complex arrival and departure procedures and already the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation has reported that domestic and international pilots often have problems following air traffic controllers' instructions. The Telegraph Mirror on 20 February last and Australian Aviation magazine of July 1997 reported the bureau's findings that pilots frequently failed to comply with air traffic control directives. Many such incidents involve large commercial jets at this airport.

Some of the mistakes at Kingsford Smith have been publicised. At 2.40 p.m. on 10 October 1995, when traffic levels were, luckily, very low, a fully laden Qantas 737 from Auckland landed on the wrong runway. In January this year an Ansett A320 failed to obey the instruction to veer left as it took off, and came close to the path of an incoming Japan Airlines 747.

Kingsford Smith is not immune to the prospect of accidents. In recent years there have been several serious accidents in the approach to and departures from the airport. In April 1994 a DC3 crashed into Botany Bay when taking off. In April 1995 an engine cowling fell from a Philippine Airlines jet shortly after take off. In both instances it was pure luck that the take offs were to the south and no‐one was killed. In January 1994 the pilot and sole occupant of an AeroCommander turboprop cargo plane was killed when it crashed off Cronulla as he was preparing to land.

The exponential growth of air traffic at the airport, the congested and complicated arrival and departure streams, and the ever decreasing safety margins as new technology is employed to increase capacity rather than to improve safety, all bode ill for passengers and residents alike. About 60 per cent of fatal crashes occur during approach and landing—that is worldwide. About 25 per cent of fatal crashes occurred during take off. It does not make sense to have approach and departure paths over a densely populated area.

I turn now to the myth that an airport at Badgerys Creek is the solution to the airport problem in inner Sydney. Badgerys Creek is a confidence trick on the people of inner Sydney. If it is built, it will do nothing to alleviate their problems and, in all likelihood, will actually make the situation worse. In two airport systems all over the world the role of the second airport is to enable the main airport to operate more efficiently. In other words, Badgerys Creek will take smaller aircraft from Kingsford Smith, freeing up capacity to accept more large jets. It will also take the overflow of jets during peak hour so that Kingsford Smith will operate in the most efficient and cost effective way.
As stated in the original second airport EIS at page 57 and repeated in the third runway draft EIS at pages 5 to 7:

A second airport augments the capacity of a primary airport by catering for peaks in traffic . . . when there is only one (airport). It must necessarily be under‐utilized a great deal if it is sized to handle the peak. Where there are two facilities, one handling the peak and the other the baseload, the utilization of the primary airport can become very high. Indeed, the secondary airport makes it possible for the primary airport to be fully utilized most of the time, operating at a maximum capacity during most of the hours it is open.

You have only to consider the airports in London to see that a second airport does nothing to ease the problem of the first airport. Heathrow is still growing, even though it has a second airport, Gatwick. London now even has a third and fourth airport, but Heathrow continues to grow.

If Badgerys Creek is not the obvious solution, why has there been such Messianic support for it over the years from inner Sydney Labor politicians and more recently from inner Sydney Liberals? The answer is that they have nothing else to offer—within the limited parameters that they are prepared to consider this matter, the only hope they offer their constituents is the false hope of Badgerys Creek.

They are not prepared to consider downgrading Kingsford Smith, nor even genuinely limiting its growth. Badgerys is not now, nor ever will be, the solution. It is not planned to be a replacement airport, nor should it be. It will not even be an adequate second airport.If it is built, it will not solve the problems of inner Sydney, but it will create problems of its own, including noise pollution for tens of thousands of Sydney residents. It will further degrade the catchment of the Hawkesbury‐Nepean and will obliterate areas of significance in terms of Aboriginal heritage and remnant vegetation.

Sydney's air quality, which is already known to be in a critical condition, will give the final coup de grace if Badgerys Creek airport is built. If you want to turn Sydney into Los Angeles, build an airport at Badgerys. The only solution to Sydney's airport dilemma is to build a replacement airport. Kingsford Smith should be downgraded and eventually closed. Some people are going to say that the Greens are crazy if they think Kingsford Smith can be closed. We say, alternatively, or in the opposite direction, it is crazy to think that it can stay there. Many economic experts, such as Professor Gordon Mills from the Sydney University's Centre of Micreoeconomic Policy Analysis, believe that taxpayers will get a better return on their money if the land now occupied by the airport were to be utilised for residential, commercial and recreational purposes.

The replacement airport should be outside the Sydney basin air shed and able to be connected with fast train links. The site selection process should be reopened now before any further mistakes are made. We should look at all potential sites and investigate their feasibility and environmental impacts.

Finally, there is that myth being promulgated about this bill that it will enshrine in legislation the present levels of access to Kingsford Smith by regional airlines. The bill does not do that. Presumably, given the promises that are being made, the regulations will include such a provision. But it is not in the bill, and the regulations are more easily changed than is the actual legislation.

If we continue along the present path there is nothing surer than that the regional airlines will eventually be squeezed out of Kingsford Smith. A second airport at Badgerys Creek will facilitate that. Under this so‐called cap, the day could come when for 17 hours a day there will be 80 movements every hour, and they will all be jet movements. What sort of cap is that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts)

I take this opportunity to ask the minister if he has any comment on the figures I used about the increasing lack of safety for residents living under flight paths in Sydney, and the increasing potential for aircraft accidents with a cap which could lead to up to half a million aircraft movements through Kingsford Smith per annum?

This bill is also a management tool to limit movements in a given time. I would be of the view that this bill now supersedes the peak charge legislation so does this mean that, with the introduction of this bill, peak charges will be abolished?
