TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. I refer to Mr Reith's demand on AM this morning that the maritime unions accept publicly stated performance targets in order to improve their productivity. Will the government now do the decent thing and announce a publicly stated performance target for itself on unemployment? How much will it reduce unemployment by and within what time frame?

—The performance indicator of the government is the budget, and watch out for that next year because it will be a good one, Senator Cook. In relation to employment, we have had some good figures recently. We had a slight decrease in the rate of unemployment. We have had some good figures from the ANZ survey on jobs. Today, with the jobs vacancy survey conducted by DEETYA, there has been a slight rise in the number of vacancies in skilled employment. That all points to the right track. We are on the right track in relation to that. With the forecast growth that we have, things can only get better. But coupled with that, Senator Cook, can I tell you that we are looking at training our youth, as you well know, with our apprenticeship scheme to give an opportunity to our youth for real jobs. That apprenticeship scheme is real training for real jobs. So, if you want performance indicators, just look at how we are doing.

BREAK.PARA: I remind you also of the MTIA report which looked at seven ways for Australia to get richer. Do you know what it said? It said that this government had achieved a majority of those means already by putting our budget on track and wheeling in the deficit that you gave us. The MTIA report said that we are on the right track with macro-economic reform and it applauded this government's fiscal policy. It is that fiscal policy which is placing this government in a very strong position in relation to the South‐East Asian position. If you do not believe that, read the Herald Tribune article written on the weekend which said that Australia stood strongly amongst the Asia‐Pacific region. That is an international paper made up of the Washington Post and the New York Times whereby the international community recognise the strength of this economy.

Do you want me to go on? I can go on, because what we have got, Senator Cook, is a very good economy. We have growth on the way up, we have low inflation and we have low interest rates—very different from what you had. We have a rate of unemployment which is nowhere near the 11 per cent that peaked under you, mate. I can tell you right now that, if you want performance indicators, we will give them to you.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, since you say that you will give us performance indicators, when can we expect to hear from you on what your performance indicators will be as to what the target will be to reduce unemployment by and within what time frame? You said that you will give us some performance indicators; when will you announce those two targets, Minister? While you are on the subject, and since you talked about the budget, can you at least tell us what economic growth figure the government believes is necessary in order to achieve an improvement in the unemployment figures by the end of this financial year?

—The forecast this government has stated in relation to unemployment is eight per cent by the June quarter of 1998. That is the forecast figure which we have stated. Over the June quarter of 1997, the growth rate was 3.2 per cent, which is a great increase on last year. Senator Cook, in relation to your supplementary question, you obviously did not listen to my first answer on our performance indicators. They are there and you will just have to wait for the budget to see just how well this government will be going next year.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Minister, I note that the Australian officials at the Bonn climate change negotiations are reporting a high level of interest in Australia's unilateral efforts to reduce greenhouse emissions. Will you confirm reports that other delegates are seeking details of Australia's efforts? Is there a particular interest in Australia's greenhouse challenge program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank Senator Macdonald for that question because one of the highlights that have come out of the Bonn negotiations is the very high level of interest in Australia's efforts to reduce greenhouse emissions. They are particularly interested in our very successful greenhouse challenge program. This interest in the program follows President Clinton's announcement on US climate change proposals. The US proposals contain aspects that bear a remarkable similarity to the philosophy and aims of our greenhouse challenge program. It is already apparent that many of the delegates acknowledge that Australia's efforts deserve consideration and recognition.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. My understanding of standing orders in this place with regard to photographs being taken is that a photographer can focus only on the person speaking. That photographer has been waving his camera right across all the people sitting on this side. I ask you to request him to desist from that practice.
—Photographs may be taken of only the person who has the call at the time. I call Senator Parer.

—Thank you, Madam President; I will smile. The interest in Bonn in the greenhouse challenge program is a real endorsement of the dedication and solid continued performance of those who have worked so hard to make the greenhouse challenge program work, despite sustained and ill‐informed criticism by minority groups whose efforts raise concerns about their real agenda. They are certainly not in Australia's interests.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia's greenhouse challenge program is a cooperative, voluntary agreement between the federal government and industry, with industry committed to specific emission reduction targets and reporting back annually on progress. Four of Australia's largest companies—Rio Tinto, BHP, Shell and ICI—in August lodged the first reports under the program showing that all were reducing their emissions on a per unit of production basis. In two years, 200 organisations have become greenhouse challengers; 53 cooperative agreements have been signed, and more than 40 other agreements are likely to be finalised before the Kyoto conference. The agreements signed to date will reduce the companies' forecast greenhouse gas emissions in the year 2000 by an equivalent of 17 million tonnes of carbon dioxide.

Central to the Clinton proposal was the consultation process between industry, key energy sectors and government on how best to reduce emissions and encourage use of energy efficient products. President Clinton also said that American companies would be given credit for early action to provide an immediate incentive for them to act early. He said that the USA would pursue industry by industry consultations with key industry sectors on how they could best reduce emissions and encourage the use of energy efficient products. This is the basis of the greenhouse challenge program. The similarity between this element of the US proposal and Australia's greenhouse challenge has been noted by my colleague Senator Hill in his comments on the US proposal.

The Greenhouse Challenge Office is attending the climate change negotiations in Bonn to raise international awareness and understanding of the objectives and achievements of the greenhouse challenge program. The program is attracting strong interest from international delegates about this partnership approach between government and industry. Delegates were interested to find out how the program works, how Australian industry was encouraged to take a voluntary approach to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and the program's achievements to date.

In Australia the Greenhouse Challenge Office, government and peak industry associations in the energy, mining, manufacturing, commercial transport and services sectors have been working to encourage companies to improve their energy efficiency and adopt world's best practice in the efficient use of energy. Finally, I want to emphasise to those opposite that there is little doubt that Australia's efforts are now being recognised and quietly supported by more and more developed countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Assistant Treasurer. I ask: why has the Australian Tax Office recently made a ruling that from 1998 adjustable beds, which are used for the frail elderly and disabled, will lose their sales tax exempt status and be subject to a 12 per cent rate? Isn't it true that by overturning a 1985 decision you are adding up to $300 to the cost of these beds which, as you know, are bought almost exclusively by old and disabled people? Is this ruling just another revenue raising exercise; or is it, like your decisions on nursing homes, part of a concerted attack on elderly and sick Australians? What action will you take to overturn this decision?

—I thought the first part of the question was interesting and important; I thought the second part was just a pathetic political attack. To argue, Senator, that this government has not given great thought and major policy initiatives to help the care and comfort of the aged is just dead wrong. It is quite clear, Senator West, that you have not bothered to look at the policy initiatives that this government has taken, and will continue to take, for a disadvantaged group in the community. In relation to the tax ruling, the tax ruling is an interpretation by the Tax Commissioner of the law as it now stands. If you want further details on that, I will seek those from the commissioner.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Is there any chance of this being overturned by the government? Also, will you at least rule out a change in the tax exempt status for other items for sick, disabled and elderly people, such as lift chairs and other medical aids?

—Senator, as I said, the tax rulings are an interpretation of the law by the Tax Commissioner. The matter you have raised is clearly an important issue, and I am quite happy to come back and advise the Senate on that matter.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. The Howard government has a clear commitment to improving literacy in Australian schools. Will the minister inform the Senate of the initiative this government is taking? Are the government's efforts supported by international trends?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Heffernan for this most important question. There are two parts to this question. I will deal first with the second part, international practice, because the opposition might be interested to know what Tony Blair had to say about this in his address to the Labor conference in Brighton; in fact, he stressed education. In his speech last month, he set a target of 80 per cent of students meeting the standard in literacy by 2002; for numeracy, the target was to be 75 per cent by the year 2002. Tony Blair agrees with what we are doing. Recently, when I attended the UNESCO conference in Paris, there was an overwhelming sentiment that literacy was most important in today's world; and there was recognition of what this government was doing in relation to literacy and numeracy.

ANSWER.PARA: Let us just have a look at what this government has been doing. In March this year, Dr Kemp, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, called for a national effort to promote the literacy and numeracy skills of young Australians. Com monwealth, state and territory education ministers have subsequently agreed to a national literacy and numeracy goal. That goal is that `every child leaving primary school should be numerate, be able to read, write and spell at an appropriate level'. As well as that, the minister has also adopted a subgoal; that is, that `every child commencing school from 1998 will achieve a minimum acceptable literacy and numeracy standard within four years'. It was also agreed that the goals would be achieved through a national literacy and numeracy plan which focuses on the crucial early years of schooling.

I might add that it is important that students' progress can be measured, and education ministers agreed that national benchmarks in literacy and numeracy should be set for years 3, 5, 7 and 9. Assessment against the benchmarks and national reporting achievements are key elements of this national plan. Education ministers will consider the approval of a final year 3 and year 5 literacy benchmark at the next ministerial council, scheduled for 12 December this year.

The Commonwealth makes a significant financial contribution to schools in the sum of $3.8 billion a year. In the last two federal budgets schools funding has been one of the few areas of federal expenditure which has been quarantined from cuts. In fact, for literacy there has been an increase of over $80 million over the four years from 1997 to the year 2000. This government has already committed $669 million for literacy and numeracy in those four years. Of this amount, $650 million is allocated to education authorities for grants to schools. As well as this, the Commonwealth is also providing $19 million to fund national literacy strategies and projects. This includes $7 million for professional development for teachers in all government and non-government educational systems.

Madam President, this government recognises quite clearly that this is an issue which has to be addressed which the last government failed to address. This government believes that the goal of Australian schools should be to ensure that all Australian children reach their full educational and personal potential. Education is after all a passport to life. That is something which this government recognises and the last one did not.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Alston, Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts. Minister, I refer to your claim in the Senate on 20 October that the Savage Garden CD retails in New Zealand for $A18.90. How do you reconcile that claim with the fact that the only wholesaler licensed to distribute the CD in New Zealand has stated that all of their CDs have been sold at a wholesale price of $A17.90 without taking into account any retail mark‐up or the New Zealand GST of 12.5 per cent, and that they were retailing in New Zealand on 21 October at prices from $A24.55 to $A31.79? Do you have any evidence to back up the claim that you made in the Senate on 20 October, or were you just making it up?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The precise details of the price differential are not currently in my mind, but—
—Ha, ha!

—I am delighted to know that you are aware of precisely the price differential—are you? The information that I have, which was based on inquiries made in New Zealand on the very day to which I referred, was that last Monday a copy of a CD by the multi-award winning band, Savage Garden, was retailing in the big discount chain stores for $29 in Sydney and $30.95 in Canberra. The same CD purchased in New Zealand on the same day was the equivalent of $A18.90. It was on sale in Los Angeles on Friday for $A23 and on the Internet for $A17.

ANSWER.PARA: These are not figures plucked out of the air. These are figures based on inquiries made at the point of sale. I know that Mr McMullan, who has lately taken an interest in this issue, has certainly suggested that there is not such a great price differential, but of course he is comparing New Zealand prices with Australian prices for a CD using a different exchange rate. Whereas, on the information available to me, the price comparison was made on the same date; so you are talking about the same record on the same date.

BREAK.PARA: Of course, during that very time that elapsed before Mr McMullan weighed into the argument, there has been a significant devaluation of the Australian dollar against the New Zealand dollar. I can understand why he might have wanted to portray it in a slightly different light. But the fact is that the exchange rate was supplied to the government by AAP at the time of the actual purchase in New Zealand, not an artificial rate a week old.

I also found it of interest that Mr McMullan's press release did confirm that New Zealand consumers pay less for their CDs than Australian consumers and that is one of the matters that is of great concern to us. If there is such a significant price differential, why do prices need to be so high in Australia? Is it because if you control the market, you can decide to charge whatever you think the market will bear? If you think that the New Zealand market is more depressed or it is smaller and they will not be able to pay the same price, therefore you sell them more cheaply.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —They are horrified at your behaviour and I can understand that. They only have to take one look at Senator Faulkner and they are horrified. We have to stay here unfortunately, unlike those who have a choice in the matter.

BREAK.PARA: All I can say is, if you really want to address this issue seriously, you will look at all of the evidence that demonstrates that prices of CDs in Australia are much higher than in a number of other countries, despite the fact that you will get the Michael Gudinskis of this world saying blithely that we have very cheap CDs, close to the cheapest in the world and no-one else goes down the path we are proposing. None of that is factual and if you looked at the Sunday program a few weeks ago you will have seen that there is a very significant price differential even within the European Community. There is parallel importing allowed within that whole group of countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I will make it quite simple. Minister, are you aware that at the same time the Savage Garden CD was retailing in New Zealand at prices ranging from $A24.35 to $A31.79 it was available in Brashs in Canberra for $24.95? Is it true then, as you explained to the Senate on 20 October, that there could not be a starker contrast between the price of CDs in this country and the price of one of our nearest neighbours, New Zealand?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —If I understood Senator Lundy's question correctly, she said that in New Zealand you could buy a Savage Garden record for the equivalent of $24.95 and $31, whereas in Australia you could buy it for $24.95. None of that in the slightest contradicts the proposition that you can also buy it in Australia for $31 and in New Zealand for $24.95. Quite clearly, Senator Lundy is conceding that there is a very significant price differential between Australia and New Zealand. I simply do not understand why you want to barrack for higher prices in Australia than there needs to be.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts. The government agreed to the call number display—the CND—as an opt‐out service, on the basis that Telstra complied with Austel's privacy advisory committee report. That report recommended that Telstra achieve a level of 80 per cent awareness of how to switch off the call number display before the service be introduced. This was also the basis upon which consumer groups participated in the negotiation process. It was also part of the government's election commitment to privacy laws in the private sector. Can the minister assure Australians that the call number display service will not be introduced unless 80 per cent of consumers are aware of how to turn off the service?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that there are concerns about the potential privacy implications of the proposed new CND or caller‐ID services. The Australian Communications Authority has requested the Australian Communications Industry Forum to develop, as a matter of priority, a code on CND intro duction and calling‐line identification availability issues.

ANSWER.PARA: The former regulator, Austel, did develop CND guidelines in 1996, which were agreed to by the then government. The guidelines incorporated recommendations that CND be offered on an opt‐out basis, that blocking be free of charge, that carriers be required to conduct CND public education campaigns—with 80 per cent successful awareness—before introducing services, that private line customers be given default line blocking and that organisations which receive CND services implement procedures for ethical use and privacy protection guidelines. These guidelines provide an appropriate balance between the desire of persons to have the service introduced and the need to address privacy implications of CND—particularly the desire of persons that their telephone numbers remain private.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you stated that people are concerned about the privacy implications. Are you concerned about the privacy implications? When can we expect a copy of the code to which you referred, and what privacy measures are in place now—or will be in place by 1 December this year—to ensure that personal information sent or received using the CND will be adequately protected?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have already indicated, the ACA has requested the Communications Industry Forum to develop, as a matter of priority, a code on CND introduction. They are aware that that should be in place before 1 December. No doubt they will take account of any privacy concerns expressed to them. The opt‐out principle, which was certainly one espoused by the previous government, does enable those who are aware of the service to decide that they do not want that access given. Clearly we want a sufficient level of awareness, but you obviously want to hand‐feed people; you want to insist on it all being done for them. We would rather go down the awareness track, as our predecessors did. The code will be designed to ensure that we achieve those targets.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. Minister, are you aware that RMIT plans to reduce undergraduate HECS places in high demand courses in 1998? Is it the case that planning documents prepared by RMIT as part of the university's profile negotiations detail reductions in undergraduate HECS places of 200 students in business and 110 students in applied science for 1998? Are these course reductions the result of the federal government's funding cuts or are they an attempt to strip back undergraduate HECS places in potentially profitable faculties to accommodate up‐front fee paying students? Can the minister assure the Senate that, despite the debilitating effects of the job losses in DEETYA, the department is closely monitoring university planning documents for 1998? (Time expired)

—The Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology runs its own affairs, Senator Carr. It is not for the government to dictate to that university how it should run its internal affairs, but it has realised an increased demand for fee paying positions, and that is something which is being felt across the board.
—What rot: 80 per cent of staff and students—

—There has been an increase in applications, Senator Stott Despoja. DEETYA is certainly well able to monitor how universities are planning their affairs, but the points you raise are a matter for the university.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, the points that I raise go to the question of the department's monitoring of the universities in terms of the government's policy on up‐front fee paying and the commitment that there would be no reduction in undergraduate load. There is clear evidence here that the government policy is being breached. What are you going to do about ensuring that there is adequate monitoring of those universities and their abuses of those fee paying provisions to ensure that they return higher levels of up‐ front fees at the expense of HECS paying undergraduate load?

—To answer your question, Senator Carr, there is no evidence that the government's policy is being breached. In any event, the department will be monitoring all university plans and university activities and will report to me in due course.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is it a fact that on 1 October the Prime Minister wrote to the Remuneration Tribunal asking the tribunal to look at a new and different method of paying parliamentary travel allowances? Will the minister inform the Senate what the nature of the request was and release a copy of that letter to the public? Can the minister confirm that no other parliamentarians or members of the public will have input into the deliberations of the tribunal? Will the minister, through the Prime Minister, see that the process is opened up to both public input and scrutiny?

—I remember the Prime Minister announcing that he was referring that matter to the Remuneration Tribunal. As I recall it, I saw what I think was probably an interim report from the tribunal saying that they were considering the matter. I have no knowledge of the nature or details of the inquiry that they are conducting. I will seek advice on that and report back as soon as possible.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question of the minister. The report he saw may have included the fact that earlier inquiries which did have parliamentarians' input have been suspended while the Prime Minister's request is being answered by the tribunal. I ask again, will the minister put it to the Prime Minister that other parliamentarians—all members of parliament—and members of the public have input into the tribunal's deliberations? Can he give an assurance that the tribunal's findings will be made public?

—I am sure the tribunal findings will be made public. I would be very surprised if that is not the case. Senator Brown is right; he reminds me that the interim report did say that the general consideration was being postponed whilst this was being looked at. I can remember a few determinations also being announced, including one that concerns somebody in this chamber.
—National Party whips.

—You read the reports too, Senator? One concerns the chairman of the Treaties Committee, I can recall. I do not really see that there is any reason why Senator Brown, if he is interested in this matter, could not write to the tribunal himself.

—My question is directed to Senator Herron, the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. Minister, how does the government justify its proposal that parents of children in child care who fail to provide information about a change of circumstances affecting their child care assistance within 14 days of being asked to provide it are punishable by six months imprisonment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Gibbs for the question. As I understand it, that was a continuation of the previous government's legislation. There were added reasons for its continuation, but as I understand it, it was a continuation of the previous government's legislation. I will get back to you if I am incorrect in that regard. I do not see anything in the brief that covers that particular question and I will get back to you on that if I can obtain any information. It is not in the brief. I have read the brief and I have not seen that particular answer to the question, so I will get back to you on that if there is anything relevant here.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Thank you for that, Minister. Could you ask the Minister for Family Services if that is so and, if that is the case, could this draconian proposal be put forward to the minister and could he be asked to reconsider it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am happy to do that. As I understand it from previous information, that was the continuation of legisla tion, as I have said. The opposition has no claim to any great, extraordinary results in relation to the child care legislation which we are now fixing up for them. The approach we are taking is entirely different to what they did. We are now changing the focus from service providers to parents, a rather major change. We are also making a less prescriptive service provision system. We have a series of safety nets to ensure that families with children who require additional support are able to access the child care that they require, unlike what was available under the previous administration. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Knowles, Sen Susan

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Justice, Senator Vanstone. Minister, as you know the law and order issue is of great concern to all Australians. Would you please outline to the Senate—

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't it interesting that the opposition do not believe that law and order is a problem for all Australians. It is worth noting that. No doubt the minister will make comment about that as well. Minister, would you please inform the Senate as to what this government is actually doing to reduce crime and the fear of crime that is confronting the community?

—I thank Senator Knowles for the question because she rightly identifies, despite the opposition's complete lack of interest in the community's concern about law and order, that there is a fear of crime in the community. People do feel that it is probable that they will be the victim of some form of crime against their person or property. In a world where globalisation and technology mean a shrinking world, where international borders are becoming less relevant and the nature of crime is changing dramatically, governments have to be ready to respond.
—You cut back on customs; that's what you did.
—For crime prevention, that means a much greater level of international and national cooperation.
—You cut back the NCA in South Australia.

—Commissioner Palmer was appointed recently as the Asia delegate for Interpol and that is a great recognition of the role that the AFP can play in this respect. The annual report of the AFP clearly indicates that their recent success in the fight against global crime directly relates to greater interagency cooperation.
—You have cut back by hundreds of millions of dollars.

—Senator Bolkus sits over there, jabbering away and saying, `What about cutbacks?' yet again seeking to exaggerate in the community the notion of a cut‐down in law and order when he well knows that those cuts are a function of having to fill Beazley's black hole, when he knows full well that his government put efficiency dividends on the AFP and when he knows how many officers came out of the AFP under his government's control; he, nonetheless, seeks to complain. With these small cutbacks that had to be made to fill Beazley's black hole, nonetheless, in the first month of this year, the AFP seized around 60 kilograms of amphetamines, 60 kilograms of cocaine, 250 kilograms of heroin and 11,600 kilograms of cannabis products, with some 380 arrests and summonses and 711 charges laid.

BREAK.PARA: AUSTRAC plays a key role in the gathering and analysis of financial information, which is very important especially in relation to drug dealers. The notion of the important drug dealers being people operating on a street corner is long gone. AUSTRAC plays a key role in the activities of those involved in money laundering, in major tax evasion and, of course, in drugs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you tell them the truth about it?

—This portfolio is particularly involved in reducing the supply of illicit drugs. The Prime Minister announced the formation of a task force to review the problem of illicit drugs. That task force has in fact reported. The Prime Minister has also indicated he will be making a major announcement on Sunday with a major Com monwealth initiative in the fight against illicit drugs.
—Why don't you tell them how much more drugs are coming in?
—Senator Bolkus, instead of interjecting and niggling and complaining and being unhappy that he is not in government, would do well to recognise the point that was made the other day—
—I'm not. I'm exposing your hypocrisy; $250 million cuts.

—And that is that the community does not want politicians fighting each other over drugs; what the community wants is politicians fighting together against them. Senator Bolkus, you might as well understand that. We are going to have a cooperative approach like you never did.

—On a point of order, Madam President: I have noticed that Senator Vanstone does not appear to be addressing her remarks through the chair. I know she is bitter about her dumping by the Prime Minister to this junior portfolio, but I do think you ought to draw to her attention that she is required to address her remarks through you.
—There is no point of order. Senator Bolkus should cease interjecting and Senator Vanstone should ignore him.

—Senator Faulkner has never forgiven himself for begging Richo for his job. That is the real problem. Remember that? `Ah, but I am a good environment minister.' The minister for getting rolled. Get real, sport.

BREAK.PARA: What needs to be understood is that we will be working with the states and we will be working with parents and schools. We will have a cooperative approach to the battle against illicit drugs in Australia the likes of which the opposition never put together. They sit there and carp. They want to be divisive on this.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a totally dishonest approach. Tell them what you cut back. They want resources and you don't want to give them that.

—What the community wants, Senator Bolkus, through you, Madam President, is a cooperative approach in the fight against drugs. They want us to work together. If you do not want to be a part of that, you stay over there nitpicking and carping. But on Sunday we would look forward to a bit of support and the community would look forward to a bipartisan approach on the fight against illicit drugs.

—My question is addressed to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Is it true that, contrary to an election commitment given by the government that there would be no involuntary redundancies in the public sector, the names of the 22 Australian Taxation Office staff marked for involuntary redundancy will be released in the near future? Can the minister tell the Senate what criteria the government and the Australian Taxation Office are using to decide which of its 22 staff will be sacked?

—Senator, in relation to the question that has been raised, we have, as you are aware, undergone a major review in the tax office to make sure that the tax office is efficient and works at best practice. You will be aware that quite a range of announcements have been made in relation to change in the tax office, which I would have thought the Labor Party would have been very strongly supportive of. You have asked about 22 particular people and the criteria. I will check and provide you with an answer.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, it is my understanding that the criterion that the tax office is using to decide who those 22 staff will be is those staff that are deemed to be the least efficient. Can the minister confirm whether this is the case? If so, what is the government's and the ATO's definition of `the least efficient' and how is it to be measured?
—Did you write that?
—Yes.

—I am not sure what you would prefer, Senator Mackay: that the tax office should retrench the most efficient. I do not know whether that was the implication which came from your question. It certainly sounded like that.
—How do you define it?
—I know that you have trouble defining who is efficient and who is not, but we don't.

—My question is to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, I draw your attention to the newspaper article in the Age today quoting Will Hutton. Does the minister agree with the proposition of Will Hutton, noted author and economic commentator currently touring Australia, who is today reported to argue that, while markets have important merits, they are also unstable, short‐term and very poor at distributing risks fairly if left to their own devices; that endemic short‐termism is one of the fundamental weaknesses of Australia's economy, especially of our money markets, which are obsessed with quick returns; and that there are no more persuasive advocates for the intervention of governments in the marketplace than the high priests of economic rationalism in global financial markets who look to the International Monetary Fund to bail out countries such as Mexico and Thailand, and even to central banks to provide them with liquidity and capital if necessary. Does the minister agree that it is hypocrisy—
—Order! Senator Murray the time for asking your question has expired. I call Senator Kemp.
—Madam President, I raise a point of order. I think the government should be aware that I gave notice of that question.
—Senator Murray, there is no point of order. I call Senator Kemp.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Indeed, I did just prior to question time today receive a call from Senator Murray who asked whether I had read my Melbourne Age this morning. I had to confess I had not read my Melbourne Age . Because of the interest of Senator Murray in this matter—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just a moment, Senator Kemp. It is hard to hear you.

—Indeed it is, Madam President, because of the rabble on the other side. Senator Murray is quite right. He drew that particular article to my attention and as a result I did have a chance to read the material. There were some things in the article which, I would have to say, I agreed with. There were some things in the article which I thought did not match my views, and some things in the article which I thought were plain wrong.

BREAK.PARA: Let me say, in relation to the first matter, that I agreed with the proposition that markets are not everything. Markets are not an end; markets are a means to an end. This government of course does not slavishly believe in markets. We believe that markets are often a very efficient way of ensuring that the right signals are given for production and consumption and that they lead to greater efficiencies in the economy.

The alternative to markets we have seen in planned economies. There was one political party in Australia that actually used to believe in being socialist. That particular approach has been dropped because the socialist approach to the world—as George Campbell would readily agree—comprehensively failed this century. Those particular economies, Senator Murray, which decided they would not use markets in the end suffered major collapses of their political systems, social systems and economies. So the fact of the matter is that we do not slavishly believe in markets. Can markets always work better? The answer is yes, they can, and there is a whole range of regulations which are established by government to assist markets and to ensure that markets can operate effectively and efficiently.

Senator, there are other things in the article which, I would have to say, I did not agree with. I thought the discussion in the article on the constitution was, to say it politely, fairly lightweight. But, Senator, it was an interesting article. It was an article which in some ways was provocative but, as I said, it was a bit like the parson's egg.

TALK.START.PARA: —Curate's!
—The curate's egg: some parts were good and some parts were not so good.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The point of the question was not lost on the minister although it was lost on some of his colleagues. Will Hutton is the author of the most influential book in the UK in the last three years, and the point he makes is that market intervention is necessary in dealing with joblessness and a lack of confidence in the economy. The question is: does the minister acknowledge that, given that the government does and must intervene in the economy, it requires an effective, efficient, well‐resourced and trained public service to do it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course it is absolutely vital that we have an effective, efficient and well‐trained public service. No‐one would argue with that and so on that particular point we are in blazing agreement. On the issue of the role of government in promoting employment, this government believes that creating employment is one of its highest priorities, and we have put in place a range of policies to ensure that the fundamentals of this economy are right and that the brakes on growth come off. That is precisely what is occurring.

ANSWER.PARA: We were left by the failed previous government with an economy where the fiscal imbalances were huge, where there was mounting debt, mounting interest rate bills and all those things which create major problems and which of course have resulted ultimately in the high levels of unemployment that the Labor Party left this country with. This is an issue that we are dealing with very effectively.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Herron as the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. Minister, at the last election the federal government, then in opposition, offered the women of Australia choice. Are you aware of a recent report by Gillian Beer, of the National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling, which shows that women who work, particularly those from low income families, have no financial incentives to work, even part time, because of the high costs of child care and the rapid reduction in family payments? How have you provided women with choice when you are condemning these low income women, who would like to work, with extra child‐care costs and penalties which have made working too expensive? Aren't you in fact forcing women to remain at home?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of that particular thing, but the whole premise on which that question is asked has no foundation whatsoever.
—That is what the Lyons Forum wanted—punish poor working‐class women. This is what you wanted.
—Thank you, Senator Schacht. This has no foundation whatsoever.
—Senator Schacht, cease interjecting!

—It is a completely false premise. The opposition is again trying to beat this up, and some of the media have suggested that rising child‐care fees are forcing women out of the work force. But it is important to look at the facts. Let us look at the facts. Decisions to increase fees are made by service providers, not by government. It is a free market. Fee structures in child care are influenced by several factors such as movements in award wages; charging practices; changes to regulations or increases in overheads, such as rates, insurance and utilities—something that those on the other side would have no concept of because they have never been in a decent occupation in private enterprise where people understand these things.

ANSWER.PARA: Secondly, the ABS labour force figures show that the total participation rate for females with dependent children under 15 years has remained relatively stable—about 59 per cent since January 1996—so there has been no change. But `Don't let the facts interfere with the argument' is the opposition's approach. Thirdly, preliminary 1997 child care census data shows that the average weekly full‐time fee for families attending long day care centres is now around $160. This is only slightly above the trend over the last six years that has seen increases of around six per cent, or between $6 and $10 per year for families using full time care. So there has been no change.

Under the previous government the graph shows identical change. Senator Faulkner may not be aware of that, but there has been no change. So to suggest that there has been some dramatic change is completely false. But `Don't let the facts interfere with the argument,' is what the opposition says. Claims that the government's child‐care measures have forced women out of the work force have no basis in fact when a responsible analysis of the data is undertaken. But responsibility is not something that one usually associates with the opposition—just as they are creating the apparent firestorm in relation to aged care.

The government is concerned that the fees continue to rise, as they have done since 1991. It is a fact that fees are rising. The new child‐care council will examine charging practices as a key priority over the next year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. As a woman who has worked in a low income occupation, I ask the minister: how can you claim to be representing battling families when you are preventing women in battling families from contributing to their family income and participating in the work force? According to this research, a woman must work more than 19 hours per week before the benefits outweigh the costs of working.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Now we are going to a specific example and the point is made that of course there is a spectrum of matters across the whole population.
—In the fullness of time.
—It depends again on the wages of that particular person, the number of hours that are required, the access, the fees that are charged.
—What about the average income earner?
—The figures speak for themselves. It is an incorrect premise that Senator Jacinta Collins—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections for people to hear.
—They do not like hearing facts, Madam President, because it interferes with the argument. The facts speak for themselves—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senators on my left will cease interjecting.

—The important point about the changes in the legislation is that the shift of the focus is from the service providers to the parents. A less prescriptive service provision system is being brought into place. There are a series of safety nets—Senator Jacinta Collins did not refer to that in her supplementary question—to ensure that families or children who require additional support are able to access the child care they require.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman. Minister, yesterday you tabled a report showing that the Howard government had dramatically increased efforts to stamp out fraud and non-compliance in social security. The report showed $28 million a week being saved with 330,000 payments being cancelled or reduced. What has been the community's reaction to this good news? Do all the groups in the community support our efforts to ensure welfare only goes to the deserving?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Calvert for his interest in this matter and for the opportunity to respond. I am pleased to report to the Senate that there has been a tremendous community reaction to the compliance report that I tabled yesterday. Already there has been a surge in tip‐offs to our teleservice centres this morning—calling the 132850 number—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senators on my left will cease interjecting.

—They are civic minded citizens who want the system to be as clean as possible and they have been ringing in all morning wanting to do their bit to help save taxpayers' funds and to protect those who are genuinely entitled to government support. The community supports our law enforcement efforts because they know what went before over the last 13 years. And does the Labor Party support our efforts? Do they even care about $28 million every week being saved for the taxpayer? It does not appear to be so.

BREAK.PARA: Before the last election we promised to fix the social security system and what was Labor's response? The then minister, Mr Baldwin said, `The savings the coalition pretends it can glean from the social security system do not exist.' That is what he said. Labor just would not admit there was a problem so they went on continuing to provide a hammock.
Now that we are saving $28 million a week in fraud and compliance, have they admitted they are wrong? No, they have not. The shadow minister, Jenny Macklin, said this morning:
This is a huge increase in activity for no returns.

I ask you: what does she mean `for no returns'? There has been a 27 per cent increase in reviews. Is that not a return? A 47 per cent increase in debts recovered. Is that no return? A 47 per cent increase, as well, in debts identified for collection through the year. Is that no return? How about a 23 per cent increase in public tip‐offs? Is that no return? That demonstrates that the public are serious. And how about the 32 per cent increase in referral to the DPP, which is going to show an increase in convictions during this year?

Ms Macklin obviously cannot read the annual report of the department where it is absolutely clear as clear that in the last year of Labor the number of referrals to the DPP dropped off—inevitably affecting the number of convictions in the last financial year. So you will see an increase in convictions, I am sad to say, in this financial year as a result of our 32 per cent extra effort.

And if Ms Macklin thinks that finding 330,000 people breaking the law is unimportant, is no return, it just goes to show that Labor is still not listening to Australians, not to taxpayers, not to families, not to the community. Our government does listen and it acts and, with $28 million a week being saved, it gets results. The difference is that Labor was not prepared to take the tough decisions; they were not prepared to deal with mismanagement and inadequate administration. They are cynical opportunists; they do not believe in good governance.

That has been the response since the report was tabled yesterday. It contrasts with the reaction that the British government has made to these issues. They have introduced a tip‐off line which has had one‐quarter of a million people respond to it in the last year. They are keen to do better because they see it as the responsibility of a citizen to report breaches of the law wherever they occur. It is very important that we recognise in Australia that this is not antisocial; it is a civic responsibility for all of us—government and the people—to uphold the law. In England they are toughening up the system enormously. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. Minister, you would be aware of the non-stop lobbying of the opposition regarding the problems that have arisen from your government's cuts to the Abstudy budget in May this year. As you may also be aware, it has been predicted that the cuts at premier institutions for Aboriginal education such as Batchelor College in the Northern Territory would result in enrolments falling by some 80 per cent at that college, student load targets not being met and the funding base of the college collapsing. Given that your predecessor, Senator Vanstone, gave assurances to this Senate in question time in August that no harm would be brought to bear on colleges such as Batchelor as a result of these changes, can you inform the Senate whether the government has made a decision on this issue? The reason it is now pressing is that colleges such as Batchelor are now in the middle of recruitment for next year and the current inaction and silence by the government is absolutely ruining their chances of having a reasonable academic year next year. In relation to the assurances that have been given by Senator Vanstone, when will the government make a statement? (Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I might just remind the Senate that this government has committed an additional $80 million to the year 2000 to the indigenous education strategic initiatives program. I think that is worth remembering. At the moment we are conducting a review in relation to Abstudy. We are also considering the matters raised with Dr Kemp by the vice-chancellors the other day. An announcement on that is imminent. That relates to the 13 budget measures announced this year.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to Batchelor College, I can tell Senator Collins that that matter is under review. But I think you should remember that we have committed $72 million to indigenous higher education and $6.2 million per annum to English as a second language for indigenous children. This government is doing something about indigenous education. You are totally wrong in saying that we are doing nothing about Abstudy. There is a review in place, and that will take into account all aspects of Abstudy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I advise the minister that I said nothing of the sort. I did not say that you were doing anything about Aboriginal education. Minister, it is now almost November. The cuts to the Abstudy travel component, as you well know, will cut the enrolment of this college by about 80 per cent. The college is now in the process of recruiting its staff. The matter is urgent. When will you advise the college about what you are going to do to fix the problem?
—As I said before, this matter is in hand and the government is having a close look at it.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALKER.NAME: Senator PARER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday in question time Senator West asked me a question with regard to the training of Customs staff to police the diesel fuel excise avoidance matters and at the same time the advertising for outside auditors to carry out similar work. I indicated to Senator West that I would refer the matter to the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs. The minister has provided a response to Senator West's questions. I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The response read as follows—
Yesterday, Senator West asked me the following question without notice during Question Time:

"is it true that there has been an extensive training campaign amongst staff, including 100 or so from New South Wales, to detect the diesel fuel excise avoidance? I am advised that the Customs Service did advertise on 22 August from outside auditors to carry out this work. Why is it going to outside auditors when it has already trained up a significant number of its staff to undertake the same exercise?"
In response, I indicated that I would refer the matter to the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs.
The Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs has provided the following response in relation to Senator West's question.

The Government, in the 1996-97 Budget, announced its intention to revamp the operation of the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme (DFRS) to improve accountability and administration, and clamp down on misuse of Scheme.
Legislation giving effect to that commitment, the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Act (No 1) 1997, was passed by the Parliament earlier this year and will come into effect on 1 January 1998.
The main changes to come into effect on 1 January 1998 are:

PARA.TAB: provisions to support claimant self-assessment;
clear obligation on claimants to retain and create records which will substantiate rebate claims;
revised audit powers for Customs;
new penalty provisions; and
measures for Customs to obtain information from claimants about their operations.

SPEECH.PARA: These provisions will not change the current entitlement of all claimants to claim rebate before they actually use the fuel.

Customs is training officers who administer the DFRS concerning the changes to the Scheme. This includes training in compliance audit techniques as well as client management, processing of claims and eligibility criteria.

The Commercial Compliance activities within Customs have recently undergone a series of major reforms and Customs has adopted auditing standards which require staff with a high level of audit competence. These reforms are based on the recommendations of an Industry Panel which was established in 1994 and reported to Government in February 1995. Implementation of the recommendations from the Panel Report entitled "Looking to the Future—Compliance Improvement" has been a major priority for the Customs Service over the past two years.

The recruitment program to which the Senator referred is designed to complement existing Customs resources responsible for auditing a range of Commercial activities including imports, exports, excise, diesel fuel and other industry assistance schemes.

Customs is taking a dual approach to the achievement and maintenance of audit competence within the organisation the recruitment of qualified auditors and the training of existing staff through a recently established tertiary accredited education program. The recruitment campaign is in line with recommendation 11 of the recent Australian National Audit Office Report, "Risk Management in Commercial Compliance", which recognised the sound progress made by Customs in this area of its activities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator West asked me a question on 20 October in relation to aged care. I have received a response from the minister. I seek leave to incorporate that in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

BREAK.PARA: SENATOR WEST asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 20 October 1997: What is going to be the impact upon often middle-aged children if they move into their parents' home to care for a frail aged parent? They may well continue to work and hold down a full-time job, but they will continue to work and hold down a fulltime job, but they will still be able to keep their frail aged parent out of a nursing home for a number of years, but less than five years. I wanted the Minister to look at the impact on those middle-aged children. Has the Government chosen the time period of five years deliberately because it has evidence that most carers who do this crucial work, do it for less than this time period before their parents become too frail for them to stay at home?
SENATOR HERRON—The Minister for Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

This Government recognises the invaluable work of carers, whether or not they are in employment and whether or not they are living with the person they are caring for. We acknowledge that, however long they care for, and whatever other commitments they may have, this is a difficult and emotionally demanding job and one that deserves our acknowledgment and support.

In response to community concerns about the protections for the family home, the Government announced on 27 October that the home would not be counted as an asset for accommodation bond purposes where a carer who was eligible for a pension or benefit had lived there for at least two years, not five years as currently stated in the Aged Care Act 1997. This improved protection for carers will be made effective from the commencement of the new arrangements on 1 October 1997.

The protections of the family home in the Aged Care Act were developed in consultation with consumer and industry groups, including the Carers' Association. The five year protection was agreed after discussion by the Funding and other Implementation Issues Working Group, including a representative of the Carers' Association, and was accepted by the Government.

The view was that this protection should be restricted to people who had been living in the home on a long term basis, who had no significant means of support other than their pensions, and who would face genuine hardship if they had to leave the home.

While automatic exemptions are provided under these circumstances, it is also open to people to apply under the hardship provisions if they or their family would face genuine hardship in paying a bond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston), to a question without notice asked by Senator Lundy today, relating to restrictions on parallel importation of compact discs.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Alston is completely oblivious to the damage that will be caused to the Australian record industry if parallel importing is permitted. This government's total disregard for the thousands of jobs that will be jeopardised by parallel importing further demonstrates their lack of concern for jobs, job security and small business.

Senator Alston's ludicrous assertion that CDs are cheaper in New Zealand and the United States ignores the fact that the US has lower sales tax and lower regulatory rates for artists and composers. New Zealand does not have a strong record industry like Australia's, and in fact most of their major artists come here because our record industry offers them some protection and security. There is no real investment in local talent in New Zealand, their taxation system is different and they have lower advertising rates, which impacts upon the cost of CDs.

Senator Alston's bungled efforts in this matter are highlighted by the fact that neither the United States nor New Zealand allow parallel importing. In fact, as far as I am aware, no OECD country allows parallel importing. The basic fact is that, if parallel importing is to be allowed, then Australian artists will be worse off. Japan, which is probably one example that we could argue does allow parallel importing, does so at a higher retail price than Australia.

BREAK.PARA: How does Senator Alston propose to ensure that any potential drop in the wholesale price of CDs will be passed on to consumers? Already one leading Australian company, Shock Records, have pointed out that, although their recommended retail price is $27.95, their products are often sold for $30. In other words, Minister, your government cannot guarantee that retailers will pass on any savings to consumers. Your proposals will do absolutely nothing to benefit Australian consumers and instead will destabilise a vital industry for the sake of a possible saving of $1.60.

I cannot believe that Senator Alston actually buys CDs. If he bothered to visit a few local retailers here in Canberra—we could certainly do with a few more Liberal dollars spent locally—he might discover that most department or chain stores offer between $3 and $7 off the recommended retail price. Parallel importing, which will place at risk thousands of jobs, will not improve the current state of record prices.

But the major concern to Australian small businesses is the risk to jobs and job security resulting from the proposed changes. Approximately 95 per cent of recordings currently sold in Australia are locally manufactured, and the job security of thousands of people presently employed in this thriving local industry will be placed at risk.

Senator Alston is also content to place at risk hundreds of jobs in the freight industry. CD distribution is one of the biggest users of freight in Australia, and job security in the freight industry will be at risk if parallel importing is allowed.

I question whether Senator Alston is genuinely committed to maintaining a vibrant and world renowned music industry. If the minister has his way, artists like Savage Garden, You Am I, Hoodoo Gurus and countless others would not exist. Yet again Senator Alston demonstrates complete insensitivity and a total lack of understanding of the implications that parallel importing will have on Australian jobs and Australian culture.

I am gravely concerned that the minister, who is also responsible for all matters relating to intellectual property in the area of new media, is taking this position with respect to parallel importing, with its impact on copyright and neighbouring rights. This is of major concern and has no doubt contributed to the lack of confidence that this sector has in Senator Alston as the minister for these matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran, Sen Julian

TALK.START.PARA: —The government rejects Senator Lundy's claims that the decision in regard to parallel importing will, firstly, have any effect at all on employment. It can be equally argued the other way. In fact, it will increase employment. Senator Lundy also made the spurious claim that it would affect the freight industry. Again, we reject that. Quite frankly, we expect that more CDs will come into the country because of this decision and therefore more CDs will be carried by freight. It was a spurious claim because with more CDs coming into the country the freight industry, quite logically, will be advantaged.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Lundy also quoted Shock Records. I have received letters from Shock Records, and I also recall reading in the Australian their chief executive saying that CD prices will come down. Consumers will benefit from this. The decision, as tough as it is and as difficult as it was to make, is in line with this government's reform program. We know we are up against a very strong and powerful lobby. We know that the previous government buckled under that strong and powerful lobby, but this government has its eye on a reform program and was not going to buckle under the very strong and powerful Australian music lobby.
We considered the arguments. Some good arguments were put forward by the Australian music industry, but on balance we have made this decision in regard to parallel importing.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is really a wet lettuce defence of the government's position.

—Senator Schacht, I wait for you to jump on this matter. How do you explain that the five major record distributors in this country are all international companies? They basically have a—I will not use the word `cartel'—dominance over the market and they are all foreign owned companies. I challenge you to answer that anomaly in your argument.
—Put a reference to the ACCC.

—Senator Schacht, you will get a chance to answer that, and I ask you take it. I have also been strongly lobbied by many of the record shops in regional areas, in which I take great interest. There are many record shops within regional Victoria and Australia that have approached me asking the government not to make this decision. But, once explained to them, they can see that with a greater choice for the consumer surely the turnover will increase.

SPEECH.PARA: It is logical economic sense. The economics is there. The benefit to the consumer is there. The choice is there. All you are attempting to do is to protect five foreign-owned record distributing companies in Australia. That is the key to this argument. That is what I challenge you to answer. You are protecting a group of five, a monopolistic—

TALK.START.PARA: —An oligopoly.

—More than an oligopoly; an oligopoly is two. I do not know what five is called. They are a close-knit group that weigh heavily on the industry. We are going to bring greater competition to the industry, greater choice to the consumers and, unquestionably, a reduction in the prices of CDs.

SPEECH.PARA: Thank you for warming me up on this issue. I needed a bit of cranking up. Now I am absolutely off and running. You would not make the hard decision. We all saw former Minister Lee dancing on the stage out the front with John Farnham and others when they were lobbying here. He was buckling under the pressure. He probably got a few free tickets to his latest concert. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Lundy's motion to take note of the dreadful answer that the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) gave to her question today. Senator McGauran has just given the most hilarious defence I have ever heard in any area of government policy. As it came from the National Party, it should not surprise one. SPEECH.PARA: Earlier this month we pointed out that Senator Alston clearly gave misleading information to the Senate about the price discrepancy between the price of a CD in Australia and the price of the same CD in New Zealand. Senator Lundy's question clearly pointed out that the information he gave in his answer on 20 October was clearly misleading. When Senator Alston was exposed on this, what was his defence? He said, `Oh, well, inquiries were made.' He did not say that he had made the inquiries himself. He left the potential there to blame someone else. As is usual with this minister, whenever he is caught out he always blames somebody else.

He blithely said, `I didn't see the question. One of my staff or department wrote that. They didn't clear it with me. I have no responsibility.' It was lodged here as an answer to a question on notice in his name. He blamed the staff again.

Another document that was leaked from his own department was about funding in the ABC and the fact that it was contrary to his policy document Better communications. What did he do? He said, `I didn't see the cabinet submission. It wasn't my cover note. It is all the department's fault.' Even a submission that he had lodged under his name in the cabinet room was not his fault—he had not seen it; he blamed the department.

He made poor old Neville Stevens take 100 per cent of the blame at the estimates committee. The incompetent minister did not see what was going on. If that was the truth, he made Neville Stevens take the fall for it.

An article written by Ann Davies earlier this year, on 26 February, about cross-ownership rules was embarrassing to the minister. He immediately said, `I was misquoted.' He never took the trouble to put a writ or write a letter to the Sydney Morning Herald saying that it was wrong. An article appeared earlier this week, again by Ann Davies, which talked about a whole number of policy issues that the minister has deferred till next year, telling representatives of the media industry that they would not be dealt with. He again blamed somebody else. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Schacht never ceases to amaze me. As shadow minister for communications, in opposition to Senator Alston, he flails around at every single opportunity just to try to restore some of his flagging credibility in the Labor Party. There was a chance that Senator Schacht might have moved up two or three seats, not just one. SPEECH.PARA: Senator Lundy raised the issue of the parallel importing of CDs. She knows that the continuation of the existing arrangements helps the multinationals outside of Australia. —Madam Deputy President, I am returning to the issue, but when you walk past Senator Carr's office, if you are down a few blocks, you can sometimes hear the conversations.

—If he could improve the soundproofing in his office, there would be some chance that we would not be able to hear those conversations three or four offices down the corridor.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Carr interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Carr, there is not much else that we need to know about your activities in Victoria.
—Senator Ferguson, I am more interested in the parallel importing of CDs.

—Madam Deputy President, I was about as close to the parallel importing of CDs at that stage as Senator Schacht was in his previous speech when he talked about a totally different matter that occurred before an estimates committee. I think if you are going to be consistent in your rulings you should allow people to range far and wide on the taking note of this particular answer. BREAK.PARA: The conclusions and recommendations of the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee with respect to the Copyright Amendment Bill 1997 —
Senator Murphy interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You should listen to the recommendations of that committee, which state:

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee . . . having carefully assessed all the evidence, considers that it is inappropriate to use copyright as a vehicle to restrict the parallel importation of products.

BREAK.PARA: I think that sends a clear message. It would do Senator Lundy well to take note of that committee report when she tries to stand up and defend the current situation with regard to parallel importing as it relates to CDs for the benefit of the Australian community.

Not only should we be looking at what has happened to the industry; we should be looking at what has happened to the consumers of CDs. The Labor Party would do well to remember that only a couple of years ago they very nearly did away with parallel importing themselves. They could not quite bring themselves to the brink of making that major decision, which would have removed the parallel importing and the monopoly that currently exists within that industry. We hear only of the protestations of some well‐to‐do people within the music industry who want to protect their special provisions and the privileges they have at present.

Those opposite should also take note that a number of people in the music industry think that the removal of the restrictions on CD importing which we have in place at present could only help the industry in the long term. It will help not only the musicians in the industry and those working within the industry but also consumers. We have a responsibility as a government to make sure that all people involved in this particular decision get a fair decision.
