SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —It is important that we bring to the attention of the Senate the fact that Senator Alston—who was to be the shining star of the government but who has fallen a long way from there—came into the Senate and stated what he said were facts with regard to the prices of CDs in New Zealand. The truth is that he was totally incorrect. I will read a couple of paragraphs from a letter written by Geoff Sherning, the Finance Director of Warner Music, New Zealand, to Gary Smerdon, the Finance Director of Warner Music, Australia. It goes to the very point that was raised with regard to the question of Savage Garden CDs. The letter states in part:

PARA.EMPHASIS: As the only wholesaler licensed to distribute this title in New Zealand in the marketplace, we can confirm that all CD units have been sold at the PPD of $NZ19.65. This is a fact; we can be audited and is therefore beyond challenge. We are staggered that the assertion has been that this product is predominantly retailing at $NZ18.80. To further clarify how absurd this assertion is we have today confirmed with our top key retailers the current retail prices of which they are selling Savage Garden. The sample is representative of six to five per cent of our total business.

SPEECH.PARA: It then lists the prices at which CDs are sold at a number of stores: warehouses, $26.99; sound stores, $34.95; True Tone stores, $33.95; ECM stores, $33.95; Marbecks stores, $33.99; CD stores, $33.95; and compact disk shops, $29.95.

We know that people would like to have cheaper CDs; we all would. But the reality is that some of the assertions being made by the minister are totally incorrect. In considering the whole issue, as we did on a number of occasions when we were in government, we took account of the jobs that are dependant on this industry. I am referring not only to direct jobs but also to jobs across the board in areas such as transport, et cetera.

If you take account of this claim about delivering cheaper CDs, you come down to how those sales are made up in terms of the sales in retail shops. Top 40 music probably makes up about 80 per cent of their sales. The other 60 varieties of music, if you like, out of 100 will make up 20 per cent of their sales. If you bring about a position where there is parallel importing—and the competition in the existing music industry in Australia is such that they will have to cut their costs and finetune the manufacturing process such that you will get a restriction with regard to choice—you will not get lower prices.

When you get pirated CDs coming into the marketplace, the fact is that the music retailers that are selling top 40 music will set the price. All the CDs that are supposed to be cheaper will be brought up to that price level. It is simply not true to say that there will be a reduction in price. That has occurred in other countries. I think it was in Sweden or Norway where they introduced parallel importing and then got rid of it after 10 years. That is why, for Senator Ferguson's benefit, we never took a decision to introduce parallel importing, and rightly so. It is important that we do protect the jobs in the music industry. For the development of our own musicians in this country, we must maintain a set of circumstances where we do foster them, protect the jobs and ensure that it runs more efficiently. There is nothing wrong with that. In so far as competition is concerned, I know that all retailers and indeed people within the music industry are more than prepared to accept competition. But you will have no control over CDs if you introduce parallel importing. As to the proposal that the minister put, he ought to come in here and apologise to the Senate for misleading it with regard to the prices that he stated, because they were clearly not true. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp), to a question without notice asked by Senator Murray today, relating to the operation of financial markets.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the question is timely, particularly in relation to the fall in stock markets at the present time. It does give rise to an interesting question that I think everybody should be debating much more extensively in this country about investing in markets for retirement income purposes and comparing such an investment with a return from a government's social security system. I draw Senators' attention to a recent book entitled Promises to Keep—Saving Social Security's Dream by Americans from State Street Bank and Trust Co., Marshall N. Carter and William G. Shipman. One of these gentlemen is currently in Australia and I understand he will be addressing the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia conference tomorrow, if he has not already done so.

Senator Murray's question was based on Will Hutton's Age newspaper article on markets. My contribution is not to comment on the article but to use the market linkage to look at the efficiency of market investments for retirement. If one looks at moneys invested over a long period of time, such as 30 to 40 years—and this is the period in which we have to set aside money for retirement income purposes—you see that income derived from the market, such as investments on the Stock Exchange, produce a much more efficient and higher return than that which can be derived through most social security systems.

The problems in most Western societies are that people are living longer. On the other hand, most of these countries are not getting the big increases in population because of declining birth numbers and, particularly in Australia, there is fairly static migration.
In the short term, governments can overcome retirement financing problems by reducing social security benefits for aged care on the one hand or, on the other, by increasing

taxes. Unfortunately, there is no end over time to which the taxes have to rise in order to meet an ageing population's retirement needs. In our society we are finding increasingly a reluctance, particularly from the young, to both meet their own retirement income needs and provide the funds for the retired out of current taxation. In addition, we are living in a part of the world—the Asian region—which has low taxes on income. So in Australia we want low taxes but, at the same time, we expect social security benefits equal to the Swedish type models.

Governments around the world are finding increasing difficulty in meeting their government retirement pensions. However, in the long term we have to look very clearly at investment in markets to generate the necessary retirement funds. Australia is in a transition. At the present time government meets 80 per cent of retirement pension needs. Under SIS, Australia will have a nine per cent levy on employers by the year 2002 to meet the SGC, but for most Australians this mechanism will not be sufficient. Australia will have to provide vehicles or incentives where people are compelled to lock away additional moneys such as through markets for their retirement to ensure that they are going to get an above return compared with what could be provided through a government pension system.

To achieve such an outcome governments must be cognisant of the fact that they must keep the tax rates relatively low on savings income for retirement purposes. The acknowledged maximum figure around the world is about 30 per cent. Regrettably, in Australia we have taxes on entry, taxes on earnings and taxes on exits.

However, in the last few minutes remaining to me, I must state one essential feature. One must start investing early and establish a continuous saving pattern. This will enable the benefits of compounding to grow the investment significantly. Compounding has a very magical influence. At an eight per cent return over 10 years the investment doubles. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate notes, with grave concern:
(a) the inability of the Howard Government to deal with unemployment, particularly long-term unemployment,
(b) the absolute disregard that this Government shows for those who are unemployed, evident by:

PARA.TAB: (i) cuts to vital funding for vocational education and training and labour market programs,
(ii) the institution of industrial relations reforms that have increased job insecurity, and
(iii) massive public sector job cuts; and

SPEECH.PARA: (c) that, as a result, the Howard Government has only managed 1 per cent employment growth in the past 12 months, highlighting its failure to fully explore creative and practical solutions to the unemployment crisis.

Before I get into the substance of my comments, I would like to make some observations with regard to the contribution of Senator Ellison today in question time. I must say that I thought it was a fairly pathetic performance. I did notice that his performance per se has improved, but the content has not improved.

I am interested in Senator Ellison's reference to the MTIA. I have—as I am sure he has—read the MTIA Make or break report. In particular, I am quite interested that you regard that as a big tick for the government when, in fact, the report is quite scathing about this government with regard to its lack of industry policy.

Interestingly, when the Treasurer, Mr Costello, addressed the MTIA dinner—and Senator Ellison himself referred to the seven‐point plan the MTIA has—Mr Costello did not get past the second point. He got to point 1 and then he got to point 2, but he did not get past the second point. He raved on and on about getting the fundamentals right, getting low inflation right, getting interest rate cuts, and so on. `Hang on there, folks, the whole thing's going to change, just hang on there and be patient'—as I think one minister said—`be patient, it will happen.'

With regard to Senator Ellison's contribution at question time, the reality is that he was asked a very specific question and that is: what is the growth target of this government? That question was not answered. It has been asked a number of times in this chamber and it has never been answered. I have an answer for Senator Ellison. Your growth target is four per cent. How do I know this? Because the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) himself set that as a growth target in one of his headland speeches prior to the last election. He said—and I can remember it vividly—that no government can hope to make a real dent in unemployment unless the growth rate exceeds four per cent.

At the end of the last financial year we ended up with a growth rate of 2.5 per cent. At the moment, depending on who you believe and which set of statistics you look at, the best possible construction you can put on the current growth rate is about 3.25 per cent. That is nowhere near four per cent. The Prime Minister has failed on his own benchmark.

Let us have a look at the record of this government with regard to unemployment. I say again—as I have said in this chamber many times—when this government came to office unemployment was at 8.4 per cent. What is it now? Unemployment is currently running, as everybody knows, at 8.6 per cent. In fact, not only has this government failed to deliver specific initiatives to combat what is Australia's greatest problem, but they have sent the whole show backwards. We are going backwards.

Yet again in this chamber I commend the previous employment minister, the Minister for Justice, Senator Vanstone, for her candour when she said that if this particular government does not get unemployment below eight per cent it does not deserve to get re‐elected. My view is that it does not deserve to get re‐elected on a whole series of fronts, but she has also set a benchmark. So we have two benchmarks: one set by the Prime Minister that the growth rate must be four per cent; and another one set by the previous employment minister, Senator Vanstone, that this government has to get unemployment below eight per cent or this government will not get elected. They are your benchmarks and they are the answers to the questions that Senator Ellison could not answer today.

Whilst I am on this subject, I would like to address some of the points raised in a recent Sydney Morning Herald article that the Democrats have made much of. They asserted that 3.3 million jobs have been lost over the last decade. That is completely wrong. The Democrats have taken that figure from the Sydney Morning Herald article on Monday, 20 October which reported that there had been 3.3 million full‐time retrenchments between 1986 and 1997 and interpreted this as being the figure for net jobs lost.

You do not have to be Einstein to work out that there is a difference between loss of full‐time jobs and retrenchments. The reality is that there were in fact three million full‐time retrenchments in the decade to 1996. They were actually offset—and this is the way it works—by the creation of many more jobs. People get retrenched, they move out of the work force, more jobs are created and people move into the new jobs. That is the way it works. It is pretty simple. As I said, you do not have to be Einstein to work that one out.

The reality is that over the period of the Hawke and Keating governments two million net jobs were created. What has happened—and even this government understands it and the MTIA certainly does—is that there has been a shift of jobs from manufacturing to services as part of a worldwide structural economic transition and adjustment. The Democrats are clearly, in my view, unaware that there can be a shift in the composition of employment without an overall fall in numbers. That is pretty simple to understand.

I would like to put on the record here that we regard it as absolutely offensive that the Democrats lump us in with that lot on the other side in terms of job creation. I might say that, if this is the Democrats' position with regard to the middle ground, they are going to fall right through the hole in the middle ground. They are not going to capture the middle ground.

The problem of unemployment today is that the Howard government, unlike the previous Labor government, has absolutely retreated from a role of managing and shaping economic change. Let us cast our minds back to when we came into government in 1983. In 1983 unemployment was at 10 per cent. It was at 10 per cent because the Howard‐Fraser government's entire job strategy in terms of decreasing unemployment was getting infla tion down. Does it sound familiar? That was the big strategy—to get inflation down and everything else will follow.

Unfortunately, that is not the way the world works. The number of jobs throughout the 1980s grew steadily. There was an economic boom in the 1980s. In Australia jobs growth was higher than any other OECD country mainly because the previous Labor government actually decided to do something about the job situation.

There were a whole series of initiatives by Labor. This is why I find the Democrats lumping us in with the government a bit offensive. There were stacks of things that the government did. For example, there was the community employment program which was allocated $300 million to fund 70,000 full‐time jobs averaging six months each on labour intensive projects of social and economic benefit to the community. There was also the subsidised work study traineeships for young people arising out of the Kirby report and in 1989 the official unemployment rate fell below six per cent.

There was a recession in the early 1990s. It just did not happen here. There was a worldwide recession in the 1990s and obviously unemployment rose very sharply at that point. Labor acted very quickly, unlike this government, which simply attends to what it regards as the economic fundamentals, which do not seem to include growth or setting an actual jobs target.

Then we had the expansionary job creation policies of infrastructure spending in One Nation in February 1992. We acted very quickly. Then we had Working Nation, which was introduced in May 1994 and we aimed to reduce the unemployment rate to five per cent by the year 2000. We put it on the record. We said that we aimed to reduce unemployment to five per cent by the year 2000. This government has not had the intestinal fortitude to make even any kind of statement. All they talk about is budget forecasts. We want to know what your jobs target is. We were prepared to put our money where our mouth was and put it on the record. You put it on the record.

BREAK.PARA: The Keating government introduced Working Nation and boosted spending on active labour market programs as a proportion of GDP from 0.27 per cent in 1990‐1991 to 0.73 per cent in 1994‐95, moving us from one of the lowest spending nations in the OECD with regard to this to being approximately in the middle—hardly what one would call profligate, hardly what the present government regards as a high spending, high taxing government.

As a result unemployment—especially long‐term unemployment—began to fall. Overall, 740,000 jobs were created in Labor's last term of office. However, there is no doubt that when we left office—and we do not resile from this fact—unemployment was still too high, at 8.4 per cent. We think it is absolutely appalling that after 18 months of the coalition government it is 8.6 per cent. All you have done is increase unemployment. That is the reality.

Let us have a look at what this government's record is in terms of its so‐called `job creation strategy'. What do you do if you have an unemployment crisis if you are this government? You cut jobs. That is this government's solution to the unemployment crisis. Since this government was elected, 80,000 jobs have been cut out of the Commonwealth and state government sectors. When you cut that amount of jobs out of the public sector, you directly affect regional Australia. I know that very well in terms of my home state of Tasmania. If you cut the heart out of the public sector, it has a direct effect on the economy and on the amount of money circulating, not to mention on the people who lose their jobs and lose access to the services that people in regional Australia lose access to. As well there are the social implications of unemployment.

The dries over there would at least concede that when you cut that number of jobs out of an economy it impacts disproportionately on the regions and means there is less money going around the regions. Go no further than asking the Premier of Tasmania, Tony Rundle, to confirm what I have just said. Go no further than asking the Tasmanian Department of Development and Resources to confirm what I have just said.

After falling every month for 32 consecutive months under Labor, the number of long‐term unemployed has jumped by 58,500 since May 1996, due to this government freezing, cutting and then abolishing numerous successful Working Nation programs. Again, my state of Tasmania has been particularly badly affected. We lost $40 million to $50 million over three years as a result of the cuts to Working Nation. That initiative has not been well received in my home state of Tasmania—and this government has not been well received there either. I am quite confident of an increase in seats for Labor in the next election.

As I said before, unemployment has actually gone up to 8.6 per cent, despite a big drop of half a percentage point in the participation rate, as many people give up hope and drop right out of the labour market. I am not going into the fairly simple arithmetic of drops in the participation rate and drops in the labour force and how that affects the unemployment rate. That is a complex argument for the government to understand, but it is evident to most of us that there is a clear nexus—a clear connection.

What did this government do? As I said, they cut jobs out of the public sector. They cut 22,000 workers out of Telstra, they abolished a whole series of innovative and strategic interventionist—to use the new phrase that the Prime Minister (John Howard) is using—industry programs. Although Mr Howard talks a lot about strategic intervention, we have not seen much of it.

The government abolished DIFF and slashed EMDG and support for research and development. If you go around and talk to small to medium enterprises about the impact this has had, it is disastrous. Here we have a situation where we are attempting to get into export markets, and what this government does is slash the very programs that SMEs require in order to get into those export markets.

Senator Calvert is here, and I am sure he is aware—although I appreciate that he will not be able to say this—that that is precisely what Tasmanian businesses are saying. On the Senate Economics References Committee we did the round of Tasmanian businesses to talk about industry policy, and that is what they were saying. Businesses everywhere are saying, `We needed those programs and we want them back.'

What else did this government do? It dismantled the employment service—bungle! Senator Vanstone could not get her own way, so she pulled the bill. I would be interested to know whether Senator Ellison could tell us how the government's new employment services regime is going to be instituted without legislation. How is that going to happen?

We are much more pro‐active. We believe unemployment is a high priority. We would generate economic growth at annual rates better than four per cent, as we did before, in order to make serious inroads into unemployment. Labor will support Australian industry through intervention and strategic assistance. We have the runs on the board there. We will tackle the high concentrations of unemployment in regional areas through the creation of public sector programs to deliver where they are most needed. We have a genuine strategy. We have put our cards on the table in terms of what we want to do. We would like this government to put its cards on the table.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on this general business motion moved by Senator Mackay. The overall thrust of the motion cites the inability of the government to deal with unemployment, particularly long‐term unemployment. I will lead off on Senator Mackay's last point.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Mackay was saying what the Labor Party would do for regional Australia. She said they would be creating public works programs. What a turnaround on 13 years of Labor policy this is. Labor totally neglected regional Australia. If you look at the capital works programs of the previous Labor government, over 13 years the graph declines drastically. They chopped it in half over that time. So to come in here and say as your final point, `We are going to increase public works programs,' is humbug. You had 13 years to do it. You did not do it and, if you ever get back into government, you will not do it either.

BREAK.PARA: Let me focus on the record of the Labor government. Labor senators come in here and criticise the current government, but it has only been 18 months since they left government, and we remember very clearly their record on unemployment over that time. There was a massive increase in long‐term unemployment—which is the focus of this motion—over the last 10 years. That largely resulted from the failed policies—such as the so‐called Working Nation program—of the previous government.

One‐third of the total number of unemployed became long‐term unemployed under their government—a disgraceful record. If you look at the total figures of unemployment over that time, you will find that Labor's average was 8.5 per cent—over 13 years. That is the best a so‐called Labor government could do. What a total disgrace. We all remember when they pushed it to the highest point of all in the recession we had to have, according to Mr Keating. It got up to 11.2 per cent because of the previous Labor government's total inability to handle the economy of this country. They sent the economy into a boom and then brought it to a bust with a shuddering halt, with terrible ramifications for the people who are unemployed, particularly the long‐term unemployed.

It was not until Australia started to come out of that recession that they really started to try and come up with a serious program for dealing with it. So as they were heading into the next boom they were actually trying to grapple with the problems of the previous recession. It certainly was too little too late.

The Working Nation program was an absolutely hopeless failure, and I want to spend some time going into the reasons why it was a failure. There are a lot of lessons for government in the way in which they tried to tackle this problem and the enormous amount of money they wasted on very poor outcomes—very poor in an economic sense but even tragic in terms of the social and personal consequences of putting some people into jobs temporarily and then pulling them back out again when they were not able to get long‐term employment. The programs under Working Nation were expensive, they were very badly targeted and they achieved poor job outcomes. There was even a very devious attempt by the ALP to hide the real numbers of Australians whose lives were blighted by long‐term unemployment.

I now come to a more detailed critique of Labor's Working Nation, which so clearly failed the long‐term unemployed. In 1994 I chaired the Senate employment, education and training inquiry into long‐term unemployment. We held extensive hearings on this matter and gathered evidence from many parts of Australia. It revealed that long‐term unemployment was an absolutely desperate problem. What was particularly unfortunate about it was the nature of the groups that it targeted. Those who had been in disadvantaged groups before this problem reached the size that it did in society were affected, yet again, disproportionately. I refer particularly to the youth of this country, to older Australians, to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, to people who come from non‐English speaking backgrounds, and to people in regional Australia and the outer suburbs of the major cities.

The inquiry that we held highlighted three overall failings of this Working Nation program. First of all, it created a negative perception of training as a useless exercise to those people who were involved. They really could not see it leading anywhere and, for 70 per cent of them, it certainly did not. They were back in the unemployed—but not the long‐term unemployed. Because of the way Labor changed the definition, they were regarded as newly created unemployed people. The effect of all this was to artificially push down the long‐term unemployment rate according to official statistics. That was just a little bit of magic the Labor government created to try and make their record look better. In reality, it was not.

The second overall failing related to the churning of the unemployment queues that robbed the participants of hope when, at the end of training, there was no real job. The real problem with what Labor tried to do at that time is that they put people into training saying that that would make them job‐ready when the jobs came. But the jobs did not come and, because they did not link the sorts of training often to real job outcomes, the effect, tragically, for 70 per cent of the long‐term unemployed who were involved in the Working Nation programs was no jobs at all. So they were returned to the unemployed.

A closer examination of Working Nation underlines how it failed to deliver particular job outcomes. There were fewer people successful in the private sector wage subsidy program, for example. Labor's wage subsidy placements in 1994‐95, at the height of Working Nation, were actually 50 per cent below the targets. Instead, Labor increased the proportion of expensive programs with very poor job outcomes, such as the new work opportunities program. Each new wave job actually cost the taxpayer $143,000. The success rate was so poor that, when you averaged out what the program cost for each successful placement, it was $143,000. Obviously, they persisted with some very ineffective programs. In my own region, in northern New South Wales, they boosted the amount of money they poured into these programs just before the 1996 elections to make it appear that unemployment was dropping. These people had been redefined.

When they brought in Working Nation, the Labor government also created case management systems. The concept of case management is really quite good, but they applied it in a very unsatisfactory way. For a start, they did not have enough case managers. Also, there was, under their case management system, something which we have subsequently corrected: there was really no incentive to get clients into real jobs. Money spent on these programs was often wasted; for example, training people who could not swim or who had a chlorine allergy to be swimming instructors. That was one of the things they were doing. Money for programs was often redirected to advertising campaigns—flashy ads like those ones you saw with Bill Hunter in them—trying to make out to the public how successful this all was.

Just prior to the last election, Labor spent $860 million on three of the worst performing Working Nation programs in terms of outcomes. That is almost one billion dollars on three highly unsuccessful programs: new work opportunities, which I have mentioned before, LEAP and jobskills. This is a disgraceful outcome for a so‐called Labor government. Since the election, the Howard government has carried out what the people of Australia wanted—a shake‐up of these major programs. We have spent, in the time since we have been in government, in the 1996‐97 budget, $1.6 billion on labour market programs. That is about the same amount as Labor was spending on Working Nation before they lost government. But we have been spending it far more effectively.

Let me take the opposition through our efforts to make labour market assistance more effective for the unemployed than the programs they ran previously. We do not attempt to conceal the truth, as the Labor Party has done, on employment. Any Australian would be able to confirm to you that the labour market remains flat, but the figures in September have shown a very positive pick‐up, with 70,000 new jobs being created under the policies of this government. We are not talking about artificial jobs that are going to disappear in six months time; we are talking about real jobs that have a prospect of people holding on to them as time goes on. We have clearly indicated our compact with the Australian people to do something about unemployment.

Let me remind Senator Mackay and the Australian people what the Howard government has done in this job creation area. First of all, we have got the economic fundamentals in this country right. We have turned the federal budget into the black, which has great benefit to business and those that employ and create real jobs. We have turned around Labor's $10 billion deficit, restored the economic fundamentals so that Australia has the best economic outlook that it has had in a generation: the lowest interest rates since 1969 and the lowest inflation rate since 1962. This provides the conditions for small business, the economic generators, the business and job generators in this country, to create real jobs. As I outlined earlier, real job opportunities were never achieved under Working Nation.

Further, our government has acted almost immediately to free up the industrial relations system. The Workplace Relations Act has made significant changes that have actually removed barriers to business employing staff. The changes to ALP Minister Brereton's unfair dismissal laws have assisted a very large number of large and medium sized businesses. The opposition parties in the Senate are now incurring the wrath of small business in this country as they stand in the way of further unfair dismissal reform.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not been feeling any wrath.

—Well, you should, Senator Stott Despoja, talk to those people who are employing less than 15 people, where the unfair dismissal laws have not been removed because you have blocked them in this Senate. They say to us that that is the major brake on employing more people. Senator Stott Despoja, why are you trying to stop small businesses employing more people? That is precisely what you are doing. The major job generator is being stopped by a combination of the Greens, Labor and the Democrats in this country. So Labor, who created the problem for small business in creating jobs, are now exacerbating it, in cahoots with the Democrats and the Greens. That is continuing and will continue unless these parties change their minds and turn this around.

BREAK.PARA: Let me canvass for the opposition a range of other initiatives that are now in place under this government to deal with job creation. Labor decimated the apprenticeship system in this country. In their last year there were 60,000 people in apprenticeships, and under this government there are 200,000 new apprenticeships being created. We have created the common youth allowance to focus youth on the vital links between training and unemployment. The work for the dole program will ensure that long‐term unemployed are relinked to work opportunities and training. We are reforming labour market programs in this country so that they will be more effective. We are still continuing the spending at the same level, but we are making it far more effective than before. Labor's demonstrated record of failure over 13 years has been now overturned and this government, by getting the economic fundamentals right and by getting the job programs on track, will turn this around.
Debate (on motion by Senator Ian Campbell) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Quirke, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —It is incumbent on me to officially welcome new Senator Bartlett. As I just said to him a moment ago, I am very pleased he has come because that means I am no longer the new kid on the block. I wish him well and I am sure he will have a good, happy time here and, one would hope, a productive time. I am sure that all senators who will follow me in this or in other debates will extend to Senator Bartlett all the courtesies that were extended to me by honourable senators only a few weeks ago. I trust his time here will be very profitable.

SPEECH.PARA: The debate that we have here this afternoon is a rather interesting one. The government senator who took up this issue a moment ago was talking about the training programs of the last government. I do not really want to get too much into that sort of stuff because I think, in essence, what happened in the Hawke‐Keating years was an honest attempt—and in large part a successful attempt—to up‐skill the work force in Australia for what was obviously going to be the most important restructuring of employment and the nature of employment in this country that we have seen in the last 20 years.

BREAK.PARA: However, as the government wants to go back to other times, I will do that very quickly. I well remember what happened in 1982, in the dying days of the Fraser‐Howard government, when the Prime Minister at that time decided he wanted to have an early election. What he did was to bring in a budget that he knew was only going to last a few months. In fact, in the last couple of months of 1982 and early in 1983 we had double‐digit unemployment. Indeed, we got there at a very fast rate. I must say that the other thing we had was almost 11 per cent inflation. If the government senators want to start talking about some of the record on this, they need to get that part of the record straight.

We inherited in 1983 a dollar with the skids well and truly underneath it. There was a massive depreciation of the currency throughout the course of 1982 and into 1983. The coalition could not, under Mr Howard, make a hard decision. That hard decision was to float the dollar so that it could find its proper level. But the policies that were put in place were only there temporarily so that Mr Fraser could have a poll at the end of 1982. Those plans did not work, and in 1983 a 13‐year period of Labor government started.

During that period of Labor government we saw unemployment come down quite substantially. We also saw for the first time ever surplus budgets in this country. We had been promised surplus budgets before but they were never delivered. With the great surpluses at the end of 1988, with the back of inflation broken, with unemployment coming well and truly down, with the participation rate going up—during the Fraser years there were large numbers of people who would have loved to have joined the work force but they gave up any hope of getting a job—with those indices right, the Hawke‐Keating years saw a greater participation rate than had taken place before.
This afternoon Senator Tierney told us a little bit about some of the Working Nation training programs.

TALK.START.PARA: —He didn't tell us that Senator Vanstone was sacked.

—As Senator Faulkner just said, he did not mention Senator Vanstone. I was actually waiting to find out about the ship that was going to get painted. I was waiting to find out about the two million bucks that went over the side on that particular exercise. You know what? I heard nothing about it at all; he was absolutely silent.

BREAK.PARA: For government senators to come in here to try to rewrite history over that 13‐year period—and in particular where the governments of the time had to deal with the fact that we needed to educate and train our work force for the new industries that were developing in this country, and they did so, and they did so well—really belies the fact that the conservatives in this country have ever understood what labour market reform is all about. The only thing they understand in that is to drive down wages so that they can get cheaper employment for the likes of Mr Moran and the others who put into their coffers at election time.

I would be remiss here today if I did not say that last week I had hoped to get up and have a few words about the original motion that triggered this one. When the Democrats came in here last week they put up a motion which said that we were all as bad as each other; that, in fact, the Liberal government now is hopeless—I agreed with that; at least half of the motion was pretty good—and the Labor Party was not much better. I do not mind a bit of product differentiation if that is what they are about but, at the end of the day, as I said last week before I was gabbled up by all the government senators, as incompetent as this present bunch are, as incompetent as some of their ministers are, I think a few of them are trying to do something about the problem. Leastwise, some of their policies are not really quite as bad as a few I have seen, from time to time, floating around the electorate from those people who will probably never have control of the leavers which determine these particular questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tough call—it is marginal.

—Senator Faulkner says that it is marginal, but I have had a long experience with the Democrats in South Australia. The first great experience I had with them was in the Kingston campaign in 1990. The then member for Kingston, Gordon Bilney, played what was described as one of the `foulest and dirtiest tricks in Australian politics'. He circulated the Democrat election platform to all of the constituents in Kingston and said, `If you vote for Janine Haines this is what you are going to get.' He highlighted a few points in the platform, like, tax on the family home and a few things like that. Do you know what happened? The voters deserted them in droves. We have only seen Janine Haines once or twice since that time but at the end of the day I do not think we have missed too much.

BREAK.PARA: On a couple of other occasions, particularly in recent times in South Australia, I have had dealings with the Democrats. I have not had a lot of experience with the Democrats up here but I have certainly had a lot with the three that are in the Legislative Council in South Australia. One of their programs was to do everything they could to end gaming machines in South Australia. That is one of the things I was involved in as a shadow minister. In fact, as I understand it, something of the order of 5,000 people who did not have a job before now have employment in the hospitality sector in South Australia. It may well be that some senators in here do not like gaming machines; I am one of them. I have never put 10c in one. But who am I to tell people what they should spend their money on?

When I was dealing with this in South Australia, the Democrats came up to me and said, `Look, we want $20 million out of gaming machines to go and put on horseracing.' I said, `What are you talking about?' They said, `It's like this. We want you to use you numbers to squeeze the government's bill for tax so that we can get 20 million bucks'—which is a lot of money in South Australia—`and give it to the horseracing industry.' I was puzzled over that because I could not understand the difference—and I still cannot—between putting a couple of bob in a gaming machine and putting some money on a horse. No‐one has explained the difference to me except that there are 400,000 people in South Australia that employ 5,000 others that have voted with their feet.

I would like to have more time here today but I understand that I have only a short park for this debate. One of the problems the Democrats have is that eventually they are going to be called to account for some of their policies. They are going to be called to account for some of their ideas on how people in this country can get upskilled to work in the modern industrial society that we are aiming for.

Let me finish by saying that the Democrats oppose any mining venture around the place because if they did not do that we would have to kill weeds. And that is something over here that we cannot accept at all: the death of a weed or someone getting a job. That is an equation that will come down on the side of getting somebody a job. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, on behalf of my coalition colleagues I would like to welcome Senator Bartlett. It is a shame that he is not actually in the chamber this afternoon because this really is a pretty important topic. Senator Mackay has put up a pretty brave motion. I am not suggesting that Senator Mackay herself, personally, is hypocritical, because she follows the Labor line, but the motion smacks of such hypocrisy and such opportunism in circumstances where Labor's record has to be seen to be believed. The whole motion that has been brought forward this afternoon seems to proceed on the assumption that structural unemployment happened in a vacuum—it just dropped out of the ceiling and, there we are, we have had dreadful unemployment since the Howard government came to office.

SPEECH.PARA: The whole motion is directed to blame and not solutions, even though there is a reference to the need to explore creative and practical solutions to the employment crisis. Of course, one of the problems about that is that everything that Labor stands for looks backwards to an age that no longer exists. It does not exist in an age where the economy is globalised, where there has been loss of jobs because a lot of industries have become obsolete and where one really does have to look at fixing the economy before you can look at what initiatives and employment programs might address this problem that we have in this country and that is even worse in other countries throughout Europe and the region.

What we have with this motion is old Labor—the old Labor that we know so well. No wonder Senator Quirke did not want to go back to Labor's record. It is very difficult to see how anyone on the other side of this chamber could keep a straight face when advocating that somehow or other they addressed the problems of a loss of jobs that beset this country. Labor destroyed 420,000 full-time jobs during the `recession we had to have'. Full-time unemployment fell from 6.2 million in July 1990 to 5.8 million in November 1992. Young people fared even worse. The number of young people with full-time jobs halved. Full-time youth unemployment fell by approximately 240,000 from 465,000 in June 1989 to 227,000 in March 1994. These were the young people whom Mr Keating told to go and get a job. What an insult to people who were genuinely facing problems under Labor.

Long-term unemployment trebled during the worst recession since the 1930s Depression. Long-term unemployment increased from 114,000 in November 1989 to 349,000 in July 1993. The unemployment average under Labor was 8.7 per cent during the 13 years that Labor had to fix this problem and to actually address the structural problems that beset this economy, and it did not fall below nine per cent from March 1991 to November 1994—nearly three years—and it peaked at 11 per cent. This is not a record to be proud of. This is not a record that can be defended under any circumstances.

We should look at the manufacturing industry. The manufacturing sector was forced to shed over 200,000 jobs. During the time that Labor occupied the treasury bench, it showed no net employment growth at all. In fact, at the time the Howard government came to office, there were one million people out of work. To suggest that somehow or other you draw a line under this record and that the Howard government—or, indeed, any govern ment—has a magic wand to wave to redress this sort of structural problem and the long-term unemployment problem created by Labor is just untenable.

We all know that the way to really look at improving employment is to get the economy into such a shape that new jobs are created and sustainable jobs are created. The government's scorecard on macro‐economic reform so far is pretty impressive. The budget deficit of $10.5 billion is under control and on track to achieving an underlying surplus. That is certainly no mean feat. Inflation in the last year is the lowest it has been for 30 years. Official interest rates have been reduced on five occasions since last July from 7.5 per cent to five per cent, and economic growth is projected to reach 3.75 per cent this year.

The government has undertaken a number of significant industry reforms in its first 18 months of office, which my colleague Senator Tierney detailed. Major changes have been made which will actually help to create the environment to let the economy grow stronger and let the economy grow for a sustained period so that jobs can be created.

Whilst government can take initiatives—I will get to those in a moment—they cannot actually create the jobs. So, until you fix these economic fundamentals—the environment to allow growth, the environment to allow new jobs to be created, the confidence to get the economy back on track and the confidence that business will actually take on new employees—jobs will not be there.

The economic fundamentals also include fixing up and getting a more efficient tax system, a tax system that will actually deliver a lower rate of tax for business to encourage them to take on more employees and to do such things as fix the waterfront. That is something that has never been tackled by Labor. It is doing a lot to slow the economy because the waterfront is so slow. The turnaround on the waterfront is a national disgrace. It is important to identify and remove distortions that protect some sectors at the expense of others. This government is not in the business of business welfare and handouts; it is in the business of making the economy strong so that new jobs can be created.

BREAK.PARA: The government has implemented many initiatives in its first 18 months. Just looking back at Working Nation that everybody over there touts as some great saviour program, that was Labor's response to the unemployment crisis. You have to say that, on any view, it was a dismal failure. Between July 1990 and March 1996, Labor's policies added only an additional 7,100 full-time jobs. That is pretty paltry. Many Working Nation programs simply did not lead to real jobs. For example, only 22 per cent of participants in the new work opportunities program ended up in unsubsidised employment, despite it costing over $10,000 per person to participate in the program.

When I first became a senator in this place, I remember going to places such as Newcastle and Belmont in New South Wales to present certificates to graduates of the new work opportunities program. They were enthusiastic people who were keen about their skills and ready to offer themselves for employment. Guess what? They had no jobs to go to.

Work for the dole is a necessary scheme in a broader range of initiatives—it is only one—to tackle youth unemployment. That seems to be something that we have not got our heads around in this debate—that we have to look after young people. The whole of government approach and the work for the dole scheme have thrown up a lot of other initiatives to increase genuine job opportunities. The new national apprenticeship scheme will provide trainees with world-class skills, giving Australian businesses a competitive edge in the global economy. Another $1.3 billion has been allocated to vocational education and training in 1997. This is an increase of $144 million on funding provided in the last year of Labor.

To actually say that this government is not addressing the structural problems of unemployment is simply not to understand the economic fundamentals that are essential to create the environment to let new jobs be created. The new apprenticeships and traineeships will be in high growth industries such as technology, finance, tourism and hospitality, sport and the traditional trades.

The skills and qualifications of new apprentices and trainees will provide a skilled work force able to take up the jobs that will surely flow from the economy which is at last actually starting to show that new jobs and new opportunities will be able to be sustained. It will be easier for employers to actually hire apprentices. In the calendar year 1998, a total of $891 million will be provided for TAFE and other training providers through the Australian National Training Authority. Community reaction to what the Howard government is doing overwhelmingly supports the initiatives. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibbs, Sen Brenda

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise today to speak on the appalling record of the Howard government's ability to deal with unemployment. The hypothesis of the Australian Democrats on statistics of job losses between 1986 and 1997 is actually incorrect. I am assuming that these figures were obtained from the Sydney Morning Herald article of 20 October which stated that there had been 3.3 million full-time retrenchments between 1986 and 1997. This has been wrongly interpreted as being the figure for net jobs lost.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that these retrenchments occurred, but this gives us only half the picture. These figures were more than offset by the creation of many new jobs, both full-time and part-time. In fact, during the Hawke and Keating governments over two million new jobs were created despite the fact that we did not inherit an economy which was in very good shape.

I notice that members of the coalition have made numerous remarks to the media—with great satisfaction, I might add—about the healthy state in which we left the economy. I wish that we could have said the same when we inherited the economy from the coalition in the first place.

When the coalition first took office, it had the benefit of inheriting an economy which had seen three years of economic growth averaging four per cent, inflation averaging 2.5 per cent and an unemployment rate which had dropped from 11 per cent to 8.5 per cent. We created 700,000 new jobs and were well on our way to achieving our medium‐term target unemployment rate of five per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who created the jobs?

—Us. All the available international comparisons confirmed the healthy state of our economy in terms of budget strategy, and we had the third lowest expenditure in the OECD. Government debt was fourth lowest among OECD countries, contrary to what the Treasurer (Mr Costello) would have us believe.

BREAK.PARA: I would like to contrast this with the situation which the Labor Party inherited from the coalition. When the Hawke government was first elected, it came into office with an unemployment rate of 10 per cent, thanks to the Howard‐Fraser strategy of fighting inflation first, an inflation rate of over 10 per cent—so obviously they were not too successful at tackling that—and a country at industrial war with itself.

Our strategy was different. We focused on jobs and people—not banks and profits. The number of jobs grew steadily during the boom period of the 1980s at a rate which was faster than that of other OECD countries. This of course was aided substantially by the Accord—the preparedness of the government of the day to manage the economy—and the creation of a whole range of specific initiatives, including a scheme of direct job creation called the community employment program, which was allocated $300 million to fund 70,000 full-time jobs of an average six-month duration on labour intensive projects of social and economic benefit to the community.

I would like to contrast this with the current government's approach. It does not believe it has an interventionist role to play in managing unemployment, except when the next election looms, when it will pull fists full of dollars out of a magic hat—and probably a few white rabbits as well—and use its slush fund to fool people into thinking that it is interested in job creation schemes which build public infrastructure. But nobody will be fooled. It is really just a smoke and mirrors trick. This government seems to think that the people of Australia are stupid, that they will be fooled by colour and movement, but I do not believe that they will. I do not believe that they will not be able to see through this government's real intentions.

The government has failed to make unemployment its No. 1 priority, and I am angry about that. I am particularly angry because the government has just squandered the economic inheritance it was given and it is the unemployed who are paying the price for this.

TALK.START.PARA: —What! A $10 billion deficit!

—And you know it is, Senator Campbell. The role of the government is to intervene and assist in solving the key problems facing our country. It is not its role to sit back and save our money for a big pre-election splash and put in place instead a work for the dole scheme, which the government has already admitted is not a job creation scheme as well.
—We have not saved. We have paid back your bankcard bill.

—You are like an old record. Support for the manufacturing sector is important, and it is in this area that we differ widely from the government as well. We believe in industry policy, and I think that will be one of the defining issues of the next election. It has been widely reported in the media that employer organisations like the MTIA are frustrated by the lack of government activity in this area. This lack of activity is only going to get a lot more galling for a lot more people, given the impact of the economic problems some of our neighbours in Asia are facing and the implications that these will have for our own export industries.

BREAK.PARA: The real problem is that the government thinks that intervention in the economy is a bad idea. We have seen this demonstrated in relation to the government's slash and burn approach to vocational education and training programs and labour market programs.

The government does not believe that it has a role in managing and shaping economic change. It has some other funny beliefs and, I should say, prejudices. Mr Andrew, the member for Wakefield, has complained in the House that his phone rings almost as frequently with employers seeking workers as it does with the unemployed seeking work. I do not think Mr Andrew's solution of more job sharing is really going to solve our unemployment problem—but thanks for trying anyway, Mr Andrew.

Cuts of over $1.8 billion to the Working Nation programs are hardly likely to be offset in any meaningful way by $160 million over four years for the apprenticeship and traineeship scheme. These cuts are harming some of the most vulnerable in our community—the young unemployed.

Working Nation was one of the most comprehensive labour market programs ever put forward by a government in Australia. It was piloted, tested and proved to be successful. Also, it was targeted at all people so that you could get access to a program if you were young, older, female, an indigenous person or from a non‐English speaking background. I am very proud of the inclusive nature of those programs which, unlike the work for the dole scheme—although it does sound like heresy to raise them in the same sentence—did not target and punish the young unemployed. The youth training initiative, case management and the job compact offered real opportunities for the young, long‐term unemployed to get out of that cycle of unemployment and lack of experience, coupled with poverty.

Under Labor, the number of long‐term unemployed fell every month for 32 months. I would like to contrast this with the increase of 58,000 in the number of long‐term unemployed that has occurred since May 1996 due to the freezes and then cuts to many Working Nation programs. These so‐called industrial relations reforms, touted by the government as the panacea for solving all our economic and industry ills, have so far been spectacularly unsuccessful at addressing unemployment problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should write your own speeches. This stuff is really bad.

—I do. The increasing division between the haves and the have‐nots in our society is going to haunt us in years to come. It is about time that the government faced up to the reality that their industrial relations changes are not going to work. How much longer do we have to listen to them bleat on about needing more time?

BREAK.PARA: The truth is that employers are not racing out to hire more employees. They are more concerned about the lack of coherent industry policy and cuts to research and development. In spite of government rhetoric about support for small business, the cuts to R&D and the decision to abolish the export market development grants scheme have reduced investment in industry. Financial support for the new enterprise incentive scheme has also been slashed.

This legislation is wasting the opportunities created by the Labor government to attract investment and create real jobs. There were 739,000 jobs created in Labor's last term in office and, although unemployment was still too high, it had been cut from 11.2 per cent at the peak of a worldwide recession to 8.1 per cent. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Sandy

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a simple truism that governments must exercise fiscal responsibility to provide economic growth and job promotion. If ever we needed proof, the volatility of the stock market worldwide this week shows just that. While we did not escape the impact of the falls, Australia has come out of the turbulence in good shape. Share prices have recovered, confidence is returning and companies just this day are talking about future economic plans. This week's events, taken with the instability of several South-East Asian economies, underlines the key point that, without a stable, low inflation economy, our country, which is commodity based, is particularly vulnerable to economic movements worldwide.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday the Treasurer (Mr Costello) told parliament that the Australian economy has sound macro‐economic fundamentals of low inflation, high productivity growth and high profitability. He said we would have been in a far more exposed position had the government not put in place plans to rescue Australia's fiscal position. A healthy economy is the No. 1 goal of this government. The opposition talks about setting targets, as it did in question time today. The target that we have set ourselves is a sound foundation, sound building blocks, which is the most important target that any government can have.

When we came into office, the Commonwealth's underlying budget deficit was over $10 billion. Budget deficits over the last five years of the previous government had totalled $70 billion, driving the general Commonwealth government net debt from $17 billion in 1991 to $93 billion five years later. What a legacy. Labor simply were economic profligates.

We have now been in office just 19 months, but already the measures we have put in place to provide for the budget to move into underlying surplus by 1998 have been seen. It is a massive turnaround. By taking responsibility for the economy and correcting the fundamentals that Labor ignored, we have laid the foundations for job growth. We are pushing that growth on several fronts: with creative approaches to unemployment and youth unemployment, such as work for the dole and Green Corps; with the increased emphasis on exports; with initiatives like the supermarket to Asia; by encouraging savings and investment; by reforming workplace industrial relations so that business and small business can feel able to take on more staff; and by tackling some areas that the Labor Party in its 13 years of office did not get around to, like the waterfront—or did not get around to honestly.

Only last night the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, Peter Reith, had three hours of constructive talks with union leaders. It is a great step in the right direction to see that that cooperative workplace is being attempted. The government is committed to improving productivity on the waterfront, which will secure the jobs of waterfront workers, boost export income and then provide a whole lot of other Australians with jobs. The Labor Party claim that we have done nothing about unemployment, that we do not care about people out of work, is completely unfounded.

The thought that Labor have a mortgage on caring for those people who are unemployed is just plain wrong. Labor have nothing to crow about when it comes to creating jobs. Throughout their last year of office, employment hovered at around 8.4 per cent. They also have the distinction of delivering the highest unemployment rate since the Great Depression, and that was 11.2 per cent in December 1982. In fact, for nine months in 1992 and 1993 unemployment stayed at 11 per cent or over.

Labor's approach to unemployment was pretty straightforward: `If you can't get a job, don't worry about it. The government will fudge something for you. You can apply for the dole and get onto a program like Working Nation.' This meant that you would get some training but you would still go without a job. The long-term unemployed were given no encouragement by the previous Labor government to find work. DEETYA's evaluation of Labor's Working Nation program revealed that the share of market assistance to long-term unemployed people actually fell.

Working Nation under Labor churned the unemployed through at a massive rate, but it was entirely a cosmetic solution. By contrast, by May 1998 we will have replaced Labor's failed labour market assistance programs with a new employment services market. In this market employment placement companies will receive full payment only if they deliver results. While Labor impliedly accepted that it could not reduce unemployment and tinkered at finding ways to create work, Australia's social security bill went through the roof. It was typical of Labor's credit card approach to the economy: just book it up; don't worry about it.

Contrast that with the coalition's approach. This afternoon the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman, said that, through the efforts of her department and improved compliance measures, this government is now saving $28 million a week from people who were not entitled to certain amounts of social welfare.

TALK.START.PARA: —Living off the battlers.
—That is absolutely right, Senator O'Chee. Where help is needed, it should be provided. Where people are not entitled to help, they should not get it.

SPEECH.PARA: This is excellent news because it makes more money available for those who genuine ly need assistance. It also makes a mockery of the ALP's claim that there was no room for improvement in this area. This government is not afraid to put in the hard yards to generate jobs and wealth through proper productivity, a more sound economy and more mainstream procedures for small business. We are tackling the problems like unfair dismissal, our antiquated taxation system and competition reform.

Finally, we come to the big winner: interest rates. This has been the single most important achievement of this government's term so far. The benefits of low interest rates flow to almost every part of the economy. Inflation, at virtually zero, is at a 30-year low. It has never been so low since 1969. This government is committed to low inflation. Low inflation encourages people to save and invest, it boosts confidence and it aids those who are making long-term decisions. Low interest rates and low inflation assist businesses to make sound investment decisions and underpin the creation of new and lasting job opportunities.

Senator Mackay, I am pleased that you have re-entered the chamber, because we have come from your so‐called banana republic to a country with a solid and robust economy today, a country that can start to look itself in the face in the approach taken to fiscal responsibility and fiscal consolidation. This has been clearly demonstrated this week. As the stock market roller‐coaster travelled around the world, Australia withstood the bumps, and we will continue to do so because this government faces reality in a way that the Labor government never could.

I will admit that the inevitable process of structural reform is not something new to us. It was a problem that the previous government faced as well. Structural adjustment in the economy is here to stay, whether you like it or not, but economic changes which all countries face and which Australia is facing bring opportunities. Those opportunities have to be recognised by business, and they have to be encouraged by government.

It is government that must put in place the methods by which economies can grow and adapt. It is a shared responsibility. It always interests me when companies say that they have a right to put people off but that it is the government's responsibility alone to create jobs. Governments never create jobs. I understand, for instance, that the proposed merger of the Bank of Melbourne and Westpac may cause up to 750 job losses this year. I understand that, over the last three years, around 15,000 jobs have been lost in the banking industry as its operations have changed.

I also understand that there is probably the same number of people employed in banking now as there was in 1949. There has been massive structural adjustment in that industry, and it is a shared responsibility of banks and government to provide the sorts of incentives needed for the economy to grow. It is not always the right of companies to put people off and then say that it is the responsibility of governments to create jobs. It is a shared responsibility; it is a responsibility which this government takes up and will continue to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to this motion because, quite clearly, the government have done nothing to affect the unemployment rate, particularly the long‐term unemployment rate, in this nation. That is the essence of what we are talking about here this afternoon. According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, if you look at the people who have been unemployed for between 52 weeks and 104 weeks in a year, you see that the number in August 1996 has gone from 99,700 to 105,500. Quite clearly, there has been an increase in the number of people who are long-term unemployed.

SPEECH.PARA: If one looks at the other category—that is, people who are unemployed for 104 weeks and over, and do not forget that is two years or more—one will see that the number has gone from 119,600 to 129,800. So in both categories, those that are unemployed between 52 weeks and 104 weeks and those unemployed more than 104 weeks, the numbers have escalated in the time of this government—between August 1996 and August 1997. The government has had at its disposal the right to remedy the situation.

BREAK.PARA: What one sees is that the long‐term unemployed figure as a proportion of the total unemployed figure has gone from 28.4 per cent to 30.8 per cent. The long‐term unemployment problem has worsened during the period of this government. We are not seeing any improvement. This is where the problem lies. The fact is that the battlers, the people that the government so firmly and squarely claimed they were going in to represent, have not been given the promised wonderland that was painted for them.

If one turns to table 27 in the ABS statistics of August 1997, one sees another situation. If one looks at who are the people most affected in this long‐term unemployed area, one will find that it is the older people, the people who are finding it toughest and hardest to secure employment. If one looks particularly at the males in that area, one finds that, in the group between 25 years of age and 34 years of age who have been unemployed for 52 weeks or more, there are some 36,900 males. In the age bracket 35 to 54 years of age, there are 55,100 who have been unemployed for 52 weeks or more. This is the real nub of the argument. The fact is that the government have done nothing to turn these numbers around. We are not talking about comparisons with the period of the Labor government; we are talking about what the government have had firmly and squarely in their own control to do something about, and clearly nothing has happened.

The same problem exists for females in that bracket of being unemployed for 52 weeks and over. Again one finds a disproportionate number of women fitting into the categories 25 to 34 years of age or 35 to 54 years of age. That is some 20,600 in the first group and 37,100 in the second group. So we are finding that the government have not addressed this issue at all.

If one then looks at regional unemployment, one will find that this is part of the reason why the government does not know how to handle the problem. If you look at ABS regional unemployment statistics—and I will look at just a couple of areas in Queensland, again rural and regional areas which this government prides itself as doing something for—you find that in the south and east Moreton statistical region the unemployment rate is 9.8 per cent; north and west Moreton, 11.9 per cent; Wide Bay and Burnett, 12.7 per cent; Darling Downs and south‐west regional, 5.3 per cent.

The government might claim some sort of victory there, but it is a pyrrhic victory because the people in the bush are leaving the bush because they cannot get jobs. That is why the figures are down there. The Mackay‐Fitzroy‐central west statistical region is 9.8 per cent. It does not matter where you look; you are looking at a rate which is well in excess of the national average—the national average being in the order of 8.6 per cent. We find that the government have turned a blind eye to the people that they claimed they were going to help, the people that are in most need of help.

If you look at the situation for young people, you will see that the calamity persists. Let us look at the Queensland area again. The 15- to 19-year-old full-time unemployment rate in the Brisbane inner ring is 25.9 per cent; the outer ring is 30.5 per cent; the south and east Brisbane balance, 34.5 per cent; and the north and west Brisbane balance, 36.7 per cent. In relation to some of the country regions: in north and west Moreton it is 45.5 per cent; Wide Bay and Burnett, 38.1 per cent; the Darling Downs and south west, 18.4 per cent; and Mackay‐Fitzroy‐central west, 42.2 per cent. If you look, you will see that the unemployment rate for young people is disproportionate to even the national average in those areas, and again this government have done nothing about it.

This government have tried to solve the unemployment problem by reducing the participation rate. Of course, the participation rate continues to fall. The only answer that the government can try to give us is, `Small business will create the jobs.' That is just complete and utter nonsense. If you look at what government have done to small business, you will see that they have given small business an economy that is flat and where there is little or no growth. Small business cannot take up the slack in labour that exists out there. So we clearly have a government that do not know where they are going. This to me was totally epitomised by an ad that appeared in the Courier‐Mail on Saturday, 12 April. It is headed `Public sector career opportunities including graduate careers'. The note down the bottom is of particular interest, because it says:

Please note that competition for positions in the Public Sector is very strong. Nationally, it is expected that over 100,000 people will express initial interest. In the 1995/96 financial year fewer than 2,000 non graduate permanent positions were filled. Of up to 10,000 graduates expected to sit the test, it is expected around 300‐400 will obtain permanent positions.

So this is a government that feign an interest in employment and an interest in young people—and here they are saying that, at most, 300 to 400 people will get permanent positions out of the 10,000 expected to sit the test. They go on further to say that in Queensland some 4,600 candidates sat for the former administrative services test, with less than 200 being placed during 1996 in a very limited number of departments. So they paint the picture clearly themselves. There is no doubt that it is beyond anyone's reasonable consideration that this government are doing anything to address the issue of long-term unemployment, because the statistics clearly show that, and anything about youth unemployment, because quite clearly they are just not interested.

Here, at a time when there is growth in the economy, we are seeing all the signs of a recession. We are seeing downsizing in companies. We are seeing unemployment either rising or remaining steady; if there is any fall, it can be explained by seasonal factors—and seasonal factors alone. What we have are the hallmarks of a recession, with a government claiming that they are a government of growth, that they are a government of creation of jobs. Of course, this purely is a nonsense.

Effectively, what we have is a government who have lost the plot. With the people they claimed they were going to represent, they have failed miserably. The only thing that can be taken for granted in this nation is that the only people who will represent the battlers in a fair and equitable way are those in the Labor Party. The claim that was made by the Liberal Party in their campaign was spurious indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Heffernan, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —What a tirade of rubbish. I am not too sure whether that was a cross between Al Grassby and Clyde Cameron, or a couple of Clydesdale horses and a couple of mules. But it was certainly a load of rubbish. These guys want to go back to where they were when Fraser was in government. You came into government under Keating, and all you produced under him was a record recession—the recession that we had to have. We are not producing recession; we are rising with our productivity. Sure, there is a paradox between productivity and employment, and we are dealing with it.

SPEECH.PARA: Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President, for the opportunity to get up today and rid the agenda of this rubbish. It gives me great pleasure to debate Senator Mackay's spurious motion about this government's apparent disregard for Australia's unemployed. Disregard? Rubbish! The coalition government has always been, and will always continue to be, committed to employment growth.

Paul Keating had the greatest disregard and contempt for Australia's unemployed. We all remember—and particularly our youth will remember—when he walked down the streets and arrogantly said `go and get a job' to the unemployed. What job, Paul? I remind the Senate that 13 years of Labor gave us our highest unemployment rate in the last 60 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Go back to 1982.

—Kim Beazley presided over an unemployment rate that peaked at 11.2 per cent in December 1992, and in July of that year youth unemployment was 34 per cent. You have forgotten that, have you, Senator Hogg? It was as high as 50.5 per cent in many parts of my State of New South Wales. We only to have go back two or three days ago when you would not pass the unfair dismissal law—you are not even having a go. Now Mr Beazley sits in the other place as leader of the Labor Party trying to pretend that he offers a real alternative. What did Mr McCrann call him the other day? Mr Hippopotamus.

SPEECH.PARA: Australians will not be fooled. Senators and their constituents alike must surely agree that these figures taken from when you were in office clearly show a government unable to deal with unemployment. Your government was pathetic.
The coalition has taken responsibility for Labor's mismanagement. We are creating an environment that is building job confidence. We are reducing debt after Labor's $10.3 billion legacy—

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the statistics.

—the black hole that you pretend is not there, your flying fantasy. We have seen a significant reduction in interest rates; in fact, there have been five interest rate cuts since we came into government.
—Oh, what does that mean?

—That just shows what you know about being in business, Senator Stott Despoja. You have never had a real job. You are a very great media guru and, yes, sure, you will put on a prance and a dance. But you know nothing about the real world. Go and get a real job. What a joke—and I hope the people of Australia are listening to this today—that you do not think interest rates matter. What a joke!

SPEECH.PARA: We are providing relief for small business through capital gains tax relief, a lower provisional tax uplift factor, and less red tape to enable more time for business. You would not know anything about that either, Senator Stott Despoja. We are providing training for real jobs, not make believe jobs. No wonder they do not want you for leader of the Democrats because you do not know what you are doing. The outcome will be more jobs for more Australians. It is the Labor Party who have been following a very anti-job policy.

Senator Mackay and her Labor colleagues must have a short memory. It was only last week that once again you lot displayed your anti‐job policy by voting against unfair dismissal exemption for small business.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a load of rubbish and you know it! The statistics showed that not one job had been created.
