—Don't try to hide behind that blurb you've got. The refusal of those opposite to pass that legislation is a blow to the employment prospects of thousands of Australians—I will give you the answer in a second—who would have been offered jobs if it had been passed.

BREAK.PARA: In an article in the Sydney Morning Herald on 23 October, the day after Labor and the Democrats down there betrayed our unemployed—Senator Stott Despoja has left the chamber; she has gone to hide—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, she has not!
—the Chief Executive of the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia, Mr Rob Bastian, said:

BREAK.PARA: . . . the unfair dismissal provisions of the Workplace Relations Act were part of a host of regulations which made small business fearful of hiring staff.
He went on to say:
. . . at least 50,000 jobs could be created by the exemption—
that you knocked back. He continued:
Mr Bastian said this was based on an assumption that one in 20 small businesses would take on people if they did not have to cope with the provisions of the Federal Workplace Relations Act.
They are the anti‐job provisions left over from the Industrial Relations Reform Act of your old mate Laurie. Good old Laurie—the old Laurie whom we all know from Botany Bay, and Murray Farquhar—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I think that the speaker was referring to a member in another place by quite unparliamentary terms. I would ask the senator to refer to people in the other place by their correct titles.
—I was distracted at the time, but if—
—I will withdraw, if I did. But I called him `your old mate'. Don't you want him as a mate? I called him an old mate from Botany Bay council.
—Senator Heffernan, please withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw the remark. On the proclamation of the act in 1994, Laurie Brereton said:

BREAK.PARA: The changes present Australian employers and their employees with a great opportunity to introduce to workplaces the flexibility necessary to improve productivity and efficiency.

I was dismayed and alarmed today that there would be a suggestion from your side of the chamber that somehow you would not put off people who were the worst performers—that you would start with your best. Crazy logic!

Results from a survey by the New South Wales Chamber of Commerce in May of this year asked small business if the prospect of unfair dismissal laws discouraged them from adding on staff. Fifty‐six per cent said `yes'. That is a resounding `yes' for our coalition reforms. Those unfair dismissal laws have intimidated thousands of employers around Australia and deterred them from taking on more staff.

Had Labor and the minor parties supported the government last week, they would have shown the Australian people that this parliament is serious about employment and Australia's future. They would have shown the people of Australia that they were prepared to support the government for the sake of those people who feel disillusioned and disaffected out there—some who are second and perhaps third generation unemployed. It is a message much needed by the community that we want to help the unemployed.

This government is not giving up on the community. We will bring the legislation back, demonstrating that we are committed to job growth. This government is about getting Australia going again. Our budget reflects that commitment. Because of Labor's legacy of lies we have had to make some pretty tough decisions. Our budgets are about creating real jobs, particularly for our young people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Stop reading your own propaganda.
—I have to say that I thought it was a pretty glamorous photo of you in the paper today.

BREAK.PARA: Remember when apprenticeships were the path to lasting jobs? Yet in 1995, the number of young people in apprenticeships and traineeships, as a proportion of the work force, was at its lowest level in 30 years. The government is doing something about it. In August, the minister announced $550 million for at least 220,000 new apprenticeships and traineeships over the next two years. That is a 48 per cent increase in job opportunities for our youth. We are providing major benefits to young people, employers and, ultimately, the economy.

I would like to refresh people's memories. In December 1992, at the height of `the recession we had to have'—brought on by Captain Wacky, your leader of the past—the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate rose to the historically high level of 11.2 per cent. Senator Lundy, you are as bad as Clyde Cameron. You would not remember Clyde Cameron. Senator Stott‐Despoja might; she is a student of politics. I guess you are a rower and a bricklayer. Clyde Cameron used to come into this place and bag hell out of the government of the time. He then got into government and produced record unemployment. He said that the worst decision he made in his career as the labour minister was to introduce holiday leave loading. He said that it was the worst decision that he had made in his career—and I am pleased to see that Senator Chris Evans acknowledges that.

One million Australians were out of work under Paul Keating in any one given month—more than ever previously recorded. Long‐term unemployment reached a historical peak of 349,000 in July 1993. Unemployment has been unacceptably high for well over a decade. For nine of the 13 financial years between 1983‐84 and 1996‐97, the trend‐averaged annual unemployment rate exceeded eight per cent.

The labour market began to weaken in the first half of 1995. This led to growth in short‐term unemployment which ultimately fed into the long‐term unemployment growth which we have seen since May 1996. Long‐term unemployment increased by 1.5 per cent to 256,000 in September 1997; that is a trend. Over the last eight months, however, short‐term unemployment numbers have been declining, and the number of long‐term unemployed in the 52‐ to 104‐week category is beginning to stabilise. This augurs well for a slowdown in growth for overall long‐term unemployment numbers.

In 1998, the competitive delivery of employment services will minimise the weaknesses and inefficiencies evident in the previous government's arrangements and will help those disadvantaged in the labour market to benefit from the emerging job opportunities which we are already beginning to see. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand why Senator Heffernan would get so passionate and feel so emotional about the particular issue before us today. There is, however, no excuse for him to get personal on this issue, denouncing me as a media guru. His reference to Senator Lundy's photograph in the Canberra Times today as `glamorous' was perhaps not such a negative inference, but lecturing us or telling us that we are not necessarily politicians or that we have not had enough life experience—whatever the inferences were—does not get us much further in this debate. I only wish that the honourable senator would apply the same passion and vigour to the debate about unemployment. For the record, it is not befitting of Senator Heffernan because normally he is not personal; normally he is a lot fairer in his comments.

SPEECH.PARA: As for his comments in relation to the unfair dismissal law, I am afraid I cannot let that go. How dare he make such claims for that contrived piece of legislation? It was contrived merely for the purposes of bringing on a double dissolution—that is my opinion and that of my party—and has no substantiation with either facts and figures or anecdotal evidence. In fact, all the statistics that were brought to this chamber pointed to this law being an unnecessary and unfair piece of legislation.

BREAK.PARA: We knew that unfair dismissal claims on a national or a federal level were down by 52 per cent, and most of those claims related to big business. We knew that on state and territory levels they were down by roughly 20 per cent. So we have had no sufficient substantiation from this government for introducing those exemptions for small business from the unfair dismissal laws that we opposed for very good reasons last week. If the other side of the chamber wants to know why small business is not necessarily hiring or taking on new employees, it is because they, like many other people in this community, do not have confidence in our economy.

Mr Acting Deputy President, you would not be surprised to see some of the reasons that small business gives for not hiring more employees. It is certainly not the unfair dismissal laws. They are certainly not calling for an exemption for small business from the unfair dismissal laws. When we survey small business, when we look at the Yellow Pages survey of small business, what do we see? More than 50 per cent say that they believe the economy is either in recession or at a standstill. That is why they are not taking on more employees.

As for Senator Heffernan's reference to interest rates, the interjection that I made in the chamber was not that interest rates do not matter—quite the contrary. I am just sick and tired of hearing this government bleat about lower interest rates and low inflation as some kind of panacea to the problem we have with our economy, with our growth rates—or lack of them—and with our unemployment rates.

We wonder why the Reserve Bank stepped in and lowered interest rates. They had to do something to get our economy moving, because not a lot of growth is happening. If we look at Treasurer Costello's forecast from last year, we see that the government was anticipating that growth would be around 3.7 per cent by June 1997. It was actually 3.25 per cent. So much for the government's estimates of what growth would be. We do not see much happening on the manufacturing side either. I was not for a minute suggesting that interest rates are not important. They are fundamentally important, but lower interest rates are not necessarily an indicator that our economy is alive and well. Our economy certainly is not.

Not only the current government has failed to address the issue of unemployment; the former government, I and my party believe, has too. Any attempt to have a meaningful discussion about employment in this place has failed. We only have to look at last week's urgency debate, brought on by the acting leader of the Democrats, Senator Lees, where we tried to debate this issue. Not only did we not debate the issue; the two old parties spent the afternoon filibustering, moving to suspend standing orders and scoring political points in an attempt to delay this debate. That was more offensive than usual because it took place against the backdrop of a series of articles by the Sydney Morning Herald which pointed out quite soberingly and starkly that 3.3 million jobs had been abolished in Australia over the past decade. That includes 550,000 jobs lost under the coalition government. The record of this government and of the former government is appalling.

Increasingly we are seeing a lack of full‐time jobs and the casualisation of the work force. We are seeing no attempts by this government to inject money where it counts. That means looking after specifically targeted, successful labour market programs. It means looking at how we can retrain and skill and develop our workers so that they can compete in a changing work force.

It does not seem to be acknowledged very often, either by the former government or by the current government, that our work force has fundamentally changed. People are going to need skills and training in order to enter into and compete in a changed work force. We know that entry level jobs have diminished. We know that those traditional jobs that young people have occupied have gone. Yet I see no moves by this government to invest in jobs that are sustainable, meaningful and long term. That requires an economic commitment and an economic stimulus.

On the contrary. I hear the former minister for employment, Senator Vanstone, relying on some kind of McDonald's led recovery. There is the idea that people can go into low skilled, low value jobs—that, regardless of their professional inclination or qualifications, young people should take jobs at McDonald's. That is not even the point. There are not enough fries to go around for the 90,000‐odd young people who do not have a job in this country.

What have we seen from the government? We have seen a Green Corps, but, depending who you ask, that is not actually a job creation program. You bet it is not a job creation program—it is not creating any jobs that I have seen. Over three years, 3,500 places does not even come close to matching the 75,000 potential labour market program places provided through REAP, LEAP, land care and regional employment programs.

We have seen the work for the dole scheme. In her contribution, Senator Coonan suggested that was one way of instilling skills and what have you in young unemployed Australians. It is a compulsory scheme. I cannot see how that is instilling the dignity and motivation this government claims young people lack so badly.

It also misses the fundamental point: not one new job is being created by the work for the dole program. Much of the money being used to fund such a program has been cut from valuable labour market programs run under the former government. The Democrats would be the first to agree that there is no point in having labour market programs unless they are specifically targeted and appropriately funded.

What this government has done is to cut the successful schemes that operated under the former government's Working Nation program. I nominate Skillshare and NEIS as two of the obvious ones that had successful outcomes and successful rates. Yet they were cut or completely defunded. Cuts of $1.7 billion over two years to labour market programs are inexcusable and contrary to the direction in which we should be heading, given the changing nature of the work force.

Not only has this government cut funding to labour market programs. It has also cut $1.8 billion out of higher education. Higher education is an area which makes money for the government. We make more out of higher education exports in this country than we do out of wheat sales. Yet we are undermining that sector with cuts to quality research and education at a higher education level. There have been cuts of $1.8 billion to that sector over three years. About $50 million a year is my estimate of the amount that has been cut out of the vocational education and training area.

TAFE and the higher education sector are not the only victims. What about those institutions that foster training and education research—CSIRO and other educational institutions? They are the very institutions that will be responsible for not only solving the problems of today but also finding the solutions to the problems of tomorrow, whether those relate to the environment, to health or to something else. They are also the areas in which we should be targeting our wealth, ensuring that we do have sustainable and meaningful jobs for the future. CRCs, the Energy Research and Development Corporation and all those areas are the keys to ensuring that we not only have an educated work force and an enlightened and democratic community but also that we are investing in future technologies for tomorrow.

On that note, I commend the motion but acknowledge that it has not only been this government that has failed to address the issue of unemployment but the former government as well. I would like to take these few seconds to congratulate the Democrats' latest addition, Senator Andrew Bartlett from Queensland, a man who is passionately committed not only to the issue of solving unemployment but to social justice. He is also clever enough to make the connection between environmental protection and employment creation. I welcome him to this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take the opportunity to also welcome Senator Bartlett and congratulate him—

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Stott Despoja interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The latest job creation scheme for the Senate; at least we are making a contribution. I hope you enjoy your time here and congratulations on your election.

BREAK.PARA: We are debating the issue of unfair dismissal. We heard many panaceas to the problems of the country when this government got elected. First it was the current account deficit, then it was interest rates and then labour market reform. We had labour market reform; we ran that flag up but it did not seem to work too well. There were about 50,000; every week there was a new announcement—we had to have something that was the next solution to the country's problems. But the principal problem that we ran into was the way in which this government went about reducing expenditure. We have heard this government say that Labor created a fiscal black hole; you created an economic backwater. You destroyed the economy of this country.

We put in place all of the fundamentals. We brought inflation under control, had good employment growth and, with regard to expenditure, even though you seem to think it was too high, at least the economy was growing. The economy grew at a rate in excess of four per cent over the whole period we were in government. It was pointed out earlier that the now Prime Minister (Mr Howard) said that we would have to have growth in excess of four per cent, indeed higher growth, to make any dent in unemployment.

They were the things that you claimed, but what has happened since you have been in government? After 18 months of you people in government, what have you done? Unemployment has gone up, the economy has gone backwards—

TALK.START.PARA: —Inflation is zero.

—Senator Herron says that inflation is zero, but not because of any fundamental work that you ever did or your government has ever done. Absolutely not. Inflation was well under control when we left office. That is a point acknowledged by most major economists in this country. That is a fact.

BREAK.PARA: You said the panacea for employment would be small business. You said that we needed to do a whole range of things for small business. If we look at what was shown to us on many occasions when the coalition was in opposition—they referred to it time and again—the Yellow Pages Small Business Index, in the May edition we see what the confidence prospects are for the next 12 months. It says:

Small business confidence remains low, falling marginally since the previous survey three months ago. A net 40% of proprietors expressed confidence in their own business prospects, the lowest level since August 1993.
That is not a really good record on the part of a government that has been there for over 18 months and that said it had all of the solutions.

On many occasions I can recall the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, saying, `Workers can only do better under us. You can never do worse, you can only do better.' I bet there are a lot of workers out there thinking, `I wonder what that "better" meant? What did it actually mean in terms of us?' So many of them have lost their jobs, whether they be in the public or private sector. My own state was promised so much by this government in so far as expenditure and support, but what have we seen? Here again the other day we saw the government vote down an amendment to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1997 —an amendment proposed by us that would have very much assisted our state and, in particular, a region of our state that has unemployment in excess of 20 per cent. You voted that down. If ever the people of Australia had an indication to them that you people in government had totally misled them on all of the promises that you made, that was a really good example.

We have heard the Prime Minister say, in respect of the BHP announcement in Newcastle, `Free trade zone, tax breaks, tax holidays. We are going to invest a huge amount of money to bring information technology business.' With Senator `Doormat' Alston they created the ministry for the information economy, which has no money and seems to be going nowhere.

I mentioned before the Yellow Pages Small Business Index. If things are going so well, why is it that if you come up to the August edition of the Small Business Index, it says, in terms of confidence prospects over the next 12 months:
Small business confidence remains low, little changed over the past five quarters.
It should be called the mirror exercise: you are always looking into it. It goes on to say:
Confidence lifted strongly in the two territories but fell in Queensland, South Australia and Western Australia.

It did not even mention Tasmania. That is because it would not even register in terms of the confidence in Tasmania. It is a dip, a minus—it has gone down. Acting Deputy President Calvert knows that only too well.
Across all sectors, the Small Business Index says:
. . . small business confidence fell in Transport and Storage, was little changed in Personal Services and rose in all other sectors.
In the `Economic outlook' it says:
Small businesses' perceptions of the economy remain strongly negative, with more than 80% of proprietors surveyed in August seeing the economy in recession or at a standstill.

There is no evidence more damning than the evidence of the people that you say you are the champions for. That is the reality. You have tried to create a facade about legislation that relates to unfair dismissal, which is of little or no significance to these people at all, although you try and make it out to be. You have created another smokescreen. You needed another smokescreen for the government so you said, `Unfair dismissals is the problem. These people cannot employ and they cannot sack people.'

What a load of complete and utter rubbish. The very thing that these people want from the government is a lead in industry policy, in industry development. They want some confidence instilled back into the process called the economy of this country. They want to see a government that is taking some real direction in industry policy development. But what are you doing?

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not producing 20 per cent interest rates like you lot.

—I go to one example, for your benefit, Senator Heffernan: anti‐dumping legislation. What has the government done about it? It got Mr Laurie Willett to do a review and to provide recommendations on how best to address the question. Prior to the election you promised to bring down the number of days it took to deal with anti‐dumping and countervailing measures from 245 days to 155 days. Senator Parer came in and told us you had done a marvellous job; we have got the fastest system in the world because we have got it down to 215 days. We were promised 155. It is a long way short, I would think. You have got a report with all the recommendations, which I have to say Australia's manufacturing industry in particular welcomes and supports, and what do you do? You sit on your hands. The former minister for small business said, `We are going to refer it to the Productivity Commission.' Has he done that? No. So where is it at? What are you actually doing?

BREAK.PARA: You have all these opportunities to demonstrate to small business that you actually are going to reinvent this economy, re‐instil some confidence and get some industry policy development under way and demonstrate to people that you are doing something. Then these people will not be saying, `Look, 80 per cent of us still think the economy is at a standstill and going nowhere.' You should be addressing those questions, but you are doing absolutely nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Synon, Sen Karen

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the opposition for raising this important issue today. As we have heard many people say in this debate today, unemployment is the most critical issue facing this country. I am just somewhat disappointed that the ALP chose to force the debate to be aborted last week when the Democrats had moved a motion condemning the Keating and Hawke governments for their implicit and complicit role in the unemployment role in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: It is somewhat of a shame also that we revisit this issue after the Senate has just shamelessly rejected our amendments to the unfair dismissal laws. My colleague Senator Abetz last week raised the issue of the article in the Daily Telegraph headed, `Opportunity lost: dismissal law refusal trims hair salon jobs'. I wish to again draw the Senate's attention to that article, because I think it is a most important one and is indicative of the way many small businesses around this country are feeling.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read it out. You don't have anything of substance to say, so read an article.
—It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Hairdresser Vicki McFarlane was ready to take on two new staff members at her Parramatta salon in time for Christmas. But when Opposition MPs in Canberra scuppered changes to the unfair dismissal laws on Tuesday, Ms McFarlane decided it was just not worth the risk. "We feel betrayed by what the Senate has done," she said yesterday. "We can't grow—we need more people but we can't afford to put them on without the laws being changed."
That is shameful, and there are two people in Parramatta who do not have jobs because, Senator Lundy, of the Labor Party's position on this important amendment.

Further to that, if we needed more proof, in the Sydney Morning Herald of 23 October there is an article in which the New South Wales Chamber of Commerce chief executive, Ms Katie Lahey, is reported as rejecting the claim by the federal opposition that no independent research proving business concern on the issue exists. The chamber said that when it surveyed 800 small businesses in May and asked if the prospect of such claims discouraged them from adding staff, 56 per cent said yes. Her comments were supported by the chief executive of the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia, Mr Rob Bastian. He claimed that at least 50,000 jobs could be created by the exemption, and yet the opposition and the Australian Democrats have the audacity to come into this chamber and suggest that there is no evidence.

Unemployment is an important issue. As I say, it is the second time this chamber has considered it within a week. I am very concerned that the ALP in opposition declines to take responsibility for the unemployment problem that occurred under their 13 years of mismanagement of this country. I am frankly astonished at how you can sleep at night, because after 13 years you left us an economy that was basically in desperate need of some sound economic and financial management.

TALK.START.PARA: —So you knocked the stuffing out of it. You sacked 25,000 Telstra workers.

—You handed us an unemployment problem that was a disgrace. You should be ashamed of yourself. You are certainly not proud of your record because, if you were proud of your record, Senator Carr, you would have had no problem coming into this chamber last week and defending your record. But you are not proud, are you, and that is why you sought to abort the debate on the motion last week.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Stott Despoja said recently that the Senate is not good at engaging on this important issue, and I agree with her. When we have in this country 30 per cent of unemployed youth in households where no other person is working, it suggests to me that this is an absolutely fundamental issue and one that needs bipartisan support.

TALK.START.PARA: —So why did you cut long‐term unemployment programs? Since you got in, unemployment has gone through the roof.

—Unemployment is indeed the most important issue facing this nation. It is an issue not just about economics but about people's lives and about the way we as a society either support their hopes or condemn them to a bleak future. The coalition is working towards the goal of everyone who wants a job having one—the only legitimate goal a government that truly cares for its people can have. It is certainly not a goal the ALP espoused when they were in government.
—You have no credibility on this whatsoever.
—It is certainly not a goal the Democrats have either because we were alerted last week to the fact that in their unemployment issues paper the Democrats said:

BREAK.PARA: . . . a goal of every Australian having work is an impossibility.

Quite astonishing, isn't it? The goal of every Australian having work is an impossibility—that comes from the Australian Democrats. The ALP certainly did not have a goal of every Australian having a job, but this government certainly does. We heard that Senator Bartlett is passionate about the issue of unemployment. That is very encouraging because I would like to see whether he can revisit the Democrats' lofty ambitions for Australia's unemployed.

Our Prime Minister, John Howard, cares deeply about the plight of the unemployed and has committed himself and this government to working to turn this country and the fortunes of its people around. Jobs are our No. 1 priority. I am proud to be a member of a government for which jobs are a No. 1 priority. I could speak for hours on what the ALP did—or, rather, did not do—for the unemployed of this country over 13 years.

Unlike anyone else in this chamber, I have worked for nearly a dozen years directly with unemployed people in the western suburbs of Melbourne in Footscray, one of the most depressed areas in Victoria, and right throughout Victoria. One of my primary motivations for wanting to join the Howard government was my genuine despair about what the ALP's policies were doing to the morale and enthusiasm of the unemployed people I worked with.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can't believe you are saying this with a straight face.

—It is true, Senator Lundy, I am sorry—1.3 million Australians who under Labor could not find the level of employment they sought. We all know the disgraceful position of Labor when unemployment did not fall below nine per cent for nearly three years from March 1991 to November 1994.
—So how does your conscience treat the fact that you put 15,000 local people out of work?

—We all remember, Senator Lundy, when unemployment rates reached 11.2 per cent in December 1992—the highest level of unemployment in the postwar era. We all remember that Labor did nothing to solve it—two million people unemployed, discouraged from seeking work, underemployed, and the Labor Party did nothing.
—Fifteen thousand jobs locally. You have put people out of work. What about those families? You have a selective conscience, Senator Synon.
—Order! Senator Lundy, you have been continually interjecting. Please cease.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, it shows Senator Lundy's lack of respect for this very important issue. Sure, the Labor government spent money on the problem. Labor governments are good at spending money, aren't they? They do not fix the problem, they do not address the underlying causes of the problem and they do not even recognise the issues—but they spend money. The ALP spent $2.7 billion on labour market programs in 1995‐96, a time during which the unemployment rate rose. Fascinating, isn't it? Labor's labour market programs did not work. For example, take jobstart: in 1995 more than 50 per cent of the participants of jobstart remained unemployed three months after completing the course. I have recently had an analysis presented to me that suggests the real success rate of jobstart, when you measure it against a control group, was 28 per cent. Almost a quarter of those people had taken part in previous training programs.

BREAK.PARA: If you have ever talked to unemployed people, Senator Lundy, you would hear them talk about the training merry‐go‐round that they were on under Labor. Unemployed? Do a computer course. Done a computer course? Do a forklifting course. Done a forklifting course? Do a horticultural course. Done a horticultural course? Do a hospitality course. Done a hospitality course? Do a tourism course. That was all it was—a training merry‐go‐round. That Labor considers that it has any credibility in this debate astonishes me.

However, I would prefer to focus on the positive things our government is doing. The Democrats said it very well themselves when they said—also in their unemployment issues paper—that the Working Nation program was not about creating new jobs but reshuffling the unemployed. What an indictment!

The record of the ALP is a disgrace, as we have already covered, but who will ever forget Paul Keating—Captain Whacky—telling students to go get a job at a time when youth unemployment in this country stood at 26.6 per cent, when more than a quarter of our young people could not find work? Unemployment under Labor did not fall below nine per cent from March 1991 to November 1994. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Carr ) proposed:
That the question be now put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —When I looked at the ranks of the people who proposed this motion, when I looked at the ranks of the opposition senators who supported this motion, it was an interesting gallery of faces I saw. I was reminded of that line from the poem by Henry Lawson—
—You only have 30 seconds; give us some pearls.

—I know that Senator Bishop wishes he was in the government but he is not in the government, he is not in his place and his interjection is just as disorderly and irrelevant, if not more so, than it would have been if he had been sitting on the other side of the chamber. I was reminded of the lines by Henry Lawson when he was speaking about people locked up in gaol last century. The poem says:

SPEECH.PARA: Not the hunted look, not the guilty look,
But the awful look of the caught.
That is what the opposition are. They are the people who have been caught out on unemployment. They are the people who were caught by the electors of Australia at the last election.
Senator Bishop interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Bishop, if you wish to make a comment you should do so from your own seat. It is disorderly to make remarks at the best of times but it is more disorderly not to be in your own seat when you make them.

—They were caught out by the people of Australia at the last election because nobody in this country believed what the ALP had to say about unemployment. Unemployment was one of the reasons why the people who sit opposite sit opposite now and do not occupy the treasury bench.
—Vehemence is no substitute for substance, Senator O'Chee.

—There is a very good reason, Senator Lundy, why you have a position on the frontbench in opposition. That reason is that there are people in this country who suffer from unemployment and suffered from unemployment for year upon year of the Labor government. That is the track record of the people who sit opposite. It is a track record of unemployment and, worse still, it is a track record of indifference to the human plight of unemployment.
—Ha, ha!
—They scoff; they scoff at unemployment. The track record of a former Prime Minister was very clear.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I wonder if it would be possible to turn down the volume of the microphones a little, or at least turn the bass up so the sharpness of the voice is not there.
—Senator McKiernan, I do not think that is a point of order.

—There are none so deaf as those who will not hear and those who will not accept the judgment of the Australian people on unemployment. The judgment of the Australian people on unemployment was that the Labor Party was guilty. They sent them to gaol. They are all sitting over there—arrayed in rows, tried and convicted and sentenced to opposition—because they did not have any constructive plans for unemployment in this country. They did not have one constructive plan. Nobody on the other side can come up with a constructive plan.
—Fifty per cent unemployment in New South Wales in some areas.

—Thank you very much, Senator Heffernan. Senator Heffernan has put the record straight. Some areas of New South Wales had an unemployment record of 50 per cent. Yet the Labor Party has the audacity to come in here and accuse this government of being responsible for unemployment. This is the government, I hasten to remind people, that is trying to pick up the pieces—the legacy left behind.

BREAK.PARA: It was interesting to listen to the contribution of Senator Gibbs. She is a very nice-hearted person, but her contribution was utterly irrelevant. She was accusing this government of squandering the money that the Labor Party had saved. In their last year of office alone, their savings were negative $10 billion. They had gone into debt. This is how irrelevant the Labor Party is. They do not even know their own track record. Their track record is of massive spending for nil result. That is the legacy of the Labor Party and that is why those people sitting opposite are in opposition and are no longer on the government benches.

This government has a different view. This government believes that we have to get the economy right. One of the reasons why you will never get jobs growth while government is borrowing money is that the government is borrowing the very money that small business needs to invest, expand and grow.

TALK.START.PARA: —Piffle.

—Senator Carr says piffle. Senator Carr believes that small business is piffle. Senator Carr believes that the role of small business in creating jobs is piffle. I say to Senator Carr that Senator Carr and the Labor Party are piffle. Their policies are piffle. They have been demonstrably piffle. Senator Carr was part of the Labor Party that came up with the jobs ready strategy. The only person in Australia who was really job ready was Bill Hunter. He was ready to do a job for the Labor Party any time he was called. He was jobs ready. He did the ads for the Labor Party in the election campaign. He had been paid off.

BREAK.PARA: It was jobs for the boys but if you were not one of the boys in the Labor Party's government, you did not get a job. Isn't it interesting to note that these people now believe that unemployment is a major issue? Unemployment is less, Senator Forshaw, than when you left office. Unemployment is less now than when the Labor Party left office. They did not believe that unemployment was an issue in the last election. Oh, no, they believed that the republic was the issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was Captain Wacky.

—That was Captain Wacky and they were all the crew. They should not have been the crew; they should have been in the hold in the transport ship. They should have been the ones in chains. They were the real convicts in this whole story. They were the ones who should have been transported. Instead, they were Captain Wacky's crew. They were sailing the good ship to the light on the hill. The problem is that the light had gone out a long time ago. Look at them. They are tired and worn out. Senator Forshaw is wiping his face. He does not want to hear; he does not want to know. He does not really want to be here. It is Thursday afternoon and the only reason that we have to endure this—

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I can only take so much. I can only stomach so much, but senators are not entitled to impute improper motives. I take great offence at Senator O'Chee suggesting that I would rather be somewhere else. We have to sit here and listen to this pretender to the Poet Laureate—`The Rime of the Ancient Mariner' over here. Frankly, I think he should be directing his remarks through the chair to the issue rather than making personal attacks.
—Order! Senator Forshaw, there is no point of order. Please resume your seat. Senator O'Chee, it might be more appropriate if you direct your remarks through the chair.

—I certainly shall, Mr Acting Deputy President. You are absolutely right; there was no point of order. I had not even started to impute a motive to Senator Forshaw. Some people say that they cannot even find a motive for Senator Forshaw. When you look at Senator Forshaw, the question that springs to mind is: Why? Why are they even bothering to come in here?

BREAK.PARA: There is absolutely no purpose to the Labor opposition. There was no purpose to them when they were in government and there is absolutely no purpose to Senator Forshaw being here. He has added nothing to this debate. He has added nothing to the erudition of the frontbench of the Labor Party. If Senator Forshaw is on the frontbench for 50 years, he will do nothing for the unemployment situation of this country because these people do not have any ideas. They do not have any vision. Ben Chifley has gone, Curtin has gone and what do we have? We have the poor descendants. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In question time today I offered to provide Senator Gibbs with further information relating to a question she asked me in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. I now seek leave to incorporate this information in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—
FURTHER INFORMATION TO QUESTION BY SENATOR GIBBS ASKED ON 30 OCTOBER 1997

Senator Gibbs: How does the Government justify its proposal that parents of children in childcare who fail to provide information about a change of circumstances within 14 days are punishable by imprisonment?
Senator Herron:

As with all new legislation, the penalties are set by the Attorney-General's Department to ensure consistency with penalties for comparable offences in other legislation such as the Social Security Act.

The six month imprisonment is the maximum penalty, and is just one of the options available to the court for the offence of failing to comply with a request for information. The courts are free to opt for a non custodial penalty if a particular offence does not warrant imprisonment. It is not unreasonable to have substantial penalties as deliberate failure to provide information can lead to significant overpayments and fraud.
In most cases of failure to provide information there would be no expectation of criminal proceedings being undertaken, but payments would be appropriately corrected.
