SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the motion to take note of the Australia New Zealand Food Authority's annual report for 1996-97. It is certainly refreshing to be able to rise to discuss a most important issue—that is, public safety and food hygiene—rather than have the scenario that we witnessed only a few moments ago from Senator O'Chee who, when real business comes on, such as reports and government documents, flies the coop.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australia New Zealand Food Authority is a most important body charged with a range of functions which can be summed up in this way: it is the body responsible for ensuring the safety of food that we in Australia and New Zealand produce and consume. The functions of the authority are set out in detail in this report.

They include, for instance, reviewing the food standards code; developing nationally uniform food acts in association with the states and territories; developing nationally consistent food hygiene standards; developing nationally consistent arrangements for food surveillance and for the notification of food businesses; and reviewing food regulations. That might sound like a bit of bureaucratese but, in summary, this organisation is at the heart of ensuring public safety, and the health of the community when it comes to the food they consume and the food products that are produced in this country.

I am sure other senators are as concerned as I am—I know this issue crosses political boundaries—about the outbreaks, particularly in the last couple of years, of certain viruses associated with food products. There is an increasing concern in the Australian community about food safety.

I want to assure the Australian community that the Australia New Zealand Food Authority continues to strive to ensure the highest possible standards of food hygiene in this country. But every now and again, as we have seen in recent times, incidents arise such as the Garibaldi meat episode in South Australia and that which occurred not so long ago because of some contaminated food on an aircraft. Occasionally incidents of a serious nature arise and cause us to stop and take stock and ensure the regulations we have in place will continue to ensure that food safety, food hygiene, is maintained at a high standard.

The Australia New Zealand Food Authority is currently going through a process of restructuring. I understand legislation is to come before this chamber, if not later this year then certainly next year, which relates to future mechanisms whereby companies in Australia may be charged a fee for seeking from the Australia New Zealand Food Authority the establishment of a food standard. This is a new development and something which has never occurred in the past. We in the opposition will, when the time comes, express our concerns about that process.

BREAK.PARA: At the end of the day, food hygiene, food safety and consumer confidence are issues of public concern. They are not and should never be put into that basket of things this government seems to think should be subject to the user‐pays principle; that is, companies should not be required to pay substantial sums of money simply to make an application to the authority to have a particular food product tested and then approved if it meets the appropriate standards.

That is an issue to be debated on another occasion. I do recommend to senators that they read the annual report. It spells out in great detail the work that has been done by the authority over the last 12 months. In an era of increasing international trade and transport, this is most important work. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 October, on motion by Senator Margetts:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few remarks tonight about the report of the Nuclear Safety Bureau for the period 1 April 1997 to 30 June 1997. My interest in uranium, mining and matters that derive from them has developed from my participation in the Senate Select Committee on Uranium Mining and Milling, which gave a report some three months ago after an inquiry that went for three months and which toured a number of proposed uranium sites in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the interesting facets of that inquiry was the number of highly interesting, technical and scientific submissions made by a number of organisations, including the Nuclear Safety Bureau, the Australian Radiation Laboratories and the Office of the Supervising Scientist. The Nuclear Safety Bureau, the agency under discussion this evening, is required under the act of parliament that established it to table a report every quarter to the parliament, which it does.

The function of the Nuclear Safety Bureau is primarily twofold: firstly to monitor and review the safety of any nuclear plant owned or operated by ANSTO in this country; and, secondly, to provide technical advice to the Commonwealth on the safety of nuclear plants and related matters. The ANSTO plant in Australia consists of two nuclear reactors—firstly the HIFAR, which is an acronym for high flux Australian reactor, and Moata, which is an associated plant used in university research facilities.

In the discussion in the quarterly report on HIFAR's operations, three issues of concern arose. Firstly, the bureau reported that seven abnormal occurrences were reported to the NSB for the quarterly period under review. Those abnormal occurrences were reviewed, and it was concluded that none had any adverse safety implications. The seven abnormalities—four were due to equipment fault; one to human factors; and two were somewhat acutely described as `other', and no further detail was offered—were investigated and were designated level zero: they were of no safety significance to the Nuclear Safety Bureau and, indeed, the surrounding public community. That obviously is a pleasing development, and one hopes that that excellent record continues.

A second issue that arose from the quarterly report was the audit of radioactive discharge from the HIFAR plant. That audit review was conducted by the National Safety Bureau, Australian Radiation Laboratories and the Office of the Supervising Scientist. It analysed discharge monitoring and dose assessments that were conducted. The radiation doses to staff and public due to discharges were well within the annual limits recommended by the National Health and Medical Research Council. So the discharges that occurred were well within the official recommendations, which are based upon international standards.

There is a concern about the audit of radioactive discharge. That is, the HIFAR operation was found not to comply with the audit criteria for, firstly, the documentation of procedures and instructions and, secondly, the validation of monitoring methods. So, whilst the audit found that the discharge did not breach Australian regulations based upon international standards, it did find that the practices of the organisation in respect of the documentation of procedures and instructions and the validation of monitoring methods at best left something to be desired.

The National Safety Bureau has covered the actions proposed by ANSTO to overcome that identified deficiency, but it does not cover all of the issues raised in the audit. As a response, the National Safety Bureau has put in writing a request that an amended action plan be submitted for this agreement. One presumes that that action plan will be implemented and that further reports will be made in the quarterly reports that are tabled in this place.

The third issue that arose was the safety arrangements at Lucas Heights Science and Technology Centre. On page 5, the bureau says that it has concerns over the issue of criticality exemption certificates for facilities which contain fissile material and remains to be satisfied that the new arrangements adequately address the role of the NSB in monitoring and reviewing nuclear plants operated by ANSTO. So, once again, the report identifies a concern and issues a caution in respect of that plant located at Lucas Heights. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for consideration of government documents has expired.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee: Joint

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 October 1997, on motion by Senator Ian Campbell:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Sandy

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take note of the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on southern Africa and the government's response to the recommendations of the committee. Since the national elections in South Africa in 1993 and the lifting of sanctions in 1994, the commercial aspects of the bilateral relationship with South Africa have become the dominant element of the relationship.

SPEECH.PARA: Australians generally have a positive image of, and goodwill towards, South Africa and its President, Nelson Mandela. This has come through our connections in sport—mainly rugby and certainly cricket. Similarly, Australia is highly regarded within South Africa, particularly in the African National Congress, because of our strong stance against apartheid and especially because of the role played by former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser. Not only was he an eminent person; he had a particular connection with President Nelson Mandela. Having been there recently, I find it interesting that he visited Nelson Mandela on Robbeneiland at least twice, maybe three times, during his 27 years on the island.

Australia's wide experience on issues from public sector reform, information technology and social development to sports management are seen by the South Africans as world's best practice. Assistance has been provided in all aspects of South African life, from the management of their elections in 1993 to things that are very pertinent to both our countries, namely areas of land management. They are suffering, as we are, from the effects of El Nino.

When I was in South Africa last month, I met the minister for water resources, who was looking for particular expertise in land and water management. He made the point that he was going to approach the Murray-Darling Basin Commission to get the sort of technical assistance that was important for their development. South Africa has enormous water problems with supply to domestic users, and they are putting up about 1,000 houses a day. They also have enormous problems with land management, and they are addressing those problems. In these sorts of areas, Australia is in a position to be of assistance, and we continue to be so.

As South Africa takes its place in the international community, it will increasingly compete against Australia for commercial markets. Australian business will need to look to engage with South African business to define areas of complementary interest, particularly in the emerging third markets in southern Africa and the gulf states in Asia. A lot of Australian business goes through South Africa when it goes to other parts of Africa. This will continue to be the case. Obviously our commercial links will be strengthened because of that.

There are a number of areas of growth in the relationship which this report addresses. We have begun negotiating an extradition and mutual assistance treaty. We will begin the second round of negotiating the double tax treaty in September of this year. Those discussions are progressing pretty well. Discussions are also under way for negotiating an investment promotion and protection agreement. Our annual exports to South Africa have more than trebled over the last five years, and in 1996 they reached just under $1,000 million. South Africa is now Australia's 19th biggest export market, and significant opportunities exist for Australian exporters of materials, equipment, technology and services, education, health, mining, transport, building, processed foods, telecommunications and information technology.

The number of South African tourists visiting Australia is about 40,000, and that number is increasing all the time. Government to government cooperation continues to expand and strengthen in almost every area that is possible. South Africa continues to be a major source of skilled migrants to Australia. In the last full year where records are up to date, 3,000 people came to Australia.

We are developing an increasing dialogue with South Africa across a range of multilateral issues—for example, on disarmament, arms control and the environment. It is an important relationship. It is not a new one, but we have reached a new stage in our relationship. It is a complementary relationship. I commend the recommendations of the joint committee report, many of which have been taken up by the government. I hope that links with a fellow Commonwealth country will continue to grow.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 October, on motion by Senator Lees:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to this report as a member of the committee. I have spoken briefly to this report previously, but it seems to me that the report is one that should not be underestimated by the government and one that should be given fairly weighty consideration. The committee received a substantial number of submissions to start off with—118—and hearings took place across the width and breadth of Australia. We had submissions from various interest groups, from academics, from government and from government departments.

SPEECH.PARA: What came to my mind in hearing the evidence that came before the committee was the economic cost to our nation through marine pollution and coastal pollution. I think the costs that are involved are underestimated. When we were in Ballina, we heard evidence on the impact of acid sulfate soils leaching into the rivers and thereby destroying fish stock or making the fish that finally reached some degree of maturity totally unusable if caught for commercial or even recreational purposes. We found that the fish had a disease called red spot, which made them inedible. It attacked their flesh, under their scales. The cost to the fishermen in the area was quite substantial. In some instances, from recollection, it was estimated that up to 25 per cent of their catch would have to be thrown back as a result of the attack from the acid sulfate soils.

This is a cost to the industry. It is a cost to the fishermen in that area. It is a cost to the production. If one does not redress these problems, then one places at risk these industries in the longer term. So I was particularly interested in the economic impact that such problems hold for our society. I believe that in many instances the economic impact is not measured, because it is difficult to measure. If it is measured, it is underestimated, or it is a problem that occurs over a long period and therefore the economic impact is ignored.

This to me is one of the unfortunate aspects that I think happened in the inquiry. Whilst we recognise that there are economic downsides to marine pollution and coastal pollution, they are not well documented. Pollution does impact, though, on the outcomes in the coastal and the river communities, and it should not be underestimated. Invariably we heard evidence to the effect that, if the problem could be fixed now, it would be so much cheaper to do so than to see the problem go on for a substantial number of years and then have to expend extraordinary amounts of money to remedy the problem.

This gets down to the other issue that appealed to me in the committee inquiry, and that was the lack of base knowledge that we are in possession of to be able to test the actual degrading of our coastal river systems and our inland river systems, as well as the seas and so on. It really is something that we need to pay a great deal more attention to. Whilst we had evidence from a group in Port Phillip Bay on a very fine study that had been conducted into the Port Phillip Bay environs, and we were shown a model as to what would tip that ecosystem beyond some form of redemption and become an absolute ecological disaster, there are not a great number of these studies replicated throughout the nation.

We also saw the problem in the Derwent River. Again, part of the problem there is that we do not know when the starfish was introduced and we do not know just precisely what the state of the environment was before the starfish was introduced. We have a lack of understanding so that we can get a real measure of the extent of the disaster that we are confronted with. As I have said, this is one of my concerns arising out of the inquiry and, in particular, arising out of this report.

There were a wide range of people who appeared before us. They were not panic merchants and they were not alarmists. They were putting to us a well‐reasoned, a well‐balanced and a very coherent case as to why we should pay more attention to our marine environment, not only because we are surrounded by water but also because we depend on water. The environment is very special to us. We need to address it in a sensible, practical manner and to address the problems that are confronting us.

The other thing that was in the report was the issue of education. I have no doubt that until we can educate the people in our community—firstly, as to what the problems are; secondly, that in many instances some of them are the source of the problems; and, thirdly, that there are real remedies by reasonable practices in our society—then the problems are going to continue.

Again, it was not all disheartening in the committee's inquiry. We did have good evidence of people interested in monitoring the changing nature of the environment. Of course, the environment will just naturally change. But they were monitoring the unnecessary and degrading parts that contribute to the downgrading of our environment and, in turn, lead to some undesirable economic effects in our community. So the groups that we did hear from, the groups that we did meet, showed a real genuineness in taking the message out to the community at large. Many of them were community organisations and they showed a degree of responsibility that was second to none.

This is something the government should support as a result of the report coming before the Senate. I commend the report to the government. I understand that there are a substantial number of recommendations, because we did canvass a wide-ranging issue. I believe that a speedy response from the government showing positive action in this area is undoubtedly warranted indeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have great pleasure in following Senator Hogg in this discussion about the report on marine pollution compiled by the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee. Like him, I have a substantial interest in marine pollution—not in creating marine pollution, but in protecting against marine pollution. I should get the record absolutely correct.
—You should stick to rowing!
—Senator Conroy, don't tempt me at this hour of the night; I am trying to be charitable to you. I would have thought your being in a boat could be classified as marine pollution!

BREAK.PARA: There are a number of problems that face Australia. One of those is ballast water discharge. As Senator Hogg and others who were on the committee would know, ballast water discharge is probably the cause of entry for most of the exotic species that have entered Australian waters.

For example, we have in Port Phillip Bay toxic dinoflagellates. Toxic dinoflagellates—contrary to what some people believe—are not Democrats in swimming garb. Toxic dinoflagellates are a real danger because they can poison the shellfish and mussels and so on that are in these waters, as well as cause damage to the fish stocks. Mr Acting Deputy President, I know that you have an interest in fish—although not necessarily those in the ocean.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those as well.

—So you would understand the problems that apply to these issues. One of the problems is that, once an exotic species becomes established in Australian waters, it can move from one port to another. So the problem is a double problem. Not only is it about protecting against new species that may be brought in in ballast water from overseas, but it is also about species that have gained a foothold in Australian waters and then moved, with coastal traffic, from once place to another. That is a real problem.

BREAK.PARA: At the moment, the government has taken steps to protect against the importation of exotic species through ballast water by imposing a levy. There is a bill before the chamber—I do not want to canvass it too much—which will impose a levy on ships visiting Australia so as to create, over two years, a fund of some $2 million to study the problems of ballast water discharge and how we deal with it.

In Queensland, this is a real problem because there are some 1,100 ships that visit Queensland ports every year from overseas. Because they are bulk carriers, most of those are coming in under ballast. That is, they come to Queensland ports to pick up coal, sugar or, perhaps, alumina. So they constitute a threat to us because they must necessarily come in under ballast—and how they dispose of that ballast water is a real problem.

Consider the millions and millions of tonnes of ballast water discharged in Queensland coastal waters close to the Barrier Reef every single year from those 1,100 ships. That is a real problem for the environment of Queensland—and I think Senator Hogg understands that problem, which is why he has taken an interest in the matter—but it also represents the possibility of species moving from one place to another.

What I heard recently—and this alarmed me—is that some of these species in warm water may not immediately become apparent. In colder water, I understand, you soon find out when a species becomes established.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's why your research base is important.

—Yes, exactly. But in warmer waters we have another problem, Senator Hogg, which is this: it is my understanding that a species can come in—especially algae and bacteria, and so on—and lie dormant in the mud in warm water for a period of years, until it mutates itself into a form which can thrive in that particular environment. That is really worrying because it means that we do not actually know what may be lying in the sediment of some of our ports in Queensland. That is why it is dreadfully urgent—as honourable senators on both sides who participated in the inquiry would be aware—that we do something about this. So, as I said, I am pleased to see that the government has put in place a mechanism to generate some $2 million in funds to research the problem.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Hogg has also raised the question of run-off, especially from acid sulfate soils. This is a real problem because, in Queensland, on the Gold Coast, for example, the acid sulfate run-off is caused by housing develop ments. On the Gold Coast hinterland, it is caused by exposing the soils, as they are being exposed, for housing developments. People see run-off as being a problem which arises out of farming or out of factories. But run-off problems occur from clearing land for houses.

On top of that—not related to acid sulfate soils—you also have run-off problems because people do not understand that the water that goes down the kitchen sink does not go down the same drain as does the sewage from the toilet; they think it all gets treated at a sewage treatment plant. Often what goes down the kitchen sink or gets put out into the gutter goes down the stormwater drain and empties directly into a creek. People do not seem to understand that, when they put food scraps, for example, down a garbage disposal unit in their kitchen, they are contributing to nutrient levels in our creeks, our rivers and our coastal waters. Those nutrient levels are very dangerous—very dangerous to the fish that are out there; very dangerous to all life in those waters.

It is not that people want to destroy their environment; it is just that I do not think we do a good enough job of educating people as to how they have to protect our environment. Everybody has a role to play in this; everybody can actually do something about it. When I first discovered that what I put down the kitchen sink did not go to the sewage treatment plant but instead ended up in the stormwater drain, I ceased to put food down the kitchen sink. It does not take much extra effort. All it means is that when you finish cooking, or whatever, you put your waste into a bag and it goes in the garbage bin; you just do not wash it down the sink. That way, you do your bit to ensure that we do not increase nutrient levels in coastal waters.

I would take time at this point to pay tribute to the Surfrider Foundation, which basically is a marine based environmental group that has done a lot of work on this issue. Surfrider is synonymous with issues to do with the surf; but it is also involved in issues to do with our coastal creeks and rivers. At Surfrider they understand that, if you do not clean up those creeks and rivers, refuse ultimately ends up in the ocean.

For example, on the Gold Coast, the Surfrider Foundation has been involved in a rehabilitation of Loders Creek, which has seen an area which was utterly devastated turned into something which is now supporting a community of native wildlife of birds and fish. Loders Creek had a large number of stormwater drains running into it; by rehabilitating it and educating the people in the area, they started to solve some of the problems. That, I believe, is one of the challenges: education is one of the challenges in protecting the environment.

I think, ultimately, that there has been immense damage done to the marine environment of this country. But, because it is not easily demonstrated, because it is not trees being chopped down, because it is not topsoil being eroded away, people do not really understand the damage that has been done. We have real problems occasionally because there are pressures on coastal land, particularly in Queensland and New South Wales—pressures from development. The question is always: how do you maintain a sufficient number of mangroves to support the breeding of fish populations to support fishing industries? Isn't it interesting, Mr Acting Deputy President, that recreational and commercial fishermen these days are people who have an interest in supporting a reasonable number of mangrove areas so that we can maintain fish populations.As Senator Hogg may well know, the area of Cleveland used to be a great area to go fishing. I remember when I was a boy, we used to go fishing down on the old jetty at Cleveland—

TALK.START.PARA: —You still are.

—But it is not as good as it used to be, Senator Hogg, and that is because there has been a depletion of the fish stocks in some parts of Moreton Bay. I hope that in 10 or 20 years time we will be able to say that it is as good as it was before, that it is better because we have taken the appropriate steps. I think the committee should be commended on the work it has done on this report. I think it will be of great assistance to the government, and it adds to our understanding of the problems.

BREAK.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund Committee

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 October, on motion by Senator Ferris:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —I must admit in the very beginning that I have not had the opportunity yet to read all of this report. I have glanced through the executive summary and the executive summary of the minority committee report that is contained in the report itself.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, I wish to pay tribute to all members of the committee—and I do mean all members of the committee. I have had a look at the itinerary that the committee engaged itself in and at the number of witnesses it heard over a very short period of time. It was a committee investigation that should have gone over an extended period of time, perhaps allowing many more individuals to appear before the committee, but it certainly crammed a lot of work into a very short period of time.

In commending all members of the committee from all sides of the parliament, I also make reference to the support staff here in Canberra and those who accompanied the committee in its travels around Australia, particularly those who had the task of writing up the report. Obviously it is a great tribute to them that the report was actually tabled in this parliament this week. I think it was tabled on Monday in the other place and later in the week in this chamber. So everybody needs to be congratulated on a job well done.

The report itself is quite divided, as we all know, and I do not think that it was any surprise to anybody that the committee would hand down a majority report and at least a minority report, and maybe even more than one minority report. For that reason, I found Senator Abetz's remarks on Monday evening extraordinary when he criticised his govern ment's decision to make a concession to the opposition and Democrat members of the committee that they would have specific secretarial support throughout the course of the inquiry, and also in developing the minority report. I think there was a great expectation—a certainty rather than an expectation—that there would be a minority report.

On Monday evening, Senator Abetz sought to make capital out of that. If the good senator is criticising the decision, he is actually criticising the decision of his own government because it was his own government that made the decision; it was not something that we the opposition, the Democrats or any other political party did from this side of the chamber. So I do find it an extraordinary criticism.

It does happen from time to time in committees of this parliament, particularly in Senate committees, that the politics are able to be put to one side and a consensus opinion can be reached. Consensus can sometimes be reached even though opinions come from separate and quite diverse ranges: quite the opposite opinion can be put forward, but the recognition by the proponents of a softer line that they can learn from what the harder line is can be quite good, productive and constructive in the interests of the community as a whole. We will have to wait until debate on the bill concludes some time next month in this chamber to see whether or not that will be the case, and whether or not the government will indeed accept some of the many recommendations that are contained in the minority report of the committee.

Before I talk in detail about the minority report, I want to return to the comment that Senator Abetz made on Monday evening during the adjournment debate when he talked in his concluding remarks about the possibility of a deal being done during negotiations in 1993 on the Native Title Act. I will just quote a small part of what Senator Abetz had to say:

. . . I do not think he would believe, nor would the National Farmers Federation these days, that they were in fact taken in and consulted to the extent that the Labor Party would now have us believe. The question then is, what about the mining industry?
He then goes on about other things.

BREAK.PARA: I want to address the matter of the deal very briefly, drawing the attention of Senator Abetz—who is, incidentally, a member of the committee—to remarks made by the President of the National Farmers Federation, Mr Donald McGauchie, when he appeared before the committee. He said:

The fact of the matter was that we had what we thought was an understanding. Clearly, in law, that understanding was not there. Now we can go over this and over this and over this. The fact of the matter is we were dudded by the fine print, and we acknowledge that . . . I accept we were wrong. You can spend the rest of the day, Daryl, telling us we were wrong. Don't bother, because I will tell you that I understand we were wrong. We were done by the fine print, and that is that, but I will tell you we are not going to be that dumb again.

Those are the words contained in the report attributed to Mr McGauchie, the President of the National Farmers Federation. Again, I found it extraordinary that Senator Abetz, a member of the committee, could so mislead himself on the matter of a deal in 1993.

I believe the minority report, as contained in the report itself, is—and attempts to be—constructive to the Native Title Act. Very early, the minority report accepts that the Native Title Act 1993 is in need of amendment. It gives reasons and cites court cases to follow up on that point. Nevertheless, in its criticism of the Native Title (Amendment) Bill 1997, it goes on to say that this bill goes well beyond the requirements of those amendments.

The minority report suggests that the Native Title (Amendment) Bill 1997 rides roughshod over issues which are currently before the courts of this country and provides resolutions which uniformly favour the respondents in the case. The minority report argues that the bill denies procedural fairness to indigenous people who proceed to a court resolution of their claims. It suggests that the bill makes wholesale assertions about permanent extinguishment by a complex range of legislative and regulatory instruments where analysis of the full schedule of the bill turns up numerous instances where no such extinguishment can be sustained by reference to the facts.

The minority report suggests that the bill is incompatible with both the spirit and the letter of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975. The minority report says that the bill makes a mockery of Australia's responsibilities as a signatory to the International Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Racial Discrimination. I will be reading the report in total, including the minority report. I hope to be making a more detailed contribution to the debate on the Native Title (Amendment) Bill when it is debated in this place some time next month.

In the interim period, I hope that some of the heat which is currently in the debate is damped down a bit. That heat was, I might say, increased by some acts in the other place yesterday when certain members of a certain political party sought to amend the bill further. There are many in our community who are hoping for a fair and just resolution to the issue of native title in Australia. I believe the bill the parliament has in front of it does not and will not allow for a fair and just settlement, but I hope we can go some way toward achieving that during the debate on the bill next month.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 October, on motion by Senator Conroy:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief, but I think it is worth making a comment, seeing that I come from a background where, for election to office, I have been subject to the requirements of the act over a long period of time.

SPEECH.PARA: As people know, I had the position of branch secretary within the Shop Distributive and Allied Employees' Association. As the Branch Secretary of the Queensland branch of that association, I and many other officials were subject to regular elections. I do not believe that many people are cognisant of the fact that people who occupy honorary and also full‐time positions within the trade union movement and federally registered or state registered organisations are subject to election by the rank and file of those organisations. I was subject to rank and file ballots over a lengthy period of time.

One of the things that was always pleasing was the efficiency with which any election was conducted by the Australian Electoral Commission, but there was always one problem. That problem, alluded to in this report, is the problem of being in the position of supplying to the Australian Electoral Commission the correct addresses for members.

One of the things I found in my lengthy period of time as a trade union official—and I am sure it is a problem for many people in many other facets of the community—is how mobile the Australian population is. I had the pleasure of being the secretary of a union of some 30,000‐35,000 members, and there were invariably between about 1,500 and 1,600 people for whom one never had the correct address. No matter what steps one took to try to secure the correct address from people, it was a very difficult task indeed. It is amazing to think how many times Australians must shift from one place to another without ever letting anyone know they have moved. It is really surprising. One becomes very aware of this when one is trying to conduct a ballot in conjunction with the Australian Electoral Commission.

Any step that can improve the conduct of the ballot is undoubtedly welcome. The practice in my organisation, even prior to recommendation 3 coming down in this report on industrial elections, was always to provide the Australian Electoral Commission with the only other alternative address that was ever available to us, and that was the place of work. That proved to be a way of communicating with these people, but more often than not one found that the people for whom you did not have a correct address had invariably left the industry. Whilst this seeks to redress the problem, in the end it may well be a problem that is fairly hard to fix, even at the best of times.

The other thing that I was pleased to see was that the conduct of the elections would still be done at no cost to the organisation itself. It should be clear to everyone that it is welcome that someone independent of the organisation has the conduct of the election. That puts the officials of the organisation above and beyond reproach or criticism.

As I said, as a former full‐time official of the organisation, and even now still a part‐time honorary official, I think the system is important so that the rank and file members of these organisations are aware that the officers who are elected to the peak of their organisations are elected in a fair and proper manner, and that those eligible to vote have fair and adequate opportunity to participate in any ballot to see that they have the leadership that will give them a positive and forward‐thinking organisation. I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative on the following orders of the day without further debate during consideration of committee reports and government responses:
Community Affairs Legislation Committee—Report entitled: Review of the Health Legislation (Private Health Insurance Reform) Amendment Act 1995 —Government response. (Senator Brownhill )
Economics Rererences Committee—Report—Outworkers in the garment industry. (Senator Hogg )

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! As consideration of committee reports and government responses has now concluded, I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —In November last year the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) told the parliament that everyone should look objectively at the process of assessing applications for the importation of chicken meat. I agree, but the process must also be open and complete. The assessment process must be transparent, with the industry an active party in that process. Most importantly, the process must be complete, and be seen to be complete, before any final decision is made on this important matter. The government owes the industry and the public nothing less and yet the quarantine risk assessment has not been open and is far from complete.

SPEECH.PARA: A key part of the AQIS process is a public health risk assessment undertaken by the Australia New Zealand Food Authority. ANZFA commenced work on this assessment in 1994. My office was advised by the office of the parliamentary secretary responsible for ANZFA that assessment had been completed and was considered by the ANZFA council members last Tuesday. I have now been informed, by Minister Anderson's office, that the report is still in draft form and is not available. I can understand the minister's reluctance to release this report given his sorry history on this issue, but this report must be released and exposed to proper scrutiny. The industry and the public deserve no less.

The public health risk assessment is clearly a vital part of this whole process. It is an area of concern for both the chicken industry and Australian consumers. I do not have to remind the Senate of the numerous incidents, unfortunately some resulting in death, of food borne diseases in Australia. We cannot afford to take any chances in this regard.

The government has quite rightly progressed the development of hazard analysis and critical control points systems, known as HACCP systems, in the meat processing sector and elsewhere. There is currently a pilot scheme operating with a comprehensive evaluation process. The minister has discussed this process with his counterparts in both the USA and Japan. There is an international panel of experts overseeing the process. It is a sophisticated process involving a scientific, objective statistical analysis of both the old and the new systems. An AQIS vet is on site all the time, there have been monthly reviews by a senior AQIS vet and spot audits conducted.

Getting a proper HACCP system in place is a lengthy and sophisticated process—and that is how it should be. We are entitled to expect a rigorous approach when it comes to food hygiene, not only in our own processing industries but also in those industries in countries seeking to export product to us. I am happy to report that this is the position adopted by AQIS, the relevant Commonwealth authority.
ANZFA recently informed the Senate estimates hearing:
AQIS advised ANZFA that imported chicken and pig meat products may only be sourced from AQIS certified establishments where a detailed, audited HACCP system is in operation.

We fully endorse that position on this side of the chamber. It is important to note that the requirement is for a detailed, audited HACCP system. That standard can only be properly satisfied for imported chicken meat in an initial inspection of all processing plants proposing to send product here. A regime of regular spot audits by qualified AQIS officers is also required.

In answer to a question taken on notice from Senator Bob Collins, the government advised that an officer from AQIS visited Thailand in 1990 and inspected chicken processing plants in that country. Senator Bob Collins was advised that none of the plants visited had HACCP systems in place. He asked whether, on a second trip to Thailand by the same officer earlier this year, there were any HACCP systems in place in the chicken processing plants visited. The answer stated:
HACCP systems were not in place in any of the plants.

Based on the advice to the Senate from ANZFA and AQIS and the standards the government has set for the implementation and management of HACCP systems in Australia, it would appear that no product can be sourced from Thailand in the near future. A draft report from that second visit to Thailand has been with the minister for some time. It has not yet been provided to the parliament or the Australian industry but has been provided to the Thai authorities. An industry representative went on that trip and I understand she has sighted the document but has not been allowed to have a copy. The industry and this parliament are entitled to a copy of that report.

A similar assessment process must be made of plants in the USA and Denmark. I would remind the Senate that a proper inspection of all plants in all countries prior to any approval for chicken imports into Australia was recommended by the unanimous Senate committee report on this matter. No approval should be given until inspections of plants in the USA and Denmark have been undertaken and parliament and the industry are satisfied that plants in those countries can meet the high standards this government is imposing on our domestic meat processing sector.

There is one other important matter that I wish to raise tonight, and that is the relevance of the Australian food standards code to this matter. This is the code against which all food is assessed. My colleague Senator Forshaw asked a question about the provisions of the code in relation to cooked chicken and cooked pig meat. Senator Forshaw was told that there are currently no relevant microbiological specifications in the food standards code covering chilled cooked product. ANZFA advised that it planned to set specifications for chilled product as part of its public health risk assessment process. It stated that the specifications would be in addition to those for frozen product but would only apply to imported product, not domestic product.

If there is a weakness in the food standards code then it must be fixed. It must be fixed properly and must apply to both domestic and imported product. The Australia New Zealand Food Authority Act lays out a proper and open process which the authority must follow if it is to vary the national food standards code. I am not aware that this process has been followed to correct this weakness in the code. But there must be an amendment to the code before any approval is given to allow imported chicken onto the Australian market. And proper process must be followed, that is, an open and complete process that provides for public input.

It is important to remember that the Australian chicken industry is worth in the order of $2 billion a year. It employs, directly and indirectly, nearly 70,000 Australians, mainly in regional centres—areas where employment opportunities are limited. This industry is one of the success stories in Australia. It has grown steadily in terms of production, jobs and investment. It continues to improve its competitiveness both domestically and internationally, and it has looked to value add, and that means more jobs in regional Australia.

The minister still has a lot to do before he can properly consider applications to import cooked chicken meat into Australia. Firstly, the public health risk assessment undertaken by ANZFA must be released for proper consideration by all interested parties. Secondly, the government must satisfy itself, the industry and Australian consumers that proper hygiene standards—through a certified, detailed, audited HACCP system—are in place in all plants seeking to export product. Thirdly, until the Australian foods standard code is amended to ensure that appropriate microbiological specifications are in place for chilled cooked chicken meat, these applications should not be approved. Given the unanimous nature of the all‐party Senate committee report on this issue, I would expect the minister's backbench colleagues on the other side of the chamber to heartily endorse our position on this vital matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise during this adjournment debate to inform the Senate of a story of courage in the face of adversity; I think that is the best way I can describe it. It is a story of a remarkable young woman who is raising both awareness and money in support of the 2000 Paralympic Games. I am referring to Sue‐Ellen Lovett, a member of the Australian paralympic equestrian team, who is also actually on the board of the Sydney Paralympic Games. Sue‐Ellen's achievements and those of other remarkable athletes have ensured that the Sydney Paralympic Games in the year 2000 will receive the sort of recognition they deserve. According to a survey conducted by Woolcott Research, interest in attending the Sydney Paralympic Games has increased to over 25 per cent. Similarly, the likelihood of attending the Paralympic Games has risen to nine per cent. Supporting the underdog is a great Australian tradition, and I only hope that both awareness and interest will grow as Australians gain the Olympic spirit in the lead‐up to the games. Sue‐Ellen represented Australia in the 1996 Paralympic Games in Atlanta in dressage. She has won many awards for her fundraising efforts and is currently the No. 1 ranked rider in Australia by the International Paralympic Equestrian Committee. In 1995 she won both the Australian stock horse national high points horse and the high points dressage horse of Australia. She competes regularly throughout Australia, most recently in dressage at the Royal Easter Show, and gave a dressage demonstration at the Trivett Classic. She is an Australia Day ambassador and has been the recipient of numerous honours, including an Australian Achiever award, the Bicentennial Medal, the Advance Australia award, a New South Wales Premier's award and the Equestrian Federation of Australia Award of Excellence.

SPEECH.PARA: These achievements are beyond the reach of most of us in the community, but are even more remarkable when we consider the hardships that Sue‐Ellen has had to endure throughout her lifetime. At the age of 13, Sue‐Ellen was diagnosed with retinitis pigmentosa, commonly known as tunnel vision, and she currently has only about three per cent residual vision. This is matched by the tragic circumstances of those closest to her: her mother also has the disease, as does her sister, who has only about 30 per cent of her sight left. And, if this was not enough, her brother had an unfortunate accident and is an amputee.

Rather than dwell on her misfortune, as well she might have, Sue‐Ellen uses it as a source of great strength. She also manages to see the amusing side—if there is one—of her plight. For instance, in a recent media story she said:

When I was younger I used to ride cross‐country as well as compete in show jumping and dressage. It was really funny when I was show jumping because everyone who came to watch the blind girl jump would hold their breath and pray.

Sue‐Ellen's most recent venture was a 38‐day ride during September and October this year to raise funds and public awareness for the Paralympics. During this venture she was in the saddle, sometimes by 6 or 7 o'clock in the morning, riding for 12 or 13 hours a day. Often she would attend fundraising functions in the evening after an entire day in the saddle. Logistically, she has a sighted guide riding out in front of her, telling her in which direction to ride, and she has got a wonderful guide dog who follows in the back‐up truck.

Her ride from Melbourne to Sydney via Canberra covered a total distance of 1,455 kilometres and she did it at 85 kilometres a day—that is no mean feat. En route she visited 54 towns, hamlets and cities, attending more than 70 civic and community functions. Some of the New South Wales towns she passed through included my home town of Wagga Wagga, Adelong, Tumut, Gundagai, Yass, Moss Vale and Bowral. In fact, I was actually due to accompany her from The Rock to Wagga on a ride—we had planned to ride separate horses, I must hasten to add—but unfortunately the weather foiled our plans and I was not able to join her. I do hope to join her for part of the rides she undertakes in the future.

Sue‐Ellen literally has taken across the whole countryside her vision of the biggest Paralympics ever in the year 2000. In doing so, she has demonstrated the sort of personal courage and determination to triumph over adversity that is associated, I believe, with people on the land. This personal courage and determination is matched only by her depth of community spirit. For instance, during an earlier ride this year called Ride To Save Lives, she raised enough funds to install helipads at Mudgee, Gulgong and Rylstone hospitals. Her most recent ride through country New South Wales was part of an integrated communications and fundraising campaign for the Sydney 2000 Paralympics called Rides 2000. The program offers a unique opportunity to raise community awareness of, and interest in, the Paralympics.

We are all very excited about the Olympics in Sydney in the year 2000 but we cannot forget these wonderful people who compete in the Paralympics. It is an ideal opportunity to raise the profile and status of Paralympic athletes and sports men and women and to achieve substantial media awareness and coverage at a regional, national and international level.

Sue‐Ellen has done her ride from Melbourne to Sydney. She is going to go from Brisbane to Sydney. On another one she is going to go from Adelaide to Sydney, and the Ride 2000 is from Moree to Sydney. I hope I can join her some time before the ride from Moree to Sydney.

Sue‐Ellen's achievements are both a personal victory and a victory for all Paralympic athletes. We are certainly hoping that her efforts will generate greater crowds and interest in the Paralympics. This sort of effort is matched by the Sydney Organising Committee for the Paralympic Games approving the inclusion of a number of new disciplines and events for the games. As recommended by the International Paralympic Executive Committee, the programs will now include programs for people with intellectual disabilities—outstanding athletes in their own right—in areas such as athletics and basketball. There will be amputee events in cycling; powerlifting will include weight categories for women; rugby is getting some additional teams; and in swimming and table tennis those with an intellectual disability are going to be included.

These additions are a stark reminder of just how far the Paralympic Games have come since they were first held in Rome in 1960 with only 400 athletes competing at that time, representing 23 countries. Until 1972, Paralympic events were limited to athletes with spinal cord injuries. Today's modern technology and the continuing determination of these athletes have made the Paralympics an event with thousands of competitors including the blind, paraplegics, quadriplegics, people with cerebral palsy, amputees and others. The Paralympic Games in Atlanta boasted some 4,000 athletes, 1,000 coaches and team staff, 1,500 officials, technical personnel, the Paralympic Family and about 15,000 volunteers.

I think this country has a very proud record. Australia's record in the Paralympics is truly phenomenal. Just listen to this: in Seoul in 1988 Australia scooped just 14 medals; eight years later in Atlanta our medal tally was 106, comprising 42 gold, 37 silver and 27 bronze medals. The sports in which the paralympians particularly excelled were swimming, athlet ics, cycling, basketball, lawn bowls and tennis.

I have not given a long catalogue of these achievements just for the sake of saying it. I am saying to the Senate and to all of those listening to this broadcast that Sue‐Ellen Lovett's achievements are truly an inspiration. Her vision to hold the best‐ever Paralympic Games in Sydney is something we can all take part in and can all achieve. Her strength of character and the strength of character of the other paralympians is something that will inspire all of us. Her recent comments about her love of horseriding suggest her dogged determination. I will finish with this quote, and I look forward to her future ventures:
When I began to lose my sight people did say I should give up riding horses, but nobody should ever tell you what to do. You're the master of your own destiny.
Congratulations, Sue‐Ellen, and to all the other outstanding paralympians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferris, Sen Jeannie

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to support our government's efforts to improve the accountability of the social security system and to reduce fraud. Nothing can be more unfair to the Australian community than to be financing a welfare safety net for people who are not genuinely entitled to it. I previously spoke on this issue in February of this year. At that time this government's commitment to improving the social security assistance system had already resulted in estimated savings of more than $10 million every single week. At that time the savings in South Australia were $1 million per week.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) has now revealed that even more savings can be made from previously undetected welfare fraud. These new figures show that taxpayers will now save a staggering $28 million a week as a result of a more efficiently applied social security compliance program. In South Australia there will be savings of $2.3 million per week—up more than 100 per cent on the figures revealed just last February. Almost 270,000 reviews have been carried out across the state of South Australia by the Department of Social Security and this has resulted in the identification of more than 30,000 cases of overpayment in South Australia alone.

Importantly, more than $20 million worth of debts have been recovered from 28,000 individuals. These are people who have put their own welfare ahead of the wider community, which has been wrongly funding them. These updated figures are further evidence of the absolutely disgraceful inefficiency in the application of the welfare safety net by the previous government. It is worth recalling that the former Minister for Social Security, Mr Baldwin, boasted in 1995 that Australia was leading the world in social security compliance. In October 1994, as minister, he said:
The government has implemented a range of measures to ensure that social security payments are properly targeted to those in need.

And three years later, in South Australia alone, we have found $2.3 million worth of savings every week. It is almost impossible to comprehend that there could be so many of our fellow South Australians abusing the privilege of the social security safety net.
Very clearly, Labor had a standard of targeting payments different from this government. As we can now see, they made money available to the greedy as well as the needy. What a disgrace.

TALK.START.PARA: —John Elliott can walk free.

—Senator Conroy, I hope you are not defending these people. The previous government sat on its hands when it came to welfare fraud and the taxpayers of Australia paid the cost. This is another clear example of Labor's economic neglect. Our election commitment promised to take all possible steps to prevent fraud and to ensure that only those who are eligible under the Social Security Act could actually receive payment. In South Australia, 40 per cent of the community receive social security payments—almost 578,000 individuals. They receive payments totalling $15½ billion every year. This is the largest percentage of any Australian state population in receipt of these benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: Minister Newman's report tabled in this place yesterday revealed that more than three million compliance reviews have now been conducted—up by 27.6 per cent on 1995-96. There have been 333,000 payment cancellations or reductions identified. This is an increase of 40 per cent on 1995-96. This all adds up to ongoing savings of $28 million per week. Some targeting, Mr Baldwin. What a wonderful windfall for the thousands of honest taxpaying Australians—a saving of $28 million every week. And what a clear fulfilment of this government's election promise to take all possible steps to uncover fraud in the social security system.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission: Appeals

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney‐General, upon notice, on 27 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the answer to Senate question on notice no. 576 (Official Senate Hansard , 28 August 1997, page 6005), and specifically paragraph (5) which reveals that there are presently five matters which have been appealed by the Commonwealth from decisions of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (HREOC) and that to date $40,634 has been expended by the Commonwealth on matters being appealed by the Commonwealth:
(1) What is the substance of the Commonwealth's appeal in each of these matters.
(2) What question of law is being determined in each case.
(3) In what jurisdiction is each of these cases being appealed.
(4) Why has the Commonwealth appealed each of these cases.
(5) Can a copy be provided of the Commonwealth's submissions in each case.
(6) On whose recommendation and/or advice has the Commonwealth appealed these cases and can a copy of that advice be provided.
(7) How much money has the Commonwealth earmarked for each of these appeals.
(8) Who pays the legal costs where HREOC is a party of these appeals.
(9) Do legal costs come from HREOC's budget; if so, what percentage of HREOC's budget has been spent in defending appeals initiated by the Commonwealth.
(10) What are the grounds of judicial review or policy grounds for appealing each of these cases having regard to the circumstances of each case.
(11) Does the Commonwealth `cap' the money it will spend in appealing cases from HREOC; if so, what is the cap.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney‐General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am advised by the office of the Australian Government Solicitor that only two of the five matters in which the Commonwealth has filed an application for judicial review of HREOC decisions remain current. The following three matters have now been finalised:
(i) Secretary, Department of Defence v HREOC & Messrs Burgess, Collins & Lipping.
(ii) Commonwealth of Australia and Minister for Health v Morrish & Ors.

PARA.TAB: On 18 July 1997, the Commonwealth's appeal was upheld by the Federal Court, and the decision of HREOC set aside. The matter was remitted to a differently constituted Commission, but the complaints have since been withdrawn and the matter finalised.

ANSWER.PARA: (iii) Commonwealth of Australia v HREOC & Aufgang.

PARA.TAB: The appeal to the Federal Court was resolved by consent. The parties agreed to set aside the HREOC decision and remit the matter to a differently constituted Commission for reconsideration.

ANSWER.PARA: The following applications remain current:
(i) Commonwealth of Australia v HREOC & Roger Muller;
(ii) Commonwealth of Australia v HREOC & Jeff Kellan.

These application concern different determinations made under the Public Service Act 1922, but involve the same legal issues. In each case, HREOC found that the current respondents were discriminated against on the ground of sexual preference. The respondents had claimed allowances in respect of their same sex partners. One case involved an overseas living allowance, the other a remote area allowance. The Commonwealth submitted that the respondents were not entitled to the allowances under the relevant determinations, made under the Public Service Act, and the allowances had not been denied on the ground of sexual preference.

(2) The question of law are the same in both cases; first, whether HREOC adopted and applied a construction of the term `spouse' which was inconsistent with the definitions of the term in the relevant determinations; second, whether HREOC misconstrued provisions of the Public Service Act; third, whether HREOC erred in failing to hold that the determinations did not discriminate on the ground of sexual preference; and fourth, whether HREOC erred in finding that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986 applied to indirect as well as direct discrimination.
(3) Both applications for judicial review were filed in the Federal Court of Australia.

(4) The Commonwealth is seeking judicial review in each case, because the Commission has made, in the view of the Commonwealth, errors of law and its decision has widespread implications for the administration of other Public Service determinations.
(5) The Commonwealth's submissions have not yet been prepared.

(6) I have been advised that the Australian Government Solicitor and Counsel provided advice on whether the decisions contained errors of law and on the prospects of success if an application for judicial review were filed. The advice is subject to legal professional privilege. As with any litigant in the same position, the Commonwealth would claim that waiver of this privilege by release of the advice would risk prejudicing the advancement of its interest in the outstanding case, and therefore declines release.
(7) no specific amount has been earmarked.

(8) In each case, HREOC has only made a `submitting' appearance—that is, at the beginning of the case, the HREOC Commissioner concerned declared that he or she will abide by the Court's decision (whatever that will be), and take no active part in the case. Therefore, any costs incurred by HREOC should be minimal, and would be met by HREOC, for monies appropriated to fund its operations.

(9) As mentioned in answer to Question 8, HREOC would pay any legal costs form monies appropriated to it to fund its operations. Also, as stated in my answer to Question 8, HREOC has submitted to the jurisdiction of the Court in the current cases and, therefore, its costs should be minimal.

(10) The grounds for judicial review in the present case concern the questions of law referred to in answer to Question 2. The policy grounds for instituting these appeals are referred to in answer to Question 4.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 4 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government any initiatives in place, or under consideration, to improve the movement of passengers into and out of Australia; if so, what are they and what consultations have been had with other government agencies, the tourism industry and the aviation industry on this matter.

(2) Is there any evidence to suggest that passengers entering and leaving Australia find the current immigration, customs and quarantine requirements onerous; if so, what is the nature of this evidence.

(3) (a) What information sources does the department use to compile statistics on the origin and destination of passengers entering and leaving Australia; and (b) do other government agencies use different sources; if so, what.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Ministerial Committee for the Sydney 2000 Games is currently examining important initiatives to improve the border processing of passengers through Australia's international airports in the lead up to and for the Games. The key initiatives are:

‐ the progressive expansion of Advance Passenger Information systems which capture data on passengers electronically and which will reduce processing times at international airports from an average 55 seconds to around 20 seconds; and
‐ reengineering the process by which key border management and other statistical data is collected so as to eliminate as much paper handling as possible.

Ministers established a group of officials to develop these initiatives. The group includes representatives of the border agencies and major users of passenger data, including the Department of Transport and Regional Development, the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the Office of National Tourism, the Bureau of Tourism Research and the Australian Tourist Commission. Consultations were held with representatives of the airlines which provided written submissions.

These initiatives are in addition to those announced by the Government on 16 May which include a $350 million extension of the international terminal and streaming Australian nationals through dedicated customs lanes to cut processing times by an expected 10% after dynamic signage is installed at Sydney Airport before the end of the year.

(2) Yes. An inwards passenger must present, in addition to a passport, a passenger card and a Travellers Statement. Passengers are obliged to answer up to thirty questions relating to their entry on two separate forms. Some of the information on these forms, particularly the passenger card, duplicates that already held in visa computer systems. An outwards passenger must present a passport, a boarding pass and a passenger card which again duplicates some information already held on computer systems and requires a passenger to answer up to eighteen questions.

The collection and checking of these forms has a direct impact on the time taken to process passengers through airports depending on whether the forms are fully completed by the passenger, the legibility of their hand writing, their English language skills and their understanding of the questions. Although there are templates available at Australian airports to assist non English‐speaking passengers, Customs officers spend considerable time checking the forms for completeness and accuracy.
(3) (a) The Department of Transport and Regional Development uses data that is sourced from passenger cards to establish the origin and destination of international air travellers.

(b) The Department is not aware of any government agencies using alternative sources for origin/destination information. However, the Ministers' group of officials has under investigation alternative sources of information currently obtained from passenger cards.
