ALL STAFF
AGREEMENT MAKING WITHIN THE DEPARTMENT

The Department needs to consider our agreement making options under the Workplace Relations Act. I am interested in finding out your views on the way in which we should approach this task. The attached paper has been prepared so as to open all relevant issues for discussion and consideration. The thrust of the paper is about both the parameters of what we want to negotiate, and how we will go about the process.

We are not obliged by the Government to undertake any agreement making process. However, the bottom line is that agreements under the Workplace Relations Act are the only way in which we will be able to (firstly) maintain, and then advance conditions of employment within the Department. Therefore we must make a decision on this issue; bearing in mind the need to benefit people in the Department, and at the same time enable the organisation to move forward, and better serve the Government of the day.

The Workplace Relations Act and the prospective new Public Service Act both provide us with significant flexibility to create an employment framework which supports our corporate goals. We are able to use this legislation to facilitate agreements which can meet the specific needs of our organisation. I am keen to take advantage of this flexibility to produce a set of employment conditions which is attractive to current and future employees and enables the Department to meet the challenges of the next few years.

My preference at this stage is for one Certified Agreement which will cover the entire Department. I am happy to talk with unions, and to maintain the strong relationship we have developed. However, I need to know your views before progressing any further; this needs to be a collective arrangement.

This paper outlines those parameters around which I would like to approach agreement making within the Department. None of the details are set in concrete; these will be developed in consultation, and I would appreciate you passing any preliminary comments you may have to the Workplace Relations Unit on Cox Level 2.

In addition to this discussion paper, the Workplace Relations Unit will be holding an initial series of information sessions (in Canberra and each region) which will commence at the end of July. I encourage all staff to attend (details of the sessions are at Attachment A).
In the meantime, if you have any questions, please contact any of the following people in the first instance: Brendan Pigott (274 6631), Graeme Pulford (274 6576) or Alice Lau (274 7055).
Allan Hawke
SECRETARY
July 1997
Department of Transport and Regional Development
Agreement making—proposed parameters

The following are the proposed parameters against which the Department will approach the development of agreements under the Workplace Relations Act. They do not represent a firm negotiating stance, rather, an outline for a suggested starting point from which discussions can proceed. Each of the individual parameters is expanded upon in the attached paper.

1. The Department's preferred approach is for one departmental Certified Agreement, with provision made in that agreement for Australian Workplace Agreements for staff, eg, the SES, Senior Officers or specialist staff. The agreement will operate for at least 18 months from certification.
2. A senior management team will be set up to negotiate agreements on behalf of the Department, with support from a working group within People & Technology.

3. Considering the nature of our relationship with the various unions, the Department intends to use these established lines of communication in negotiating agreements. Additionally, individuals or groups may contact the management team to discuss the possibility of negotiating separately. All staff will be kept informed of progress with developing agreements so each employee can consider their interests and participation.

4. Within the context of a new Public Service Act and the Achieving Cost Effective Personnel Services (ACEPS) process, the Department will consider changes to a range of conditions of service to improve productivity and efficiency.
5.A Certified Agreement should contain a pay increase for staff during its life.
6. A salary sacrifice (exchange) arrangement will be considered should staff wish to exchange cash salary for non‐cash benefits based on a menu of items.
7. The Department will support a move to new broadbanded classification arrangements, to be implemented during the life of the agreement.
8. No person will have their nominal salary package reduced as a result of moving into the new Certified Agreement.
9. A performance management mechanism will be needed to manage progression through the broadbanded salary ranges.

10. The Department will maintain, and seek to enhance, its policy of effective people development, and its strong commitment to allowing people to balance their work, family and personal responsibilities.
11. Agreements will be drafted in a way which allows us to include any changes arising from the new Public Service Act in 1998.
This document spells out in detail each of the eleven items on the front of the paper.

1. The Department's preferred approach is for one departmental Certified Agreement, with provision made in that agreement for Australian Workplace Agreements for staff, eg, the SES, Senior Officers or specialist staff. The agreement will operate for at least 18 months from certification.
Under the Workplace Relations Act, agreements made at the workplace will become more fundamental to Departmental operations.

In terms of equity across the organisation, and administrative simplicity, the preference is for one departmental Certified Agreement (CA). We will work to link the CA to operate in conjunction with other major Departmental documents and programs which support our activities, future directions and priorities.

You should all be familiar with the terms of the Department of Transport Agency Agreement 1994‐95. A new Departmental CA would essentially operate in the same way as this. However, the earlier document was largely an addendum to the umbrella APS Enterprise agreement, and did not have a major impact on local conditions of service. Given the Government's emphasis on workplace level agreements, a CA will now contain many more fundamental conditions of service than previously. A new CA will, in conjunction with other supporting legislation, be the principal document to establish pay rates and conditions of service.
Timing

The timing of an agreement is also important. While agreements have a notional maximum period of operation of three years, it remains to be seen whether this is the optimum period for DoTRD's requirements. Given a significant number of organisational changes, it may be better to have the first agreement operate for a lesser period, eg, eighteen months. This will avoid the possibility of the organisation being tied into an agreement which cannot easily adapt to changing situations.

While a CA of three years' duration (the maximum allowable under the Act) can be renegotiated at any time, we may be better served by a shorter term agreement, so that the parties can examine the changes which have occurred and any need for a different approach.
Australian Workplace Agreements (AWAs)

There still seems to be a degree of confusion as to what AWAs really are. The key is that they replace the award system entirely, thereby providing an almost unlimited amount of flexibility. However, they still do not override such Commonwealth legislative provisions as Maternity and Long Service Leave, OH&S provisions and superannuation. Similarly, AWAs will not include any provisions related to tenure.

In line with Government requirements, any departmental CA must include a clause which allows for the progressive introduction of AWAs, and for them to override CAs to the extent of any inconsistency. There has been no work to date in DoTRD to draft AWAs. However, they may be made available to staff such as the SES, Senior Officers or specialist staff where we agree there is mutual advantage to the organisation and staff.
2. A senior management team will be set up to negotiate agreements on behalf of the Department, with support from a working group within People & Technology.

A senior management team, which will comprise John Bowdler (Deputy Secretary), Bill Ellis (FAS Corporate) and one other SES Officer, will be set up to negotiate agreements on behalf of the Department. A working group from within People and Technology will also be established to provide research and administrative support to the management team. This working group will also act as a conduit between staff in general and the negotiating team, collating, analysing and passing on suggestions and ideas.

3. Considering the nature of our relationship with the various unions, the Department intends to use these established lines of communication in negotiating agreements. Additionally, individuals or groups may contact the management team to discuss the possibility of negotiating separately. All staff will be kept informed of progress with developing agreements so each employee can consider their interests and participation.
Whom do we negotiate with?

I am happy to negotiate with the CPSU and any other respondent union which wishes to be involved. The Department is committed to a consulta tive process which keeps everyone informed and gives the opportunity to provide input.

The Workplace Relations Act allows staff to form internal unions, provided there is a minimum of 50 employees genuinely prepared to join. Groups of staff are therefore entitled to form such a group to negotiate separately. Likewise, individuals, or groups of individuals may seek to negotiate Australian Workplace Agreements. The departmental management team will consider each application on its merits; correspondence should be sent to FAS Corporate in the first instance.
This is the opportunity for each of you to think about the approach you would like to see taken in the Department.
Education and information

This is particularly important given that under the new Act all affected staff will be asked to vote for or against a CA. Part of the CA certification process will necessarily involve proving to the Industrial Relations Commission that:

the Department has made every effort to inform all staff of the terms, conditions and effects of any agreement; and the majority of staff to whom the agreement will apply genuinely agree to accept the terms of the agreement.
The process by which we establish whether there is majority agreement (eg, show of hands, E‐Mail, secret ballot) is also open to negotiation.
The Department has a number of means by which to ensure that staff are given access to as much information as possible on developments:
. a Workplace Relations Unit within Employee Services to provide advice and updates, and respond to queries from staff;
. a new Workplace Relations section on the OA Bulletin Board;
Transard;
. providing workplace delegates with access to the OA Bulletin Board to give staff the opportunity to gain an understanding of the legislation from a different perspective; and
. information sessions which will be open to all staff throughout the bargaining period. Details of the initial sessions are provided at Attachment B.
As part of your response to this paper, please also let the Workplace Relations Unit know if there are any other ways in which you would like information disseminated.

We will continue to ensure that staff are given access to as much information as they feel they need. Much of the available information appears quite complex; and for some, details of the legislation are still unclear. The Department will aim to present information to staff which is clear and unambiguous, and attempt not to "overload" anyone. The Workplace Relations Unit is available to discuss issues in more detail with any staff member who wishes to do so. Please contact: Brendan Pigott (274 6631); Alice Lau (274 7055); or Graeme Pulford (274 6576).

4. Within the context of a new Public Service Act and the Achieving Cost Effective Personnel Services (ACEPS) process, the Department will consider changes to a range of conditions of service to improve productivity and efficiency.

Essentially, under the Workplace Relations Act, the Department is able to negotiate on most terms and conditions of employment. The exceptions are that we cannot reduce the level of benefit for such Commonwealth legislative provisions as Maternity and Long Service Leave, OH&S provisions and superannuation. Any other provisions, whether they are currently in awards or agreements, or are new initiatives, are eligible for variation and inclusion in the Department's CAs and AWAs.
Examples of areas in which the Department may seek to find efficiencies and savings include:
. rolling in/rationalising of allowances;
. revised classification structures;
. a reprofiling of the Department, in terms of levels and numbers of staff;
. an examination of administrative and corporate support requirements;
. personnel processing savings though ACEPS;
. rationalising accommodation; and
. through any decisions to outsource functions, or provide services to external organisations on a cost recovery basis.
5. A Certified Agreement should contain a pay increase for staff during its life.

There are continued budgetary restraints imposed on the Department. The requirement to have "budget-neutral" agreements makes it difficult to fund pay increases and those improvements in conditions which do not provide a dollar saving.

Nonetheless, the Government has recently given all departments and agencies a 1.5% increase in their salary related running costs. This and some other changes provide us with scope to consider making a pay increase available under an agreement.
6. A salary sacrifice (exchange) arrangement will be considered should staff wish to exchange cash salary for non‐cash benefits based on a menu of items.

Salary exchange is a scheme whereby staff can choose to take their remuneration as cash salary or a combination of cash and non‐cash items. The rationale behind the scheme is to provide a more flexible way to pay staff, and to provide net increases in remuneration at no cost to the Department's budget. It will also assist us in attracting and retaining quality staff, which will be a key aim of a new agreement.
The Department will look at offering a menu of non‐cash items which staff can access to suit their individual financial and personal situation, eg, access to a vehicle through novated leases, etc.
7. The Department will support a move to new broadbanded classification arrangements, to be implemented during the life of the agreement.

DIR have proposed in their advice 1997/10 of 7 April (on the OA Bulletin Board), a revised classification structure for the APS. This proposes that all major APS non-SES classifications be translated to an eight level structure, APS Officer Levels One to Six, and Senior Officer Bands One and Two. Essentially this move aligns all classifications with the current Administrative Service Officer/Senior Officer minimum salary points (SOB and SOA levels have been combined into the one classification). (see Attachment B.)

Under the terms of the Workplace Relations Act, Departments are able to introduce through agreements any broadbanding of the new structure which they consider appropriate. The Department would also consider a further rationalisation of this structure, eg, a DoTRD five level classification structure, which would incorporate fewer and broader salary points. A revised structure would aim to:
. enable greater flexibility in deploying staff;
. cut down on processing costs through fewer promotion and re‐classification
exercises;
. maintain merit as the cornerstone of staff selection;
. flatten hierarchies and increase emphasis on genuine teamwork; and
. provide greater mobility and career opportunities, particularly for lower level and technical/professional staff.

The introduction of a new structure, however, will not isolate the Department from other public service agencies. Our classification structure will still be linked to the general APS arrangements, so that people wishing to move into/out of the Department will be able to assess the level and salary of the position in which they are interested. In fact, the move to a single job "family" might have the effect of increasing mobility through a reduction in demarcation and the removal of small salary point differences across classification structures.
8. No person will have their nominal salary package reduced as a result of moving into the new Certified Agreement.

Part of the certification process for any Certified Agreement involves passing the Industrial Relations Commission "no‐disadvantage test". This means that agreements must not result in a reduction in employees' overall terms and conditions of employment when compared with the relevant award, and other applicable laws. Additionally, the Department will approach negotiations from the basic premise that no staff member will experience a reduction in their nominal salary package as a result of certification of agreements.
9. A performance management mechanism will be needed to manage progression through the broadbanded salary ranges.

Under a broadbanded classification structure with significantly wider salary points, the system of annual increments which we have become accustomed to will no longer exist. To administer salary increases under the new arrangements, the Department will need a robust performance management system which assesses staff performance at regular (but as yet undefined) intervals.

For example, the performance management system may involve an assessment of staff performance against a clear set of criteria, developed by staff and their managers. Effective levels of performance will be required for staff to progress through the new structure. Given the significant salary gaps between levels, and budget restraint, the concept of "automatic" salary increments can no longer exist.

10. The Department will maintain, and seek to enhance, its policy of effective people development, and its strong commitment to allowing people to balance their work, family and personal responsibilities.
People Framework

The Department is committed to support the concepts and practices of the People Charter. We will use the Investors in People program to ensure that people are treated as the key assets of the organisation, and that the Department continues to invest in your future. The aim is to deliver staff development opportunities appropriate to our current and emerging skill requirements, and which enhance individual staff member's skill levels. The People Framework will provide a more integrated and focussed approach to staff development through the use of Individual Development Plans, and more effective formal and on‐the‐job training.

Other programs within the DoTRD People Framework which we will continue to promote include: Leadership; ASO 1 to ASO 6 Development (including the GAA Program); Mobility; Personal Efficiency; and Recognition and Reward.
Work and family issues

DoTRD has been recognised as a leader in the development of initiatives which enable staff to better balance their work, family and personal responsibilities. New agreements will recognise and build on this, and will maintain our strong commitment to work and family issues.
11. Agreements will be drafted in a way which allows us to include any changes arising from the new Public Service Act in 1998.

The Public Service Bill was introduced into the House of Representatives on 29 June, and the new Public Service Act will become law in 1998—possibly on 1 January. This legislation, like the Workplace Relations Act, will signify a major change to the way people management is handled within the APS as a whole, and more specifically, within our Department. The Public Service Commissioner will still retain the power to issue enforceable directives relating to employment matters. However, these will only refer to minimum standards; Secretaries will be free to establish standards above the minimum and tailor them to the organisation.

Under the new Act, Secretaries will have far greater control over (among others) recruitment and selection, promotion and transfer, deployment, remuneration, performance management and termination of employment. Central agencies will no longer hold the proscriptive legislative power over these areas of employment.
All departmental agreements will have a facilitative clause which enables us to make use of the additional freedoms and responsibilities which arise from the new Act.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 9 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can explanatory notes be provided to explain the effect of subsection 7(1) of the Superannuation Act 1976.
(2) Specifically, what circumstances are intended to be covered by the term "otherwise terminated" which appears in subsection 7(1).
(3) Is resignation due to physical or mental incapacity covered within this subsection.

(4) Have there been any appeals at the Administrative Appeals Tribunal level or higher on this provision; if so; (a) what was the question involved in those appeals; and (b) what was the finding of the review body.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance and Administration has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

BREAK.PARA: (1) Subsection 7(1) of the Superannuation Act 1976 defines for the purposes of that Act what is meant by retirement on the ground of invalidity. It was described in the explanatory notes, that were provided at the time of introduction of the draft legislation to the Parliament in 1976, as providing that a reference to an eligible employee retiring on the grounds of invalidity should be read as a reference to his or her being retired on the ground of physical or mental incapacity to perform his or her duties.

(2) The term "otherwise terminated" was intended to cover the involuntary termination of an eligible employee's employment (otherwise than on invalidity grounds) because of physical or mental incapacity to perform his or her duties.
(3) No
(4) Three decisions by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (the AAT) are relevant; ie:
Re Brown and Commissioner for Superannuation (1991) 14 AAR 133;
Re Morejon and Commissioner for Superannuation (Unreported, A90/94,
Re Melito and Commissioner for Superannuation (Unreported, A92/105,

All three cases focused on the issue of whether an annulment of the applicant's probationary employment under section 47 of the Public Service Act 1922 on the grounds of failing to meet the entry medical standard meant that the applicant had been `retired' or had had their services `otherwise terminated' on `the ground of physical or mental incapacity to perform their duties' for the purposes of subsection 7(1).
The finding of the AAT in Re Brown included that:

(a) the reference to a `retirement' or `other termination' in subsection 7(1) indicated that `retirement' was a type of `termination' for subsection 7(1). Subsection 7(1) therefore only intended to deal with people who had their services terminated;

(b) the modes of `termination' to which subsection 7(1) should be applied should be viewed broadly. The AAT noted that many members of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme were not employed under the Public Service Act 1922 but had their terms and conditions of employment drawn from a variety of sources, including awards and contracts. Therefore subsection 7(1) should be given the `flexible and broad meaning `the legislature intended' it to have to cover these situations. An `annulment' could therefore fall within subsection 7(1);

(c) the operation of subsection 7(1) is confined to `the grounds upon which the applicant's services were, in fact, terminated.' The issue of whether a person who voluntarily terminated employment (eg, resigned) should have been retired `by reason of physical or mental incapacity to perform their duties' is a matter for subsection 7(2).
The decisions of the AAT in Re Morejon and Re Melito followed the decision of Re Brown.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 1 October 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Australian Government stop the dumping of hazardous waste in developing countries by ratifying the Basel Ban in domestic legislation, without reservation.

(2) Will the Australian Government agree not to undermine the ban on hazardous waste exports to developing countries by agreeing at the next Basel Convention Conference of Parties, in Malaysia to: (a) adopt the proposed hazardous waste list, without reservation; (b) not support the use of Article 11 trade agreements to bypass the ban; and (c) not support the expansion of the list (Annex 7) of countries that can export hazardous waste.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Government has not approved any arrangement to export hazardous waste to developing countries since the amendments to the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1989 came into force in December 1996.

If any application was received to dispose of hazardous waste in a developing country, it would be subject to the Basel Convention's requirements for environmentally sound management and for consent to be granted by the country of import. These requirements are incorporated in Australian legislation under the Hazardous Waste Act.

As a separate matter, the Australia Government will make a decision, after appropriate consultation, on whether or not to ratify the ban amendment when the technical aspects of the Basel lists are finalised. It is only when these lists have been adopted by the Conference of the Parties that there will be international agreement on what wastes are covered by the Convention and the ban amendment.

(2) The Fourth Meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Basel Convention has been postponed until late February 1998, and the Australian Government has not finalised its position on the issues raised.

Resolution of these issues is a matter of some complexity. For example, the ban amendment says that countries listed in Annex VII can only export hazardous waste to each other. They are prohibited from exporting hazardous wastes to developing countries not listed in Annex VII. On the face of it, it appears that expansion of Annex VII offers the possibility of increased environmental protection to developing countries not listed in that Annex in that more countries will be banned from exporting hazardous wastes to them. The need to examine these issues carefully means that an Australian position is not likely to be finalised until shortly before the Conference of the Parties.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 10 October 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to an internet web site (http://sahafarms.com/v4.html#parent) that advertises Saha Farms Co. Ltd, a chicken processing factory in Thailand, and displays a photograph of factory workers apparently handling chicken meat with bare hands:
(1) Does the Government believe that food handling with bare hands is an acceptable practice.
(2) Can the Government confirm or deny whether Saha Farms Co. Ltd is owned by one of the Thai companies who have applied to import cooked chicken meat to Australia.
(3) Has the Government taken any action in relation to the information or is any action proposed; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The use of gloves dones not preclude product from being contaminated nor does their non-use mean that product will become contaminated. Australian meat export regulations, for example, do not require use of gloves in handling of raw meat; regular hand-washing and other hygienic practices are the preferred means of maintaining sanitary conditions. Gloves are often worn in boning operations over protective metal mesh gloves to prevent lodging of material in the mesh. Proper precautions must be exercised when using disposable gloves in food handling operations, including discarding the gloves when perforated and their frequent cleaning during operations; otherwise their use may result in contamination of product.
(3) No action is proposed to be taken, as none is required.
